In this case, make sure to\nclose remoteStdin so the server knows the client won't be sending any\nmore data. This ensures that the remote process terminates. For example:\n\n```\necho foo | kubectl exec -i <pod> -- cat\n```\n\nWithout this change, the `cat` process never terminates and `kubectl\nexec` hangs.\n\nFix interactive exec sessions hanging after you type 'exit'.\n\nAdd e2e test to cover noninteractive stdin: `echo a | kubectl exec -i <pod>\ncat`\n\nAdd e2e test to cover psuedo-interactive stdin: `kubectl exec -i <pod> bash`\n\nPrep for sending multiple data frames over multiple streams in remote command\ntest, which is more likely to find flakes (requires bump of spdystream\nonce an issue with the frame worker queues not being fully drained when\na goaway frame is received).\n\nFixes #13394\nFixes #13395\n\n**Release note info**\nFixed hanging when using non-interactive stdin data, e.g.  `echo foo | kubectl exec -i <pod> -- "you", "type", "'exit"], "B_body": "There are two races that can occur in TestRequestExecuteRemoteCommand:\n1. The stdout/stderr streams are written and closed, and Execute() returns a nil error before the error written to the errorStream is copied and detected as an error inside Execute(). Manifests as:\n   \n   ```\n   --- FAIL: TestRequestExecuteRemoteCommand-2 (0.08s)\n       remotecommand_test.go:161: 0: expected an error\n   ```\n   \n   The fix is to wait for the errorStream to close (with or without an error) before returning nil\n2. The stdout/stderr streams are written and closed, and Execute() tears down all streams (including stdin) before the test driver can fully read the input. Fixing how we handle terminal width in help. Some sections like the flags use the entire available width, while others like long descriptions breaks lines but don't follow a well established max width (screenshot below). This PR adds a new responsive writer that will adjust to terminal width and set 80, 100, or 120 columns as the max width, but not more than that given POSIX best practices and recommendations for better readability.\n   ![terminal_width](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/158611/19253184/b23a983e-8f1f-11e6-9bae-667dd5981485.png)\n2. Adds our own normalizers for long descriptions and cmd examples which allows us better control about how things like lists, paragraphs, line breaks, etc are printed. Features markdown support. Looks like `templates.LongDesc` and `templates.Examples` instead of `dedent.Dedend`.\n3. Allows simple reordering and reuse of help and usage sections.\n4. Adds `verify-cli-conventions.sh` which intends to run tests to make sure cmd developers are using what we propose as [kubectl conventions](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/docs/devel/kubectl-conventions.md). Just a couple simple tests for now but the framework is there and it's easy to extend.\n5. Update [kubectl conventions](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/docs/devel/kubectl-conventions.md) to use our own normalizers instead of `dedent.Dedent`.\n\n**Release note**:\n\n<!--  Steps to write your release note:\n1. "A_body": "meta.Accessor returns some very informative messages that are currently discarded by the caller\n", "A_clean_body": ["meta", "accessor", "return", "some", "veri", "inform", "messag", "that", "are", "current", "discard", "by", "caller"], "B_body": "``` release-note\nGarbage collector is an alpha feature and is disabled by default. Garbage collector deletes the dependent objects when the owner object is deleted. The owner-dependent relationship is established by setting the `metadata.ownerReferences` field of the dependent object to the owner object. In 1.3 release, the `metadata.ownerReferences` has to be set manually by the user. Garbage collector is disabled by default. It can be enabled by setting the `--enable-garbage-collector=true` when starting the controller manager.\n```\n\nAdding the propagator and garbage processor of the gc.\n\nDesign doc is at https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/docs/proposals/garbage-collection.md\n\n<!-- Reviewable:start -->\n\n---\n\nThis change is [<img src=\"http://reviewable.k8s.io/review_button.svg\" height=\"35\" align=\"absmiddle\" alt=\"Reviewable\"/>](http://reviewable.k8s.io/reviews/kubernetes/kubernetes/24509)\n\n<!-- Reviewable:end -->\n", "B_clean_body": ["releas", "note", "garbag", "collector", "alpha", "featur", "disabl", "by", "default", "garbag", "collector", "delet", "depend", "object", "when", "owner", "object", "delet", "owner", "depend", "relationship", "establish", "by", "set", "metadata", "ownerrefer", "owner", "refer", "field", "depend", "object", "owner", "object", "releas", "metadata", "ownerrefer", "owner", "refer", "ha", "set", "manual", "by", "user", "garbag", "collector", "disabl", "by", "default", "it", "enabl", "by", "set", "enabl", "garbag", "collector=tru", "when", "start", "control", "manag", "ad", "propag", "garbag", "processor", "gc", "design", "doc", "at", "http", "collect", "md", "github", "com", "kubernet", "kubernet", "blob", "master", "doc", "propos", "garbag", "review", "start", "thi", "chang", "img", "src=", "http", "k8", "svg", "review", "button", "io", "review", "height=", "35", "align=", "absmiddl", "alt=", "review", "http", "k8", "review", "io", "review", "kubernet", "kubernet", "24509", "review", "end"], "title_sim": [0.009854528388839821], "body_sim": [0.07911512932225087], "file_list_sim": 0, "overlap_files_len": 0, "code_sim": [0.0, 0.0], "location_sim": [0.0, 0.0], "pattern": 0, "time": 23}, {"A_title": "fix annoying 'please check...' messages; The PR is based on the code one or two day after the code freeze. I'll rebase after the PR gets reviewed.\r\n\r\nFix https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/35159\r\n\r\n**What are converted to use versioned API**\r\n- top level:\r\n  - cmd/kube-controller-manager\r\n  - cmd/kubelet\r\n  - plugin/cmd/kube-scheduler\r\n  - e2e tests, node e2e test, integration tests\r\n  - cmd/kube-dns (minor changes)\r\n  - cmd/kubeadm (minor changes)\r\n\r\n- dependencies:\r\n  - pkg/client/cache\r\n  - pkg/serviceaccount\r\n  - pkg/fieldpath\r\n  - pkg/cloudprovider\r\n  - pkg/util/[ pod | replicaset | node ]\r\n  - pkg/volume\r\n  - pkg/security/apparmor\r\n  - pkg/credentialprovider\r\n  - pkg/securitycontext\r\n  - pkg/dns\r\n  - plugin/pkg/auth/[ authenticator | authorizor ]/token/webhook\r\n\r\n**What remain using internal API in purpose**\r\n- apiserver, including the SelfClient used by the authorizer\r\n- pkg/registry\r\n- plugin/pkg/admission, because Attribute.GetObject() currently gets internal API object\r\n- plugin/pkg/auth (except the webhook part), this package could be converted to use versioned API, but we don't have a strong incentive, and we want to reduce the ripple caused by this PR\r\n- kubectl: by design, kubectl talks to multiple API servers serving different versions of API, so the API-specific logic in kubectl should use the \"common language\", the internal version. (IMO, kubectl should use dynamic client, and offload API-specific logic to the server.)\r\n\r\n**N.B.**\r\n- shared informers (pkg/controller/informers): shared informers are converted to use versioned API. However, plugin/pkg/admission also depends on the shared informers, and it keeps using internal API. So I have to manually add some internal version informers/listers to the shared informers. @ncdc is working on generating the shared informers, with bother internal version and external versions.\r\n- pkg/quota: @derekwaynecarr @vishh this package is depended by both plugin/pkg/admission and the pkg/controller, so I had to make a duplicate package, pkg/quotainternal, to be imported by the admission. I haven't thought this through: if we can remove `ResourceName` and `ResouceList` out of the API, we probably can avoid the duplicate\r\n- kubectl: kubectl uses several pkg/controller functions, mainly in pkg/controller/deployment/util, which are migrated to use versioned API, while kubectl still uses internal API. I have call to the conversion functions several times, to keep using the deployment controller utility functions. @janetkuo @pwittrock \r\n- Init containers: v1.Pod.Spec.InitContainers and v1.Pod.Status.InitContainerStatuses are not serialized. It used to rely on the conversion mechanism to encode/decode to the annotation fields. Kubelet now operates on v1.Pod and doesn't do any conversion, so I have to let kubelet explicitly write/read the annotations (see the changes in pkg/kubelet/config/apiserver.go and pkg/kubelet/status/status_manager.go) cc @smarterclayton \r\n- Copied some validation functions (159 lines) to pkg/v1/validation.\r\n**TODO**\r\n- I duplicated pkg/api/[pod, endpoints, service] in {"A_title": "Remove a time test, it was flaky, and why do we care how long it takes?", "A_clean_title": ["remov", "time", "test", "it", "wa", "flaki", "whi", "we", "care", "how", "long", "it", "take"], "B_title": "Allow specifying scheme when proxying", "B_clean_title": ["allow", "specifi", "scheme", "when", "proxi"], "A_body": "@quinton-hoole because he likes deflaking tests\n@lavalamp because he wrote the original code\n", "A_clean_body": ["quinton", "hool", "becaus", "he", "like", "deflak", "test", "lavalamp", "becaus", "he", "wrote", "origin", "code"], "B_body": "Fixes #14194\nReopening https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/14876 which was reverted because of GKE test failures\n\nYou can currently proxy through the API server to nodes, services, and pods with the following syntax:\n- .../proxy/nodes/nodename[:port]/path/to/proxy\n- .../proxy/namespace/foo/services/servicename[:port]/path/to/proxy\n- .../proxy/namespace/foo/pods/podname[:port]/path/to/proxy\n- .../namespace/foo/pods/podname[:port]/proxy/path/to/proxy\n\nAll of these assume the backend is http. This makes the proxy much less useful than it should be.\n\nThis PR:\n- Adds support for `<scheme>:<name>:<port>` syntax (e.g. `.../namespace/foo/pods/https:podname:port/proxy/path/to/proxy`)\n- Tolerates TLS verification errors proxying to pods (since a pod won't have a valid certificate for its allocated IP)\n- Exports the transport used to proxy to pods to allow overriding or adding to TLS options\n- Add tests for proxying to https pod endpoints (depends on updated porter test image in https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/14837 before e2e tests will pass)\n\nIn addition, this PR fixed up usage of a custom dialer (for example, for SSH tunneling):\n- define RoundTripperWrapper interface to access inner transports, make all our wrapping transports implement it, have util functions to extract dialer/tls config\n- construct the transport from the custom dialer once, use it repeatedly to avoid keep-alive leaks\n- plumb custom dialers so they get returned in a transport from ResourceLocation() so there is a single path for deciding what dialer/tls options to use\n- define a Tunneler interface to encapsulate all the tunneling logic\n- assign the Tunneler Dial function to the KubeletConfig in server.go\n- use the dialer from the transport in dialURL (and unify with the generic rest dialURL implementation)\n- correctly plumb proxy transports through all ResourceLocation functions, and places where the generic rest proxy is used\n", "B_clean_body": ["fix", "14194", "reopen", "http", "github", "com", "kubernet", "kubernet", "pull", "14876", "which", First, we make sure that we are as incremental as possible.  The bigger change is that now we use rsync to move sources into the container and get data back out.\n\nTo do yet:\n- [x] Add a random password to rsync.  This is 128bit MD4, but it is better than nothing.\n- [x] Lock down rsync to only come from the host.\n- [x] Deal with remote docker engines -- this should be necessary for docker-machine on the mac.\n- [x] Allow users to specify the port for the rsync daemon.  Perhaps randomize this or let docker pick an ephemeral port and detect the port?\n- [x] Copy back generated files so that users can check them in.  This is done for `zz_generated.*` files generated by `make generated_files` \n  - [x] This should include generated proto files so that we can remove the hack-o-rama that is `hack/hack/update-*-dockerized.sh` \n- [x] Start \"versioning\" the build container and the data container so that the CI system doesn't have to be manually kicked.\n- [x] Get some benchmarks to qualify how much faster.\n\nThis replaces #28518 and is related to #30600.\n\ncc @thockin @spxtr @david-mcmahon @MHBauer \n\nBenchmarks by running `make clean ; sync ; time bash -xc 'time "A_clean_title": ["implement", "eb", "cinder", "attach", "detach"], "B_title": "AWS: Fix detaching volumes of  deleted pods", "B_clean_title": ["aw", "fix", "detach", "volum", "delet", "pod"], "A_body": "follow up with #21709\n\n@kubernetes/sig-storage \n", "A_clean_body": ["follow", "up", "21709", "storag", "kubernet", "sig"], "B_body": "When attachDiskAndVerify gives up waiting for a volume to be attached, AWS may be still trying to attach the volume.\n\nIf the pod that wants the volume attached still exists, kubelet will retry attaching the volume on next kubelet sync (and everything is allright).\n\nHowever, if the pod is deleted, AWS is still trying to attach the volume and it may eventually succeed. We end up with a volume attached to a node and no pod for it. Nobody will detach the volume.\n\nAs fix, just fire DetachVolume to AWS when attachDiskAndVerify gives up, without waiting for result. If associated pod still exists, it will try to attach the volume soon. If the pod is deleted, AWS will detach the volume (or stop attaching it).\n\nFixes: #24807\n\nThere are several tiny patches, the last one bringing everything together. I tested it really fixes the referenced issue, still I am open for better suggestions how to fix it in a better way.\n\n@justinsb @kubernetes/sig-storage \n", "B_clean_body": ["when", "percent"], "B_title": "Add some check about image garbagecollect", "B_clean_title": ["add", "some", "check", "about", "imag", "garbagecollect"], "A_body": "if LowThresholdPercent > HighThresholdPercent, amountToFree at image_manager.go:208 is negative and image GC will not free memory properly.\n\nJustification:\n\n1) LowThresholdPercent > HighThresholdPercent implies (LowThresholdPercent \\* capacity / 100) > (HighThresholdPercent \\* capacity / 100)\n2) usage is at least (HighThresholdPercent \\* capacity / 100)\n3) amountToFree = usage - (LowThresholdPercent \\* capacity / 100)\n\nCombining 1), 2) and 3) implies amountToFree can be negative.\n\nWhat happens if amountToFree is negative? in freeSpace method, \"for _, image := range images \" loops at least once\nand if everything goes fine, \"delete(im.imageRecords, image.id)\" is executed.\nWhen checking for condition \"if spaceFreed >= bytesToFree\", it is always true as bytesToFree is negative\nand spaceFreed is positive. The loop is finished, so is image GC.\n\nAt the end, only the oldest image is deleted. In situations where there is a lot of dead containers,\neach container corresponing to distinct image, number of unused images can get higher.\nIf two new images get pulled in every 5 minutes, image GC will not work properly and will not free enough space.\nSecondly, it will take a lot of time to free all unused images (hours depending on a number of unused images).\n\nThis is an incorrect configuration. "kubernet", "review", "io", "review", "kubernet", "kubernet", "37347", "review", "end"], "B_body": "Kubernetes attempts to unmount a wrong vSphere volume in v1.4.5. This fix addresses issue #37022 \r\n\r\nThe following steps are made to reproduce the issue:\r\n1. kubectl create -f guestbook.yaml\r\nA deployment is created with a volume spec - \"hello-master\" and volumePath - \"[datastore1] kubevols/sample-volume\". At this point, the pod has the volume \"[datastore1]kubevols/sample-volume\" mounted on it.\r\n\r\n2. kubectl delete -f guestbook.yaml\r\nWhen the deployment is deleted, kubernetes attempts to unmount the volume with volumeName - hello-master. Since it cannot find the volume \"hello-master\" mounted on the node, it stalls and doesn't make any progress after it.\r\n\r\nBecause of this, any subsequent recreation of deployments fails to mount the volume on the node as  the node stalls.\r\n\r\nThis problem occurred after fixing for issue #33203 on kubernetes repo -  Fix volume states out of sync problem after kubelet restarts. There were changes to SYNC loop logic in this fix.\r\n\r\nThere are 2 fixes that needs to made on 1.4.5 branch\r\n1. The changes to constructVolumeSpec() in the vSphere plugin to get the volumePath instead of volumeName.\r\n2. The changes to getDeviceNameFromMount() to get the full volumePath - \"[datastore1]kubevols/sample-volume\" instead of the just base of the volumePath -\"sample-volume\". I just observed that this function is fixed as a part of #36840 on master branch.\r\n\r\nAfter these changes, the deployment creations and deletions worked perfectly fine. Also the recreation of the deployment worked fine. The volumes are mounted to the pods correctly.\r\n\r\n@abrarshivani @kerneltime \r\n\r\n<!-- Reviewable:start -->\r\n---\r\nThis change is [<img parts**:\n  - containerMeta: all fields in `containerMeta` will be stored in separate labels. We may also want to use these labels as list filters in the future. The `containerMeta` should be seldom or even never changed.\n  - containerInfo: the `containerInfo` will be saved in one label as a whole.\n- **Checkpoint last container status into container info label.** With this, we can remove historical containers as soon as the new container is created (see #25239). However, because kubelet may still work with old containers which don't have this label, we still can't rely on this for now. Currently, we only use the `lastStatus` to calculate the restart count. @yujuhong @dchen1107 Can we assume that people will always drain node before updating kubelet? If so we can start relying on labels.\n- **Add label version.** Whenever we make any incompatible changes to the labels, we should bump up the label version and try to support backward compatibility relying on label version.\n\nNotice that with this PR, kubelet will stop reading _restart count_ and _termination message path_ from labels added in v1.2. It means that if someone does kubelet live upgrade from v1.2 to v1.3, the termination message of old containers will be lost, and restart count of the new container will be recalculated from 0.\n\nWe could add some code to prevent this, but that will make the code a bit more complex. Because restart count is just best effort and termination message path is seldom used, can we just ignore that like what we have done in v1.2? When update node status with mounted\nvolumes, the volume list might be empty although there are still volumes\nare mounted and in turn causing master to detach those volumes since\nthey are not in the mounted volumes list. This fix is to make sure only\nupdate mounted volumes list after reconciler starts sync states process.\nThis sync state process will scan the existing volume directories and\nreconstruct actual states if they are missing.\n\nThis PR also fixes the problem during orphaned pods' directories. In\ncase of the pod directory is unmounted but has not yet deleted (e.g.,\ninterrupted with kubelet restarts), clean up routine will delete the\ndirectory so that the pod directoriy could be cleaned up (it is safe to\ndelete directory since it is no longer mounted)\n\nThe third issue this PR fixes is that during reconstruct volume in\nactual state, mounter could not be nil since it is required for creating\ncontainer.VolumeMap. When a device is detached the cache does not get invalidated. A subsequent attachment for the same volume then falsely assumes that the device is already attached. It skip the actual API call to attach the volume and gets stuck in an endless loop waiting for the attachment to finish. It eventually times out and immediately starts to wait again. This only resolves once the kubelet is restarted.\n\nThis fix releases the device from the `deviceMapping` cache when a volume is detached. \n\nWith this fix volume attach/detach operations work perfectly for me. I'm a bit unsure though how such a fundamental bug wasn't noticed before? Did this ever work and this is a regression? It could be that previous tests had the pods scheduled to a different kubelet with cold cache? The `/proxy` endpoint is too open to give to anyone but cluster admins.  As part of https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/kubernetes/issues/3481 and the general \"bastioning\" of the API server, we want to introduce new sub resources that allow specific, typed access to a backend.  Examples:\n- Proxy to a pod's port: `/pods/foo/proxy/5000/some/resource`\n- Proxy to a service's port: `/services/foo/proxy/5000/some/resource/path`\n- Expose logs for a pod: `/pods/foo/logs?container=test` -> returns \"text/plain\" stream\n- Expose logs for a resource backed by a pod `/jobs/foo/logs` -> \n- Parameterize pod logs with query options: `/pods/foo/logs?container=test&since=30s`\n- Handle remote execution: `/pods/foo/exec?container=test&cmd=/bin/bash&arg=-c&arg=echo+$foo` -> upgrades connection to SPDY/HTTP2\n- Handle portforwarding: `/pods/foo/portforward/5000?container=test`\n- Allow binaries to be posted to an endpoint (with a given type) and converted by RESTStorage or apiserver into the underlying object - essentially hand off the request body to storage.\n\nThis requires three pieces of function:\n- Allow query parameters to be properly versioned across a set of distinct resources and verbs\n- Return an input stream from a RESTStorage Get or Post call\n- Upgrade an HTTP connection to a higher protocol (exec) or hijack it (port forward) or use it to proxy other requests (proxy)\n\nIdeally we would also ensure we have methods that allow proper introspection through swagger\n- Handle content type negotiation when returning an input stream\n- Annotate request parameters with metadata for query params\n\nThis pull request will contain the changes to enable that functionality through a set of targeted refactors.  @csrwng @lavalamp @bgrant0607 @liggitt\n", "A_clean_body": ["sub", "resourc", "are", "need", "properli", "secur", "proxi", "node", "as", "per", "agreement", "authz", "discuss", "becaus", "we", "need", "tie", "resourc", "verb", "action", "proxi", "endpoint", "too", "open", "give", "anyon", "but", "cluster", "admin", "as", "part", "http", "github", "com", "googlecloudplatform", "kubernet", "issu", "3481", "googl", "cloud", "platform", "gener", "bastion", "api", "server", "we", "want", "introduc", "new", "sub", "resourc", "that", "allow", "specif", "type", "access", "backend", "exampl", "proxi", "pod", "'s", "port", "pod", "foo", "proxi", "5000", "some", "resourc", "proxi", "servic", "'s", "port", "servic", "foo", "proxi", "5000", "some", "resourc", "path", "expos", "log", "pod", "pod", "foo", "log", "container=test", "return", "text", "plain", "stream", "expos", "log", "resourc", "back", "by", "pod", "job", "foo", "log", "parameter", "pod", "log", "queri", "option", "pod", "foo", "log", "container=test", "since=30", "handl", "remot", "execut", "pod", "foo", "exec", "container=test", "cmd=", "bin", "bash", "arg=", "arg=echo+", "foo", "upgrad", "connect", "spdi", "http2", "handl", "portforward", "pod", "foo", "portforward", "5000", "container=test", "allow", k8s.io/kubernetes/vendor/github.com/coreos/etcd/integration.(*member).Launch\r\n\t/root/kubernetes/_output/local/go/src/k8s.io/kubernetes/vendor/github.com/coreos/etcd/integration/cluster.go:609 +0x66c\r\nexit status 2\r\nFAIL\tk8s.io/kubernetes/federation/registry/cluster/etcd\t120.107s\r\n```\r\nThis error basically comes from not receiving any response from the socket address. Socket address generated in the version of etcd being used with kubernetes currently, contains '.' character whereas Go1.8 doesn't support '.' character in the socket address. So, latest 3.1.0 version of etcd resolved this problem by generating adresses which does not contain any '.' character. Kubernetes needs to update it's vendored etcd to 3.1.0 for the above mentioned reason. This pull request takes care of that.\r\n\r\nSigned-off-by: Abhishek Dasgupta <a10gupta@linux.vnet.ibm.com>", "A_clean_body": ["follow", "error", "wa", "come", "while", "run", "make", "j5", "test", "feder", "ingress", "test"], "A_body": "This PR (along with GLBC support [here](https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress/pull/278)) is a proposed fix for #39989. The Ingress controller uses a configMap reconciliation process to ensure that all underlying ingresses agree on a unique UID. This works for all of GLBC's resources except firewalls which need their own cluster-unique UID. This PR introduces a ProviderUid which is maintained and synchronized cross-cluster much like the UID. note**:\r\n```release-note\r\nNONE\r\n```\r\n\r\nFixes the `--local` flag for `kubectl set ...` sub-commands.\r\n**As of the 1.7 release**, `PrinterForCommand` was updated to [use a mapper and typer for unstructured objects](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/kubectl/cmd/util/factory_builder.go#L52), which further prevented the use of `--local` when there was no connection Follow the instructions for writing a release note: https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/devel/pull-requests.md#release-notes\r\n-->\r\n\r\n**What this PR does / why we need it**:\r\n\r\nThis adds Kubernetes 1.6 support to Juju charms.\r\n\r\nThis includes some large architectural changes in order to support multiple versions of Kubernetes with a single release of the charms. There are a few bug fixes in here as well, for issues that we discovered during testing.\r\n\r\n**Which issue this PR fixes** *(optional, in `fixes #<issue number>(, fixes #<issue_number>, ...)` format, will close that issue when PR gets merged)*: fixes #\r\n\r\n**Special notes for your reviewer**:\r\n\r\nThanks to @marcoceppi, @ktsakalozos, @jacekn, @mbruzek, @tvansteenburgh for their work in this feature branch as well!\r\n\r\n**Release note**:\r\n<!--  Steps to write your release note:\r\n1. Follow the instructions for writing a release note: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/docs/devel/pull-requests.md#release-notes\r\n-->\r\n\r\n**What this PR does / why we need it**:\r\n\r\nFollows up: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/41509\r\n\r\nUpdates `kubeadm token` to work as discussed in https://docs.google.com/document/d/1deJYPIF4LmhGjDVaqrswErIrV7mtwJgovtLnPCDxP7U/edit#\r\nPromotes the command from the `ex` subcommand which now is named `alpha` for clarity. (This will later become `kubeadm alpha phase`)\r\n\r\n**Which issue this PR fixes** *(optional, in `fixes #<issue number>(, fixes #<issue_number>, ...)` format, will close that issue when PR gets merged)*: fixes #\r\n\r\n**Special notes for your reviewer**:\r\n\r\nExample UX:\r\n```console\r\nsudo ./kubeadm token --help\r\nThis command will manage Bootstrap Token for you.\r\n  Please note this usage of this command is optional, and mostly for advanced users.\r\n\r\nIn short, Bootstrap Tokens are used for establishing bidirectional trust between a client and a server.\r\nA Bootstrap Token can be used when a client (for example a node that's about to join the cluster) needs\r\nto trust the server it is talking to. Then a Bootstrap Token with the \"signing\" usage can be used.\r\nBootstrap Tokens can also function as a way to allow short-lived authentication to the API Server\r\n(the token serves as a way for the API Server to trust the client), for example for doing the TLS Bootstrap.\r\n\r\nWhat is a Bootstrap Token more exactly?\r\n - It is a Secret in the kube-system namespace of type \"bootstrap.kubernetes.io/token\".\r\n - A Bootstrap Token must be of the form \"[a-z0-9]{6}.[a-z0-9]{16}\"; the former part is the public Token ID,\r\n   and the latter is the Token Secret, which must be kept private at all circumstances.\r\n - The name of the Secret must be named \"bootstrap-token-(token-id)\".\r\n\r\nYou can read more about Bootstrap Tokens in this proposal:\r\n\r\n  https://github.com/kubernetes/community/blob/master/contributors/design-proposals/bootstrap-discovery.md\r\n\r\nUsage:\r\n  kubeadm token [flags]\r\n  kubeadm token [command]\r\n\r\nAvailable Commands:\r\n  create      Create bootstrap tokens on the server.\r\n  delete      Delete bootstrap tokens on the server.\r\n  generate    Generate and print a bootstrap token, but do not create it on the server.\r\n  list        List bootstrap tokens on the server.\r\n\r\nFlags:\r\n      --kubeconfig string   The KubeConfig file to use for talking to the cluster (default \"/etc/kubernetes/admin.conf\")\r\n\r\nUse \"kubeadm token [command] --help\" for more information about a command.\r\nlucas@THENINJA:~/luxas/kubernetes$ sudo ./kubeadm token list\r\nTOKEN                     TTL         EXPIRES   USAGES                   DESCRIPTION\r\n70c388.41a07b703aa4bedf   <forever>   <never>   authentication,signing   The default bootstrap token generated by 'kubeadm init'.\r\nlucas@THENINJA:~/luxas/kubernetes$ sudo ./kubeadm token create\r\nc57e6a.abb75fa1debe555f\r\nlucas@THENINJA:~/luxas/kubernetes$ sudo ./kubeadm token list\r\nTOKEN                     TTL         EXPIRES   USAGES                   DESCRIPTION\r\n70c388.41a07b703aa4bedf   <forever>   <never>   authentication,signing   The default bootstrap token generated by 'kubeadm init'.\r\nc57e6a.abb75fa1debe555f   <forever>   <never>   authentication,signing   <none>\r\nlucas@THENINJA:~/luxas/kubernetes$ sudo ./kubeadm token create s\r\ntoken [\"s\"] was not of form [\"^([a-z0-9]{6})\\\\.([a-z0-9]{16})$\"]\r\nlucas@THENINJA:~/luxas/kubernetes$ sudo ./kubeadm token create c57e6a.abb75fa1debe555f\r\na token with id \"c57e6a\" already exists\r\nlucas@THENINJA:~/luxas/kubernetes$ sudo ./kubeadm token delete c57e6a.abb75fa1debe555f\r\nbootstrap token with id \"c57e6a\" deleted\r\n```\r\n\r\n**Release note**:\r\n<!--  Steps to write "patch", "handler", "work", "fine", "but", "retri", "were", "broken", "thi", "candid"], "B_body": "When applying a patch, the original state of the object and patch are captured so that retries can determine if an overlapping update was made to the object, and the patch API call should abort with a conflict.\r\n\r\nHowever, the `strategicPatchObject -> applyPatchToObject -> StrategicMergeMapPatch -> mergeMap` call mutates both the original object map and the patch map, making them unsuitable for reusing for subsequent calls.\r\n\r\nWe saw this in a [downstream test](https://github.com/openshift/origin/blob/master/test/integration/patch_test.go) that exercises patch conflict retries, where the data being submitted in a patch was showing up in the original object data map.\r\n\r\nSince mergeMap *also* mutates the patch map passed in (deletes patch directives as it encounters them), we *also* cannot reuse the patch map in `applyPatchToObject` once it has been used.\r\n\r\nThis PR:\r\n* Builds `originalObjMap` separate from the initial patch application for later use in conflict detection\r\n* Changes the `originalPatchMap` to a helper that returns a fresh map from original sources\r\n* Adds an integration test that exercises retry of non-overlapping patches with patches containing `$patch` directives\r\n\r\n```release-note\r\nFix incorrect For various (legal) reasons I need to have all my EBS volumes encrypted. EBS handles key management via KMS, so you can optionally specify the key to use.\n\nThere are some restrictions on the [instance types](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/EBSEncryption.html#EBSEncryption_supported_instances) to which these volumes can be attached. PR added a `Status` call in CRI, and the `RuntimeStatus` is defined as following:\r\n\r\n``` protobuf\r\nmessage RuntimeCondition {\r\n    // Type of runtime condition.\r\n    optional string type = 1;\r\n    // Status of the condition, one of true/false.\r\n    optional bool status = 2;\r\n    // Brief reason for the condition's last transition.\r\n    optional string reason = 3;\r\n    // Human readable message indicating details about last transition.\r\n    optional string message = 4;\r\n}\r\n\r\nmessage RuntimeStatus {\r\n    // Conditions is an array of current observed runtime conditions.\r\n    repeated RuntimeCondition conditions = 1;\r\n}\r\n```\r\n\r\nCurrently, only `conditions` is included in `RuntimeStatus`, and the definition is almost the same with `NodeCondition` and `PodCondition` in K8s api.\r\n\r\n@yujuhong @feiskyer @bprashanth If this makes sense, I'll send a follow up PR to let dockershim return `RuntimeStatus` and let kubelet make use of "hostip", "host", "ip", "field"], "B_title": "Support status.hostIP in downward API", "B_clean_title": ["support", "statu", "hostip", "host", "ip", "downward", "api"], "A_body": "**What this PR does / why we need it**:\r\n\r\nThis PR allows to use the `status.hostIP` field in the downward API area.\r\n\r\nGlobal host networks services are running over the k8s daemonSets like Heka for the logs.\r\nThe Heka is able to received over UDP / TCP logs from Pods.\r\nThe easy way to reach the host is by the downward API.\r\nCurrently, the downward API only supports the `spec.nodeName` that will obviously cost DNS operations.\r\n\r\n**Special notes for your reviewer**:\r\n\r\nThis is an example of the usage area of my PR: This is very easy to spot on the Unagi or GeeksPhone, but takes a large image (e.g. grab a 3 MB one from your photo camera) to see in the emulator.\n\nAfter quite some testing I tracked this down to the moment that the filter is applied (through WebGL, `gl.texImage2D` line). During this moment (which runs on the main thread, can't offload GL to a worker at the moment) the background images of the buttons disappear as well, even though there is no actual change on them. This is not only due to buttons or anything, but seem to happen on all background-images on the current view. Maybe a gecko flake or anything.\n\nI worked around the above by writing the image information to a canvas object embedded within the button, as an <img/> tag crashes B2G desktop there. now, the events module considers inherited properties as one of the\nvalid types, by default.\n\n```\n> process.version\n'v3.0.0'\n> events.EventEmitter.listenerCount(new events.EventEmitter(), 'toString')\n1\n```\n\nThis patch makes sure that the inherited properties are considered as\nnormal types and they will not be counted unless explicitly added.\n\n```\n> process.version\n'v4.0.0-pre'\n> events.EventEmitter.listenerCount(new events.EventEmitter(), 'toString')\n0\n> const emitter = new events.EventEmitter();\nundefined\n> emitter.on('toString', function() {});\nEventEmitter {\n  domain:\n   Domain {\n     domain: null,\n     _events: { error: [Function] },\n     _eventsCount: 1,\n     _maxListeners: undefined,\n     members: [] },\n  _events: { toString: [Function] },\n  _eventsCount: 1,\n  _maxListeners: undefined }\n> events.EventEmitter.listenerCount(emitter, 'toString')\n1\n```\n\nI am guessing this would be a `semver-major` {"A_title": "Fix child process stdio data loss with slow piped consumers", "A_clean_title": ["fix", "child", "process", "stdio", "data", "loss", "slow", "pipe", "consum"], "B_title": "stream: reset awaitDrain after manual .resume()", "B_clean_title": ["stream", "reset", "awaitdrain", "await", "drain", "after", "manual", "resum"], "A_body": "##### Checklist\n- [x] tests and code linting passes\n- [x] a test and/or benchmark is included\n- [ ] documentation is changed or added\n- [x] the commit message follows commit guidelines\n##### Affected core subsystem(s)\n- child-process\n##### Description of change\n\nThe `flushStdio()` checks if there are readable handlers attached to the stdio streams to prevent data loss but it doesn't check if there are piped consumers. Change it so that it checks `pipesCount` too.\n\nI also fixed the previous testcase on the same issue to actually catch the regression as it would previously pass regardless of what flushStdio was doing.\n\nFixes #7184 \n", "A_clean_body": ["checklist", "test", "code", "lint", "pass", "test", "or", "benchmark", "includ", "document", "chang", "or", "ad", "commit", "messag", "follow", "commit", "guidelin", "affect", "core", "subsystem", "child", "process", "descript", "chang", "flushstdio", "flush", "stdio", "check", "there", "are", "readabl", "handler", "attach", "stdio", "stream", "prevent", "data", "loss", "but", "it", "n't", "check", "there", "are", "pipe", "consum", "chang", "it", "so", "that", "it", "check", "pipescount", "pipe", "count", "too", "also", "fix", "previou", "testcas", "same", "issu", "actual", "catch", "regress", "as", "it", "would", "previous", "pass", "regardless", "what", "flushstdio", "flush", "stdio", "wa", "do", "fix", "7184"], "B_body": "##### Checklist\n- [x] tests and code linting passes\n- [x] a test and/or benchmark is included\n- [x] the commit message follows commit guidelines\n##### Affected core subsystem(s)\n\nstream\n##### Description of change\n\nReset the `readableState.awaitDrain` counter after manual calls to `.resume()`.\n\nWhat might happen otherwise is that a slow consumer at the end of the pipe could end up stalling the piping in the following scenario:\n1. The writable stream indicates that its buffer is full.\n2. This leads the readable stream to `pause()` and increase its `awaitDrain` counter, which will be decreased by the writable\u2019s next `drain` event.\n3. Something calls `.resume()` manually.\n4. The readable continues to pipe to the writable, but once again the writable stream indicates that the buffer is full.\n5. The `awaitDrain` counter is thus increased again, but since it has now been increased twice for a single piping destination, the next `drain` event will not be able to reset `awaitDrain` to zero.\n6. The pipe is stalled and no data is passed along anymore.\n\nThe solution in this commit is to reset the `awaitDrain` counter to zero when `resume()` is called.\n\nFixes: https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/7159\n\nThis bug is has been around at least since 0.12, and I don\u2019t currently know why it never popped up before #2325 when the `awaitDrain` mechanism worked like it does today.\n\n/cc @nodejs/streams \n", "B_clean_body": ["checklist", "test", "code", "lint", "pass", "test", "or", "benchmark", "includ", "commit", "messag", "follow", "commit", I'm not sure how to deal with that.\n\nIn test/parallel/test-crypto.js the message is changed from \"asn1 encoding routines:ASN1_CHECK_TLEN:wrong tag\" to \"asn1 encoding routines:asn1_check_tlen:wrong tag\".  (The function name in openssl got renamed from all capital letters to small letters.)\n\nIn test/parallel/test-tls-junk-server.js, the error message changed from \"/unknown protocol/\" to \"/wrong version number/\".\n\nIt also fixes 3 current issues with the test suite against the 1.0.2 version.\n\nWhen building against the 1.1.0 version there are various tests that fail.  There are a total of 11 test failures.\n\nSome tests assumes the TLS ticket is 48 bytes.  This was always just an implementation details and you could already ask OpenSSL what the size was.  The encryption got changed from AES128 to AES256 in 1.1.0 and so the size changed. I have no idea how to get that size to the right places in the test suite.\n\nSome of the other failures are related to ciphers that are disabled by default.  For instance anonymous ciphers like AECDH are disabled and you need to enable them by selecting a different security level, which can for instance be done by adding `@SECLEVEL=0` to the cipher list, but that's not compatible with the 1.0.x version.  Ciphers like 3DES and RC4 are disabled by default.\n\nOther tests fails because the key size that's used is too small.\n\nI'm not sure yet why some of the other tests fail.\n\nThere are also a bunch of warnings about deprecated functions. ["make", "it", "build", "openssl"], "A_body": "<!--\r\nThank you for your pull request. Please provide a description above and review\r\nthe requirements below.\r\n\r\nBug fixes and new features should include tests and possibly benchmarks.\r\n\r\nContributors guide: https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md\r\n-->\r\n\r\n##### Checklist\r\n<!-- Remove items that do not apply. For completed items, change [ ] to [x]. -->\r\n\r\n- [x] `make -j4 test` (UNIX), or `vcbuild test` (Windows) passes\r\n\r\n- [x] tests and/or benchmarks are included\r\n- [ ] documentation is changed or added\r\n- [x] commit message follows commit guidelines\r\n\r\n##### Affected core subsystem(s)\r\n<!-- Provide affected core subsystem(s) (like doc, cluster, crypto, etc). -->\r\ncrypto, tls\r\n\r\nThis PR is a big patch and please don't review this immediately.\r\n\r\nIt is time to make a decision if we upgrade OpenSSL-1.1.0 in Node-v8. It breaks API/ABI compatibilities with 1.0.2 so that it needs semver-major in this upgrade.\r\n\r\nI submit this patch for intending to show and demonstrate that upgrading to 1.1.0 can be done in all platforms. CI results has already shown in https://ci.nodejs.org/job/node-test-commit/8424/ and they are green except FreeBSD failure due to Jenkins error.\r\n\r\nBefore we make the decision, I think that the following three major issues should be discussed.\r\n\r\n1. Support end difference between Node LTS and OpenSSL\r\n\r\n   Node-v8 LTS Maintenance End will be in 2020-04. According to the current support policy of OpenSSL of https://www.openssl.org/policies/releasestrat.html , it says that\r\n   ```\r\n   Version 1.0.2 will be supported until 2019-12-31 (LTS).\r\n   Version 1.1.0 will be supported until 2018-08-31.\r\n   ```\r\n\r\n   If we continue to use openssl-1.0.2, Node-v8 LTS support should be end on 2019-12-31 about 3 months earlier than our plan as we did in v0.12.\r\n   1.1.0 will be support end in the next year. A new OpenSSL-1.1.1 is now under development and expected to be released near future with new feature of TLS1.3. It is API/ABI compatible with 1.1.0 so we can deploy it with semver-minor. A new OpenSSL release will be supported at least two years. If LTS is specified to it, it will be five years support.\r\n   If we deployed 1.1.0 in Node-v8, we need to make semver-minor upgrade of OpenSSL until to meet its support end of 2020-04.\r\n\r\n2. FIPS Support\r\n   \r\n   The current FIPS support is provided only for 1.0.2. There was an announcement of a sponsor to support FIPS compliance with OpenSSL 1.1 in\r\nhttps://www.openssl.org/blog/blog/2016/07/20/fips/ but it is not yet to known when new FIPS support is released.\r\n\r\n   If FIPS support is required in Node, we have to continue to use 1.0.2 until new FIPS support is released.\r\n\r\n3. New Build Requirement (nasm) on Windows\r\n\r\n   In order to build OpenSSL in Windows with asm support, NASM is officially required. https://github.com/openssl/openssl/blob/OpenSSL_1_1_0-stable/NOTES.WIN#L20-L23\r\n   ```\r\n   - Netwide Assembler, a.k.a. NASM, available from http://www.nasm.us,\r\n     is required if you intend to utilize assembler modules. Note that NASM\r\n     is the only supported assembler. The Microsoft provided assembler is NOT\r\n     supported.\r\n   ```\r\n\r\n   It was noted even in 1.0.2 and we have been ignoring this requirement. 1.1.0 begins to checks its requirement during build. We can avoid it with our own risk but I don't think it is a good way to go.   As it is inevitable, we should decide when and what version of Node the new requirement starts.\r\n\r\nThis PR adds an experimental support of OpenSSL-1.1.0e with a new flag `--use-openssl11` in configure and contines to use 1.0.2 by default. I think that it leads API complexities when we add a new feature specific to 1.1.0 and agree that it is not a good solution.\r\n\r\nMy preference is that we stay on 1.0.2 in Node-v8 and deploy 1.1.0 or 1.1.1 someday later in v9 or v10 with replacing 1.0.2. If FIPS support is not released at that time. we separate a new branch with 1.0.2 only to have FIPS support.\r\n\r\nCC @nodejs/crypto , @nodejs/lts", "A_clean_body": ["thank", "you", "your", "pull", For completed items, change [ ] to [x]. -->\n- [ ] `make -j4 test` (UNIX), or `vcbuild test nosign` (Windows) passes\n- [ ] commit message follows commit guidelines\n##### Affected core subsystem(s)\n\n<!-- Provide affected core subsystem(s) (like doc, cluster, crypto, etc). -->\n\ncrypto\n##### Description of change\n\n<!-- Provide a description of the change below this comment. -->\n\nThis is to make it possible to build against OpenSSL 1.1.0 (#4270)\n\nIt currently has 2 new test failures when build against 1.0.2, because OpenSSL generates a different error message in 1.0.2 and 1.1.0.  I'm not sure how to deal with that.\n\nIn test/parallel/test-crypto.js the message is changed from \"asn1 encoding routines:ASN1_CHECK_TLEN:wrong tag\" to \"asn1 encoding routines:asn1_check_tlen:wrong tag\".  (The function name in openssl got renamed from all capital letters to small letters.)\n\nIn test/parallel/test-tls-junk-server.js, the error message changed from \"/unknown protocol/\" to \"/wrong version number/\".\n\nIt also fixes 3 current issues with the test suite against the 1.0.2 version.\n\nWhen building against the 1.1.0 version there are various tests that fail.  There are a total of 11 test failures.\n\nSome tests assumes the TLS ticket is 48 bytes.  This was always just an implementation details and you could already ask OpenSSL what the size was.  The encryption got changed from AES128 to AES256 in 1.1.0 and so the size changed. I have no idea how to get that size to the right places in the test suite.\n\nSome of the other failures are related to ciphers that are disabled by default.  For instance anonymous ciphers like AECDH are disabled and you need to enable them by selecting a different security level, which can for instance be done by adding `@SECLEVEL=0` to the cipher list, but that's not compatible with the 1.0.x version.  Ciphers like 3DES and RC4 are disabled by default.\n\nOther tests fails because the key size that's used is too small.\n\nI'm not sure yet why some of the other tests fail.\n\nThere are also a bunch of warnings about deprecated functions.  I left them like they are.  The proper way to deal with it will probably break compatibility.\n\nPS: During make test I'm getting invalid opcode traps, this seems unrelated to my changes and doesn't seem to cause test suite "A_body": "### Pull Request check-list\n- [x] Does `make -j8 test` (UNIX) or `vcbuild test nosign` (Windows) pass with\n  this change (including linting)?\n- [x] Is the commit message formatted according to [CONTRIBUTING.md][0]?\n- [x] If this change fixes a bug (or a performance problem), is a regression\n  test (or a benchmark) included?\n### Affected core subsystem(s)\n\ncontextify\n### "location_sim": [1.0, 1.0], "pattern": 1, "time": 0}, {"A_title": "test: avoid test-cluster-master-kill flakiness", "A_clean_title": ["test", "avoid", "test", "cluster", "master", "kill", "flaki"], "B_title": "test: make cluster test more time tolerant on more platforms", "B_clean_title": ["test", "make", "cluster", "test", "more", "time", "toler", "more", "platform"], "A_body": "<!--\nThank you for submitting a pull request to Node.js. Before you submit, please\nreview below requirements and walk through the checklist. You can 'tick'\na box by using the letter \"x\": [x].\n\nRun the test suite by invoking: `make -j4 lint test` on linux or\n`vcbuild test nosign` on Windows.\n\nIf this aims to fix a regression or you\u2019re adding a feature, make sure you also\nwrite a test. Finally \u2013 if possible \u2013 a benchmark that quantifies your changes.\n\nFinally, read through our contributors guide and make adjustments as necessary:\nhttps://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md\n-->\n##### Checklist\n\n<!-- remove lines that do not apply to you -->\n- [X] tests and code linting passes\n- [X] a test and/or benchmark is included\n- [X] the commit message follows commit guidelines\n##### Affected core subsystem(s)\n\ntest, cluster\n##### Description of change\n\n<!-- provide a description of the change below this comment -->\n\nI've observed that _test-cluster-master-kill_ fails intermittently on an AIX 6.1 machine (oslevel 6100-07-08-1339) due to timeout before worker termination. There was a previous PR (https://github.com/nodejs/node-v0.x-archive/pull/9431) which arbitrarily increased the timeout for AIX to 1 second, however this value is still a guess and appears to be insufficient. It's also worth noting the arbitrary timeouts have also caused problems for other platforms, see https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/2891#issuecomment-179158473. Arbitrary timeouts cannot compensate for external factors such as system load.\n\nIn this PR I propose removing the timeout mechanism entirely, here is how the test currently works:\n1. Fork a master process from the test harness.\n2. The master uses cluster.fork to create a worker.\n3. The worker starts an HTTP server.\n4. The master will kill itself with process.exit.\n5. The worker will then also call process.exit as part of its [IPC pipe disconnect handler](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/8ebec086a50712bce675ae59c10ac30a4f01fa8d/lib/cluster.js#L547-L553). (*)\n6. The test harness will wait an arbitrary amount of time after the master's exit to check for the child's liveness, if it is still alive the test fails.\n\n(*) Without this mechanism the worker would become an orphan child of init.\n\nStep 6 is inherently flaky. The test was originally added as part of https://github.com/nodejs/node-v0.x-archive/commit/94d337eb0fbf78bda2af6938b4a65d3c94808caf#diff-0faa53fc02580d5de2ebb484c41d691cR498 where it specifically tested the new disconnect pathway.\n\nThe test boils down to the following actions:\n1. Cause the worker's disconnect handler to be run by calling exit(0) in the cluster master.\n2. Insure that the disconnect handler also exits the worker process.\n\nSince step 2 does not actually require step 1, I propose the following alternate flow:\n1. Fork a master process from the test harness.\n2. The master uses cluster.fork to create a worker.\n3. The worker starts an HTTP server.\n4. The master kills the IPC pipe (note this not the same as using the graceful cluster shutdown API in https://github.com/nodejs/node-v0.x-archive/pull/2740/commits/6c383c61611fb78d0961a332c1ad55d1d5514ba6) which causes the child to disconnect itself. Ungracefully closing the IPC pipe causes the child to execute the same disconnect handler it executes when the master calls exit(0).\n5. The master waits for the child's exit event.\n6. The test harness checks for the child's liveness after the master's exit event.\n\nWith this setup there is no need for the arbitrary wait time. The obvious problem is if the child never exits the test will hang - however in that case the test will still be killed by the [test harness's global timeout](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/8ebec086a50712bce675ae59c10ac30a4f01fa8d/tools/test.py#L587-L591).\n\nI do believe a timeout mechanism is useful for detecting liveness issues, but the presence of arbitrary timeouts in the tests themselves should be minimized, the single timeout in the test harness suffices.\n\nAny comments are appreciated, especially from @AndreasMadsen.\n", "A_clean_body": ["thank", "you", "submit", "pull", "request", "node", "js", "befor", "you", "submit", "pleas", "review", "below", "requir", "walk", "through", "checklist", "you", "'tick'", "box", "by", "letter", "run", "test", "suit", "by", "invok", "make", "j4", "lint", "test", "linux", "or", "vcbuild", "test", "nosign", "window", "thi", "aim", "fix", "regress", "or", "you", "re", "ad", containing non-ASCII characters", "B_clean_title": ["http", "reject", "path", "contain", "non", "ascii", "charact"], "A_body": "First commit:\n\nUnsanitized paths containing line feed characters can be used for header injection and request splitting so reject them with an exception.\n\nSecond commit:\n\nThe first commit is the result of nodejs-security@ discussion but I had a change of heart.  I can't see any reasonable use case for allowing control characters (characters <= 31) but I can think of several scenarios where they can be used to exploit software bugs so let's ban them altogether.\n\nThere is a a potential compatibility issue in that tabs in paths have been observed in the wild, but, to the best of my knowledge, only in requests from buggy HTTP clients.  Here too I don't see a reason to allow them in requests that node.js initiates.\n\n@nodejs/http @nodejs/security\n", "A_clean_body": ["first", "commit", "unsanit", "path", "contain", "line", "feed", "charact", "use", "header", "inject", "request", "split", "so", "reject", "them", "except", "second", "commit", "first", "commit", "result", "nodej", "secur", "discuss", "but", "had", "chang", "heart", "ca", "n't", "see", "ani", "reason", "use", "case", "allow", "control", "charact", "charact", "31", "but", "think", "sever", "scenario", "where", "they", "use", "exploit", "softwar", "bug", "so", "let", "'s", "ban", "them", "altogeth", "there", "potenti", "compat", "issu", "that", "tab", "path", "have", "been", "observ", "wild", "but", "best", "my", "knowledg", "onli", "request", "buggi", "http", "client", "here", "too", "n't", "see", "reason", "allow", "them", "request", "that", "node", "js", "initi", "nodej", "http", "nodej", "secur"], "B_body": "http would previously accept paths with non-ASCII characters. This\nproved problematic, because multi-byte characters were encoded as\n'binary', that is, the first byte was taken and the remaining bytes were\ndropped for that character.\n\nThere is no sensible way to fix this without breaking backwards\ncompatibility for paths containing U+0080 to U+00FF characters.\n\nWe already reject paths with unescaped spaces with an exception. This\ncommit does the same for paths with non-ASCII characters too.\n\nThe alternative would have been to encode paths in UTF-8, but this would\ncause the behaviour to silently change for paths with single-byte\nnon-ASCII characters (eg: the copyright character U+00A9 \u00a9). I find it\npreferable to to add to the existing prohibition of bad paths with\nspaces.\n\nFixes #2114\n", "B_clean_body": ["http", "would", "previous", "accept", "path", "non", "ascii", "charact", "thi", "prove", "problemat", "becaus", "multi", "byte", "charact", "were", "encod", "as", "'binari", "that", "first", "byte", "wa", "taken", "remain", "byte", "were", "drop", "that", "charact", "there", "no", "sensibl", "way", "fix", "thi", "without", "break", "backward", "compat", "path", "contain", "u+0080", "u+00ff", "charact", "we", "alreadi", "reject", "path", "unescap", "space", "except", "thi", "commit", "same", "path", "non", "ascii", "charact", "too", "altern", "would", "have", "been", "encod", "path", "utf", "but", "thi", "would", "caus", "behaviour", "silent", "chang", "path", "singl", "byte", "non", "ascii", "charact", "eg", "copyright", "charact", "u+00a9", "find", "it", "prefer", "add", "exist", "prohibit", "bad", "path", "space", "fix", "2114"], "title_sim": [0.5807540199283636], "body_sim": [0.46172558566958494], "file_list_sim": 1.0, "overlap_files_len": 2, "code_sim": [0.10187012920946537, 0.10187012920946537], "location_sim": [1.0, 1.0], "pattern": 0, "time": 374}, {"A_title": "module: add --preserve-symlinks command line flag", "A_clean_title": ["modul", "add", "preserv", "symlink", "command", "line", "flag"], "B_title": "Revert \"module: preserve symlinks when requiring\"", "B_clean_title": ["revert", "modul", "preserv", "symlink", "when", "requir"], "A_body": "##### Checklist\n- [ ] tests and code linting passes\n- [ ] a test and/or benchmark is included\n- [ ] documentation is changed or added\n- [ ] the commit message follows commit guidelines\n##### Affected core subsystem(s)\n\nmodule\n##### Description of change\n\nhttps://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5950 sought to address a bug in the module loader with regards to symlinked peer dependencies. The PR passed CITGM and CI on multiple runs and was landed as a semver-major in v6. Unfortunately, it came to light after that the change breaks a number of other cases. \n\n~~This reverts the change and adds two additional test cases (one for the original behavior, and a known-issue test for the symlinked peer dependency case.~~\nThis puts the new functionality behind the `--preserve-symlinks` command line flag. The pre-v6 behavior is the default. Using the `--preserve-symlinks` command line option will make Node.js use the new behavior.\n\nThis should be considered to be a temporary solution until a better fix for the symlinked peer dependencies problem is figured out.\n\nRefs: https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5950\n", "A_clean_body": ["checklist", "test", "code", "lint", "pass", "test", "or", "benchmark", "includ", "document", "chang", "or", "ad", "commit", "messag", "follow", "commit", "guidelin", "affect", "core", "subsystem", "modul", "descript", "chang", "http", "github", "com", "nodej", "node", "pull", "5950", "sought", "address", "bug", "modul", "loader", "regard", "symlink", "peer", "depend", "pr", "pass", "citgm", "ci", "multipl", "run", "wa", "land", "as", "semver", "major", "v6", "unfortun", "it", "came", "light", "after", "that", "chang", "break", "number", "other", "case", "~~thi", "revert", "chang", "add", "two", "addit", "test", "case", "one", "origin", "behavior", "known", "issu", "test", "symlink", "peer", "depend", "case", "thi", "put", "new", "function", "behind", "preserv", "symlink", "command", "line", "flag", "pre", "v6", "behavior", "default", "preserv", "symlink", "command", "line", "option", "will", "make", "node", "js", "use", "new", "behavior", "thi", "consid", "temporari", "solut", "until", "better", "fix", "symlink", "peer", "depend", "problem", "figur", "out", "ref", "http", "github", "com", "nodej", "node", "pull", "5950"], "B_body": "After much discussion, it seems that the change\nbroke the way require detects unique identity of\nthe binary modules. Please review below requirements.\n\nBug fixes and new features should include tests and possibly benchmarks.\n\nContributors guide: https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md\n-->\n##### Checklist\n\n<!-- Remove items that do not apply. For completed items, change [ ] to [x]. -->\n- [x] documentation is changed or added\n- [x] commit message follows commit guidelines\n##### Affected core subsystem(s)\n\n<!-- Provide affected core subsystem(s) (like doc, cluster, crypto, etc). -->\n##### Description of change\n\n<!-- Provide a description of the change below this comment. -->\n\n\"doc/api/fs.md\" file had some conflict markers like \"<<<<<<< HEAD\" that are visible at the bottom of https://nodejs.org/api/fs.html\n", "B_clean_body": ["thank", "you", "your", "pull", "request", "pleas", "review", "below", "requir", "bug", "fix", "new", "featur", "includ", "test", "possibl", "benchmark", "contributor", "guid", "http", "md", "github", "com", "nodej", "node", "blob", "master", "contribut", "checklist", "remov", "item", "that", "not", "appli", "complet", "item", "chang", "document", "chang", "or", "ad", "commit", "messag", "follow", "commit", "guidelin", "affect", "core", "subsystem", "provid", "affect", "core", "subsystem", "like", "doc", "cluster", "crypto", "etc", "descript", "chang", "provid", "descript", "chang", "below", "thi", "comment", "md", "doc", "api", "fs", "file", "had", "some", "conflict", "marker", "like", "head", "that", "are", "visibl", "at", "bottom", "http", "html", "nodej", "org", "api", "fs"], "title_sim": [0.000729122162077219], "body_sim": [0.7869262940749314], "file_list_sim": 0, "overlap_files_len": 0, "code_sim": [0.0, 0.0], "location_sim": [0.0, 0.0], "pattern": 0, "time": 1}, {"A_title": "Adding Core support for Promises", "A_clean_title": ["ad", "core", "support", "promis"], "B_title": "feature: Add Promises interface for fs", "B_clean_title": ["featur", "add", "promis", "interfac", "fs"], "A_body": "**Update 02/02/16 15:07:00 PST**: [Current state of the PR.](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-178876755)\n**Update 02/01/16 14:10:00 PST**: [Current state of the PR.](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-178223110)\n\n**Newcomers**: As a heads up, GitHub has [started clipping the thread down](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/37303/12769711/ea7538ce-c9ce-11e5-8762-d24798047a48.png). I'm going to start cataloguing common questions tonight, and I'll include them under this notice so that you can quickly look to see if there's an answer to your issue without having to search through the entire thread. Thanks for taking a look & weighing in! Whether you're for this change or against it, your feedback is valuable and I'll respond to it as soon as I'm able.\n## FAQ / TL;DR for newcomers\n#### **What is the current proposal?**\n\n_If_ landed, this will land **behind a flag**, moving out from behind the flag in the next major version as an unsupported API, finally becoming fully supported one major version after that. It **does not replace or supersede** the callback API, which will continue to be the canonical Node interface.\n\nPromise-returning variants will be exposed for all \"single-operation\" Node methods \u2014 that is to say, Streams and EventEmitter-based APIs are not included in this discussion.\n\nTo use promises:\n\n``` js\nconst fs = require('fs')\n\nfs.readFile.promise(__filename).then(data => {\n})\n```\n\nUsing promises with destructuring assignment (where available):\n\n``` js\nconst {readFile} = require('fs').promise\n\nreadFile(__filename).then(data => {\n})\n```\n\nAs a prerequisite to this PR landing, domains must work as expected with native Promises (they currently do not.) AsyncWrap is not blocked on this PR, neither is this PR blocked on AsyncWrap. Both PRs are blocked on getting adequate instrumentation of the microtask queue from V8 (we need a callback for \"microtask enqueued\" events so we can track their creation, and _ideally_ a way to step the microtask queue forward ourselves, running code between invocations.)\n\n---\n#### **Why use the promisify approach?**\n\nResponse [summed up here](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-178112150).\n\n---\n#### **Why not `fs.readFileAsync`?**\n\n@phpnode notes [that it could break existing users of `bluebird.promisifyAll`](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-178236803). Plus, the naming is [contentious](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-177889777).\n\n---\n#### **Why not return promises when callbacks are not given?**\n- @jasnell expresses [deep discomfort](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#discussion_r51464838) with switching return types.\n  - We already have to provide alternate APIs in some places due to \n\n---\n#### **Should programmer errors throw, or reject?**\n\nSummed up [here](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-178189824).\n\n---\n#### **What is the value in adding them to core?**\n\n@rvagg has been massively helpful in driving this conversation forward:\n- [What are the killer arguments for including this, what is the value in adding this vs. leaving it userland?](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-178361191),\n  - @domenic notes that [`async/await` is spec'd and roadmapped](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-178367909).\n  - [My response](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-178402443).\n  - @mikeal notes [that promises are part of the platform already, and that adding support increases the base of folks willing to help fix bugs with in interoperation with them](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-178727217)\n- @rvagg [asks for clarification on the value](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-179146506) as a part of this comment.\n  - [My (wordy, sorry) response](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-179186510).\n\n---\n#### **How do you address the need to keep core small while expanding the exposed API?**\n#### **Where do we draw the line in supporting language-level constructs?**\n\n@yoshuawuyts, @rvagg, and @DonutEspresso have largely driven this conversation:\n- @yoshuawuyts [asks](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-178887233).\n  - @mikeal [responds](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-178891923).\n  - @brianleroux [responds](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-178892671).\n  - [My response](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-178894842).\n- @DonutEspresso [raises concerns](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-178926163).\n  - [My response](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-178942306).\n- @rvagg [asks](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-179146506) as a part of this comment.\n  - [My (wordy, sorry) response](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-179186510).\n\n---\n#### **Why are modules (like `require('fs/promise')`) not in scope for this discussion?**\n\n@phpnode, @RReverser, @mikeal, @ktrott, (and others, I'm sure!) have brought this up, and I've been pushing to have this conversation in a different, later issue. The conversation has mainly revolved around consensus, and the difficulty in attaining it when adding modules to the mix.\n- @ktrott does an [excellent job of summing up the concern](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-179452337).\n  - My [(again wordy, sorry!) response](https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5020#issuecomment-179505468).\n\n---\n\n**This is the original text of the PR.** It does not reflect the current state of the conversation. See above for common themes!\nThis PR introduces Core support for Promises. Where possible, callbacks have\nbeen made optional; when omitted, a `Promise` is returned. For some APIs (like\n`http.get` and `crypto.randomBytes`) this approach is not feasible. In those\ncases promise-returning `*Async` versions have been added\n(`crypto.randomBytesAsync`). The naming there isn't set in stone, but it's\nbased on how [`bluebird`](http://bluebirdjs.com/)'s [`promisifyAll`](http://bluebirdjs.com/docs/api/promise.promisifyall.html)\nmethod generates names.\n\nThis PR allows users to swap the _implementation_ of promises used by core.\nThis helps in a few dimensions:\n- Folks that prefer a particular flavor of Promises for sugar methods can set\n  the promise implementation at app-level and forget about it.\n- This should alleviate concerns about stifling ecosystem creativity \u2014 putting\n  promises in Core doesn't mean Core needs to pick a winner.\n- Folks who prefer a faster implementation of promises can swap in their\n  preferred library; folks who want to use whatever native debugging is added\n  at the V8 level for native promises can avoid swapping in promises.\n- A world of benchmarks opens up for Promise library authors \u2014 any code in the\n  ecosystem that uses promises generated by core and has a benchmarking suite\n  is a potential benchmark for promise libraries.\n\nThe API for swapping implementations is `process.setPromiseImplementation()`.\nIt may be used many times, **however** after the first time deprecation warnings\nare logged with the origin of the _first_ call. This way if a package misbehaves\nand sets the implementation for an application, it's easy to track down.\n\nExample:\n\n``` js\nprocess.setPromiseImplementation(require('bluebird'));\n\nconst fs = require('fs');\n\nfs.readFile('/usr/share/dict/words', 'utf8')\n  .then(words => console.log(`there are ${words.split('\\n').length} words`))\n  .catch(err => console.error(`there are no words`));\n```\n\nStreams are notably missing from this PR \u2013 promisifying streams is more\ninvolved since the ecosystem already relies on a common (and more importantly,\noften **pinned**) definition of how that type works. Changing streams will take\neffort and attention from the @nodejs/streams WG. All other callback-exposing\nmodules and methods have been promisified (or an alternative made available),\nthough.\n\nThree new internal modules have been added:\n- `lib/internal/promises` \u2014 tracks the original builtin `Promise` object, as \n  well as the currently selected `Promise` implementation. All promises \n  created by Node are initially native, and then passed to the selected\n  implementation's `.resolve` function to cast them.\n- `lib/internal/promisify` \u2014 turn a callback-accepting function into one that\n  accepts callbacks _or_ generates promises. Errors thrown on the same tick\n  are still thrown, not returned as rejected promises \u2014 in other words,\n  programmer errors, such as invalid encodings, are still eagerly thrown.\n- `lib/internal/callbackify` \u2014 turn a synchronous or promise-returning function\n  into a callback-accepting function. This is only used in `lib/readline` for\n  the `completer` functionality. This could probably fall off this PR, but it\n  would be useful for subsequent changes to streams.\n## Breaking Changes\n- In general: any API that would have thrown with no callback most likely does\n  **not** throw now.\n- `fs` APIs called without a callback will no longer crash the process with an\n  exception.\n- `ChildProcess#send` with no callback no longer returns `Boolean`, instead\n  returns `Promise` that resolves when `.send` has completed.\n- Wrapped APIs:\n  - `child_process.ChildProcess#send`\n  - `cluster.disconnect`\n  - `dgram.Socket#bind`\n  - `dgram.Socket#close`\n  - `dgram.Socket#send`\n  - `dgram.Socket#sendto`\n  - `dns.lookupService`\n  - `dns.lookup`\n  - `dns.resolve`\n  - `fs.access`\n  - `fs.appendFile`\n  - `fs.chmod`\n  - `fs.chown`\n  - `fs.close`\n  - `fs.exists`\n  - `fs.fchmod`\n  - `fs.fchown`\n  - `fs.fdatasync`\n  - `fs.fstat`\n  - `fs.fsync`\n  - `fs.ftruncate`\n  - `fs.futimes`\n  - `fs.lchmod`\n  - `fs.lchown`\n  - `fs.link`\n  - `fs.lstat`\n  - `fs.mkdir`\n  - `fs.open`\n  - `fs.readFile`\n  - `fs.readdir`\n  - `fs.readlink`\n  - `fs.realpath`\n  - `fs.rename`\n  - `fs.rmdir`\n  - `fs.stat`\n  - `fs.symlink`\n  - `fs.unlink`\n  - `fs.utimes`\n  - `fs.writeFile`\n  - `net.Socket#setTimeout`\n  - `readline.Interface#question`\n  - `repl.REPLServer#complete`\n  - `zlib.deflateRaw`\n  - `zlib.deflate`\n  - `zlib.gunzip`\n  - `zlib.gzip`\n  - `zlib.inflateRaw`\n  - `zlib.inflate`\n  - `zlib.unzip`\n## New APIs\n- **`process.setPromiseImplementation`**\n- `net.connectAsync`\n- `tls.connectAsync`\n- `crypto.randomBytesAsync`\n- `crypto.pbkdf2Async`\n- `crypto.pseudoRandomBytesAsync`\n- `crypto.rngAsync`\n- `crypto.prngAsync`\n- `http.getAsync`\n- `https.getAsync`\n- `http.requestAsync`\n- `https.requestAsync`\n- `child_process.execAsync`\n- `child_process.execFileAsync`\n## Next steps\n\nI haven't finished this PR yet: the primary missing piece is tests for the\npromise-based APIs, to ensure that they resolve to the correct values. Docs\nalso need updated. I'll be working on this in my free time over the next week.\n\nHere are the bits that I'd like folks reading this to keep in mind:\n- The code changes here are fairly cheap, time-wise \u2014 one evening's worth of work.\n  - Technical possibility has never been the primary blocker.\n- We know async/await is coming down the pipe, and many devs are interested in\n  it.\n  - With ChakraCore potentially coming in, this may happen sooner than anyone\n    previously imagined.\n  - Even sans the ChakraCore PR, it's my understanding that V8 will be supporting\n    async/await by EOY (Correct me if I'm wrong, here!)\n- **Promises may not be your cup of tea.** This is okay. This is not an attempt to \n  **replace** callbacks or streams with promises. They can co-exist. While Promises \n  are complicated, much of that complication falls out of the problem space that \n  both callbacks and promises abstract over. Give this a fair shake.\n", "A_clean_body": ["updat", "02", "02", "16", "15:07:00", "pst", "current", "state", "pr", "http", "github", "com", "nodej", "node", "pull", "5020", "issuecom", "178876755", "B_title": "querystring: avoid conflicts with Object.prototype and __proto__", "B_clean_title": ["querystr", "avoid", "conflict", "object", "prototyp", "proto"], "A_body": "### Pull Request check-list\n- [x] Does `make -j8 test` (UNIX) or `vcbuild test nosign` (Windows) pass with\n  this change (including linting)?\n- [x] Is the commit message formatted according to [CONTRIBUTING.md][0]?\n- [x] If this change fixes a bug (or a performance problem), is a regression\n  test (or a benchmark) included?\n### Affected core subsystem(s)\n\nquerystring\n### Description of change\n\nPer #5642, using querystring.parse to parse `'a=b&__proto__=1'` causes the `__proto__` to be swallowed and ignored. This works around the limitation by temporarily setting the prototype of the parsed obj to null during the parse, then setting it back before returning. \n\nThe rest of the existing implementation remains the same.\n\nFixes: https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/5642\n\n/cc @mscdex @WebReflection \n", "A_clean_body": ["pull", "request", "check", "list", "make", "j8", "test", "unix", "or", Please provide a description above and review\r\nthe requirements below.\r\n\r\nBug fixes and new features should include tests and possibly benchmarks.\r\n\r\nContributors guide: https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md\r\n-->\r\nThe workaround used in repl to support `let` and `const` in non-strict mode has been unnecessary since [V8 v4.9](https://v8project.blogspot.com/2016/01/v8-release-49.html) / [Node.js v6.0.0](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/doc/changelogs/CHANGELOG_V6.md#6.0.0). The first commit removes this workaround, known as \"magic\" mode. The second commit doc-deprecate magic mode (which is now entirely equivalent to sloppy mode) in both `repl` module and in `internal/repl`, which is responsible for starting the REPL in `node` interactive mode.\r\n\r\nRef: https://v8project.blogspot.com/2016/01/v8-release-49.html\r\nRefs: https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/doc/changelogs/CHANGELOG_V6.md#6.0.0\r\n\r\n##### Checklist\r\n<!-- Remove items that do not apply. As of V8 release 4.9, all of these features are now enabled outside of strict mode as well, per the ES2015 spec. This makes prototyping in the DevTools Console much easier, although we encourage developers in general to upgrade to strict mode for new code.\n\nAlso IMHO, `magic` mode is tightly coupled with  JS "remov", "common", "noop"], "B_title": "test: make common.noop a getter", "B_clean_title": ["test", "make", "common", "noop", "getter"], "A_body": "This change removes `common.noop` from the Node.js internal testing\r\ncommon module.\r\n\r\nOver the last few weeks, I've grown to dislike the `common.noop`\r\nabstraction.\r\n\r\nFirst, new (and experienced) contributors are unaware of it and so it\r\nresults in a large number of low-value nits on PRs. It also increases\r\nthe number of things newcomers and infrequent contributors have to be\r\naware of to be effective on the project.\r\n\r\nSecond, it is confusing. Is it a singleton/property or a getter? Which\r\nshould be expected? This can lead to subtle and hard-to-find bugs. (To\r\nmy knowledge, none have landed on master. But I also think it's only a\r\nmatter of time.)\r\n\r\nThird, the abstraction is low-value in my opinion. What does it really\r\nget us? A case could me made that it is without value at all.\r\n\r\nLastly, and this is minor, but the abstraction is wordier than not using\r\nthe abstraction. `common.noop` doesn't save anything over `() => {}`.\r\n\r\nSo, I propose removing it.\r\n\r\n<!--\r\nThank you for your pull request. socket, so the OS happily writes to the server socket and the `socket.destroy()` notification is seen as an EOF. "B_body": "##### Checklist\n- [x] tests and code linting passes\n- [x] a test and/or benchmark is included\n- [x] documentation is changed or added\n- [x] the commit message follows commit guidelines\n##### Affected core subsystem(s)\n- `deps`\n##### Description of change\n\nThe biggest thing in this release is that it fixes the tests on Windows. \n\nThere are a couple of Windows related bug fixes that were exposed by fixing the tests on Windows. Notably:\n- The use of `npm explore` to run a command from the directory of a dependency didn't work correctly on Windows.\n- `npm init` and others that inferred the module name from the path failed with scoped modules on Windows.\n- Removing globally installed bins for scoped modules previously failed on Windows. (And was incorrect, but working by-accident elsewhere.)\n- Correct `npm cache ls` to output real filenames\u2013 previously it sometimes mistakenly double the package name in the path, resulting paths that don't exist.\n- `npm` now warns if you paste in a command line that uses non-ascii dashes (like emdashes or endashes), as this is almost certainly not intended.\n\nAnd one new feature:\n- If we got a cache-hit for module metadata but the version requested does not exist in the metadata, we then explicitly ask the registry for updated metadata. This removes one of the primary pain points of using a very high `--cache-min`.\n##### Changelogs\n- [v3.9.0](https://github.com/npm/npm/releases/tag/v3.9.0)\n##### Reviewers\n\n**r: @zkat**\n**r: The existing asm code for S390 uses an ST/STG\ninstruction, with the memory operand associated with the general ('=g')\nconstraint to sp_addr.\n\nOn GCC 4.8.5, the GCC compiler got confused and treated sp_addr as\nan integer operand instead of memory operand, resulting in a store\nbeing emitted that writes to an invalid meory location.\n\nGiven the specific store instructions being inlined here, we should\nrestict the sp_addr operand to explicitly be a memory operand using '=m'\ninstead of '=g'.\n\nR=bmeurer@chromium.org,jkummerow@chormium.org,rmcilroy@chromium.org,yangguo@chromium.org\nBUG=\n\nReview-Url: https://codereview.chromium.org/2158523002\nCr-Commit-Position:
