Please review below requirements.\r\n\r\nBug fixes and new features should include tests and possibly benchmarks.\r\n\r\nContributors guide: https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md\r\n-->\r\n\r\n##### Checklist\r\n<!-- Remove items that do not apply. For completed items, change [ ] to [x]. -->\r\n\r\n- [x] `make -j8 test` (UNIX), or `vcbuild test nosign` (Windows) passes\r\n- [x] tests and/or benchmarks are included\r\n- [x] documentation is changed or added\r\n- [x] commit message follows commit guidelines\r\n\r\n##### Affected core subsystem(s)\r\n<!-- Provide affected core subsystem(s) (like doc, cluster, crypto, etc). -->\r\n\r\n* `deps`\r\n\r\n##### Description of change\r\n<!-- Provide a description of the change below this comment. -->\r\n\r\nBreaking changes:\r\n\r\n* Partial shrinkwraps are no longer supported. `npm-shrinkwrap.json` is\r\n  considered a complete installation manifest except for `devDependencies`.\r\n* `npm shrinkwrap` includes development dependencies by default. You can avoid doing this with `npm shrinkwrap --only=prod`. Likewise if your shrinkwrap contains dev dependencies you can avoid installing them with `npm install --only=prod` or setting `NODE_ENV` to `production`.\r\n* `prepublish` has been deprecated, replaced by `prepare`. A `prepublishOnly`\r\n  script has been temporarily added, which will *only* run on `npm publish`.\r\n* `npm search` rewritten to stream results, and no longer supports sorting.\r\n* `npm scripts` no longer prepend the path of the node executable used to run\r\n  npm before running scripts. A `--scripts-prepend-node-path` option has been\r\n  added to configure this behavior.\r\n* `npat` has been removed.\r\n* `npm outdated` exits with exit code `1` if it finds any outdated packages.\r\n* `npm tag` has been removed after a deprecation cycle. Use `npm dist-tag`.\r\n\r\nOther notable changes:\r\n\r\n* npm will now send `Npm-In-CI` and `Npm-Scope` headers to registries when fetching modules. The former will allow registries to more accurately distinguish between CI and user traffic. The latter will allow registries to implement features on the basis of the scope of the project (rather than the module actually being installed).\r\n\r\nChangelogs\r\n\r\n* [v4.0.0](https://github.com/npm/npm/releases/tag/v4.0.0)\r\n* [v4.0.1](https://github.com/npm/npm/releases/tag/v4.0.1)\r\n* [v4.0.2](https://github.com/npm/npm/releases/tag/v4.0.2)\r\n\r\nr: @jasnell "releas", "tag", "v4", "jasnel", "fishrock123"], "B_body": "<!--\nThank you for your pull request. Please review below requirements.\n\nBug fixes and new features should include tests and possibly benchmarks.\n\nContributors guide: https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md\n-->\n##### Checklist\n\n<!-- Remove items that do not apply. For completed items, change [ ] to [x]. -->\n- [x] `make -j8 test` (UNIX), or `vcbuild test nosign` (Windows) passes\n- [x] tests and/or benchmarks are included\n- [x] documentation is changed or added\n- [x] commit message follows commit guidelines\n##### Affected core subsystem(s)\n\n<!-- Provide affected core subsystem(s) (like doc, cluster, crypto, etc). -->\n- `deps`\n##### Description of change\n\n<!-- Provide a description of the change below this comment. -->\n\nHey y'all! #8977 was created a while back to track stuff surrounding this release, and I think it's a good decision to wait to do a minor bump later, rather than rush this release out in any way. Thanks a bunch for your patience!\n\nAs you can see, this is a semver-major bump for npm. That said, the actual impact of the release to the ecosystem is relatively small. Most certainly much smaller in impact than `npm@3` was. We're still sniffing out a couple of issues and might even put together an `npm@4.0.2` soon to iron that out before `npm@4` becomes `latest`.\n\n**THIS IS NOT A FINAL RELEASE** -- as mentioned in #8977, this is a preview of `npm@4` so y'all can start testing and taking a look at changes and make sure everything looks good before considering including it with official node releases.\n\nOne more note: With the release of `npm@4`, we've decided to move _both_ `npm@2` and `npm@3` to maintenance: that means we're unlikely to continue adding features to either of those, but will include critical patches, specially security patches, if something comes up. Regular bugfixes will not be done, as it's much better for our team to be able to focus on the latest release which we're standing behind. As far as Node Core is concerned, though, `npm@2` continues what we consider to be a sort of LTS release for y'all's sake. Maintenance doesn't mean it's no longer maintained, and users should continue to have a working experience with `npm@2` until `node@4` leaves LTS. `npm@3.10.9`, which I'll be downstreaming soon, might end up being our last `npm@3` release.\n\nSo without further ado, `npm@4`!\n##### Breaking Changes\n- `npm search` rewritten to stream results, and no longer supports sorting.\n- `npm scripts` no longer prepend the path of the node executable used to run npm before running scripts. A `--scripts-prepend-node-path` option has been added to configure this behavior. (/cc @addaleax)\n- `prepublish` has been deprecated, replaced by `prepare`. A `prepublishOnly` script has been temporarily added, which will _only_ run on `npm publish`. **NOTE**: This change only affects users publishing new versions of their packages and developers installing through git and local deps. Registry installs should be (mostly) unaffected by this change.\n- `npm outdated` exits with exit code `1` if it finds any outdated packages. (/cc @watilde)\n- `npm tag` has been removed after a deprecation cycle. Use `npm dist-tag`.\n- Partial shrinkwraps are no longer supported. `npm-shrinkwrap.json` is considered a complete installation manifest except for `devDependencies`. This will affect certain projects that relied heavily on this feature, most notably `hapi`.\n- `devDependencies` are now included in `npm-shrinkwrap.json` by default. This should make the transition to `npm@5` easier.\n##### Other Notable Changes\n- npm now sends two extra http headers to the registry ([npm/npm#14129](https://github.com/npm/npm/pull/14129)):\n  - `Npm-In-CI` - whether npm was run within a Continuous Integration environment.\n  - `Npm-Scope` - the scope of the toplevel package this installation is for. For example, if you have a `@node/foo` package, all dependency requests for that package will include `@node` in the header, even if those dependencies themselves are not scoped or are for a different scope.\n##### Changelogs\n- [`v3.10.9`](https://github.com/npm/npm/releases/tag/v3.10.9)\n- [`v4.0.0`](https://github.com/npm/npm/releases/tag/v4.0.0)\n- [`v4.0.1`](https://github.com/npm/npm/releases/tag/v4.0.1)\n\n**r**: @Fishrock123 \n**r**: @addaleax \n**r**: @jasnell \n", "B_clean_body": ["thank", "you", "your", "pull", "request", "pleas", NDFrame\n\naffects #4080, #3862, #816, #3217, #3386, #4463, #4204, #4118 , #4555\n\nPreserves pickle compat\nvery few tests were changed (and only for compat on return objects)\na few performance enhancements, a couple of regressions (see bottom)\n\n_obviously this is a large change in terms of the codebase, but it brings more consistency between series/frame/panel (not all of this is there yet, but future changes are much easier)_\n\n_Series is now like Frame in that it has a BlockManager (called SingleBlockManager), which holds a block (of any type we support). This introduced some overhead in doing certain operations, which I spent a lot of time optimizing away, further optimizations will come from cythonizing the core/internals, which should be straightforward at this point_\n\nHighlites below:\n\nIn 0.13.0 there is a major refactor primarily to subclass `Series` from `NDFrame`,\nwhich is the base class currently for `DataFrame` and `Panel`, to unify methods\nand behaviors. Series formerly subclassed directly from `ndarray`.\n- Refactor of series.py/frame.py/panel.py to move common code to generic.py\n  - added `_setup_axes` to created generic NDFrame structures\n  - moved methods\n    - `from_axes,_wrap_array,axes,ix,shape,empty,swapaxes,transpose,pop`\n    - `__iter__,keys,__contains__,__len__,__neg__,__invert__`\n    - `convert_objects,as_blocks,as_matrix,values`\n    - `__getstate__,__setstate__` (though compat remains in frame/panel)\n    - `__getattr__,__setattr__`\n    - `_indexed_same,reindex_like,align,where,mask,replace`\n    - `filter` (also added axis argument to selectively filter on a different axis)\n    - `reindex,reindex_axis` (which was the biggest change to make generic)\n    - `truncate` (moved to become part of `NDFrame`)\n- These are API changes which make `Panel` more consistent with `DataFrame`\n  - swapaxes on a Panel with the same axes specified now return a copy\n  - support attribute access for setting\n  - filter supports same api as original `DataFrame` filter\n- Reindex called with no arguments will now return a copy of the input object\n- Series now inherits from `NDFrame` rather than directly from `ndarray`.\n  There are several minor changes that affect the API.\n  - numpy functions that do not support the array interface will now\n    return `ndarrays` rather than series, e.g. `np.diff` and `np.where`\n  - `Series(0.5)` would previously return the scalar `0.5`, this is no\n    longer supported\n  - several methods from frame/series have moved to `NDFrame`\n    (convert_objects,where,mask)\n  - `TimeSeries` is now an alias for `Series`. the property `is_time_series`\n    can be used to distinguish (if desired)\n- Refactor of Sparse objects to use BlockManager\n  - Created a new block type in internals, `SparseBlock`, which can hold multi-dtypes\n    and is non-consolidatable. `SparseSeries` and `SparseDataFrame` now inherit\n    more methods from there hierarchy (Series/DataFrame), and no longer inherit\n    from `SparseArray` (which instead is the object of the `SparseBlock`)\n  - Sparse suite now supports integration with non-sparse data. Non-float sparse\n    data is supportable (partially implemented)\n  - Operations on sparse structures within DataFrames should preserve sparseness,\n    merging type operations will convert to dense (and back to sparse), so might\n    be somewhat inefficient\n  - enable setitem on `SparseSeries` for boolean/integer/slices\n  - `SparsePanels` implementation is unchanged (e.g. not using BlockManager, needs work)\n- added `ftypes` method to Series/DataFame, similar to `dtypes`, but indicates\n  if the underlying is sparse/dense (as well as the dtype)\n- All `NDFrame` objects now have a `_prop_attributes`, which can be used to indcated various\n  values to propogate to a new object from an existing (e.g. name in `Series` will follow\n  more automatically now)\n\nPerf changed a bit primarily in groupby where a Series has to be reconstructed in order to be passed to the function (in some cases). I basically pass a Series-like class to the grouped function to see if it doesn't raise, if its ok, then it is used rather than a full Series in order to reduce overhead of the Series creation for each group.\n\n```\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nTest name                                    | head[ms] | base[ms] |  ratio {"A_title": "Easier sub-classing for Series and DataFrame", "A_clean_title": ["easier", "sub", "class", "seri", "datafram", "data", "frame"], "B_title": "CLN: series to now inherit from NDFrame", "B_clean_title": ["cln", "seri", "now", "inherit", "ndframe", "nd", "frame"], "A_body": "This is a relatively trival 'fix', which makes it easier to sub-class Pandas Series' and Dataframes. Basically, it makes more consistent use of `self._constructor` when constructing outputs from operations on Series' and DataFrames. For example, with these changes, this is now possible:\n\n``` python\nIn [1]: from pandas import Series\nIn [2]: class MySeries(Series):\n    def say_hello(self):\n        print \"hello!\"   \nIn [3]: s = MySeries([1,2,3,4,5])\nIn [4]: s.say_hello()\nhello!\nIn [5]: s.__class__\nOut[5]: __main__.MySeries\nIn [6]: s2 = s[1:3]\nIn [7]: s2.__class__\nOut[7]: __main__.MySeries\nIn [8]: s2.say_hello()\nhello!\n```\n\nThis addresses (to some extent) issues #1713 and #60 and the issues mentioned therein. After these changes, all nosetests continue to pass (except those that skip).\n\nNote: This is my first 'pull request', so be gentle!\n", "A_clean_body": ["thi", "rel", "trival", "'fix", "which", "make", "it", "easier", "sub", "class", "panda", "seri", "datafram", "basic", "it", "make", "more", "consist", "use", "self", "constructor", "when", "construct", "output", "oper", "seri", "datafram", "data", "frame", "exampl", "these", "chang", "thi", "now", "possibl", "python", "panda", "import", "seri", "class", "myseri", "my", "seri", "seri", "def", "say", "hello", "self", "print", "hello", "myseri", "my", "seri", "1,2,3,4,5", "say", "hello", "hello", "class", "out", "myseri", "main", "my", "seri", "s2", "1:3", "s2", "class", "out", "myseri", "main", "my", "seri", "s2", "say", "hello", "hello", "thi", "address", "some", "extent", "issu", "1713", "60", "issu", "mention", "therein", "after", "these", "chang", "all", "nosetest", "continu", "pass", "except", "those", "that", "skip", "note", "thi", "my", "first", "'pull", "request", "so", "gentl"], "B_body": "Major refactor primarily to make Series inherit from NDFrame\n\naffects #4080, #3862, #816, #3217, #3386, #4463, #4204, #4118 , #4555\n\nPreserves pickle compat\nvery few tests were changed (and only for compat on return objects)\na few performance enhancements, a couple of regressions (see bottom)\n\n_obviously this is a large change in terms of the codebase, but it brings more consistency between series/frame/panel (not all of this is there yet, but future changes are much easier)_\n\n_Series is now like Frame in that it has a BlockManager (called SingleBlockManager), which holds a block (of any type we support). This introduced some overhead in doing certain operations, which I spent a lot of time optimizing away, further optimizations will come from cythonizing the core/internals, which should be straightforward at this point_\n\nHighlites below:\n\nIn 0.13.0 there is a major refactor primarily to subclass `Series` from `NDFrame`,\nwhich is the base class currently for `DataFrame` and `Panel`, to unify methods\nand behaviors. Series formerly subclassed directly from `ndarray`.\n- Refactor of series.py/frame.py/panel.py to move common code to generic.py\n  - added `_setup_axes` to created generic NDFrame structures\n  - moved methods\n    - `from_axes,_wrap_array,axes,ix,shape,empty,swapaxes,transpose,pop`\n    - `__iter__,keys,__contains__,__len__,__neg__,__invert__`\n    - `convert_objects,as_blocks,as_matrix,values`\n    - `__getstate__,__setstate__` (though compat remains in frame/panel)\n    - `__getattr__,__setattr__`\n    - `_indexed_same,reindex_like,align,where,mask,replace`\n    - `filter` (also added axis argument to selectively filter on a different axis)\n    - `reindex,reindex_axis` (which was the biggest change to make generic)\n    - `truncate` (moved to become part of `NDFrame`)\n- These are API changes which make `Panel` more consistent with `DataFrame`\n  - swapaxes on a Panel with the same axes specified now return a copy\n  - support attribute access for setting\n  - filter supports same api as original `DataFrame` filter\n- Reindex called with no arguments will now return a copy of the input object\n- Series now inherits from `NDFrame` rather than directly from `ndarray`.\n  There are several minor changes that affect the API.\n  - numpy functions that do not support the array interface will now\n    return `ndarrays` rather than series, e.g. `np.diff` and `np.where`\n  - `Series(0.5)` would previously return the scalar `0.5`, this is no\n    longer supported\n  - several methods from frame/series have moved to `NDFrame`\n    (convert_objects,where,mask)\n  - `TimeSeries` is now an alias for `Series`. the property `is_time_series`\n    can be used to distinguish (if desired)\n- Refactor of Sparse objects to use BlockManager\n  - Created a new block type in internals, `SparseBlock`, which can hold multi-dtypes\n    and is non-consolidatable. `SparseSeries` and `SparseDataFrame` now inherit\n    more methods from there hierarchy (Series/DataFrame), and no longer inherit\n    from `SparseArray` (which instead is the object of the `SparseBlock`)\n  - Sparse suite now supports integration with non-sparse data. Non-float sparse\n    data is supportable (partially implemented)\n  - Operations on sparse structures within DataFrames should preserve sparseness,\n    merging type operations will convert to dense (and back to sparse), so might\n    be somewhat inefficient\n  - enable setitem on `SparseSeries` for boolean/integer/slices\n  - `SparsePanels` implementation is unchanged (e.g. not using BlockManager, needs work)\n- added `ftypes` method to Series/DataFame, similar to `dtypes`, but indicates\n  if the underlying is sparse/dense (as well as the dtype)\n- All `NDFrame` objects now have a `_prop_attributes`, which can be used to indcated various\n  values to propogate to a new object from an existing (e.g. name in `Series` will follow\n  more automatically now)\n\nPerf changed a bit primarily in groupby where a Series has to be reconstructed in order to be passed to the function (in some cases). I basically pass a Series-like class to the grouped function to see if it doesn't raise, if its ok, then it is used rather than a full Series in order to reduce overhead of the Series creation for each group.\n\n```\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nTest name                                    | head[ms] | base[ms] |  ratio   |\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------\ngroupby_multi_python                         | 109.3636 |  78.3370 |   1.3961 |\nframe_iteritems                              |   3.4664 |   2.0154 |   1.7200 |\nframe_fancy_lookup                           |   3.3991 |   1.6137 |   2.1064 |\nsparse_frame_constructor                     |  11.7100 |   5.3363 |   2.1944 |\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nTest name                                    | head[ms] | base[ms] |  ratio   |\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nTarget [c5d9495] : BUG: fix ujson handling of new series object\nBase   [1b91f4f] : BUG: Fixed non-unique indexing memory allocation issue with .ix/.loc (GH4280)\n```\n", "B_clean_body": ["major", "refactor", "primarili", "make", "seri", "inherit", "ndframe", "nd", "frame", "affect", "4080", "3862", "816", "3217", "3386", "4463", "4204", "4118", "4555", "preserv", "pickl", "compat", "veri", "few", "test", "were", "chang", "onli", "compat", "return", "object", "few", "perform", "enhanc", "coupl", "regress", Prior to 0.10.2, numeric dtypes passed to DataFrames were always casted to `int64` or `float64`. Now, if a dtype is passed (either directly via the `dtype` keyword, a passed `ndarray`, or a passed `Series`, then it will be preserved in DataFrame operations. Furthermore, different numeric dtypes will **NOT** be combined. The following example will give you a taste. This closes GH #622\n\nother changes introduced in this PR (i removed all datetime like issues to PR # 2752 - should be merged first)\n\nENH:\n- validated get_numeric_data returns correct dtypes\n- added `blocks` attribute (and as_blocks()) method that returns a \n  dict of dtype -> homogeneous dtyped DataFrame, analagous to `values` attribute\n- added keyword 'raise_on_error' to astype, which can be set to false to exluded non-numeric columns\n- changed `get_dtype_counts()` to use `blocks` attribute\n- changed `convert_objects()` to use the internals method convert (which is block operated)\n  - added option to `convert_numeric=False` to `convert_objects` to force numeric conversion (or set to `np.nan`, turned off by default)\n  - added option to `convert_dates='coerce'` to `convert_objects` to force datetimelike conversions (or set to `NaT`) for invalid values, turned off by default, returns datetime64[ns] dtype\n- groupby operations to respect dtype inputs wherever possible, even if intermediate casting is required (obviously if the input are ints and nans are resulting, this is casted),\n  all cython functions are implemented\n- auto generation of most groupby functions by type is now in `generated_code.py`\n  e.g. (group_add,group_mean)\n- added full `float32/int16/int8` support for all numeric operations, including (`diff, backfill, pad, take`)\n- added `dtype` display to show on Series as a default\n\nBUG:\n- fixed up tests from from_records to use record arrays directly\n  NOTE: using tuples will remove dtype info from the input stream (using a record array is ok though!)\n- fixed merging to correctly merge on multiple dtypes with blocks (e.g. float64 and float32 in other merger)\n- (#2623 can be fixed, but is dependent on #2752)\n- fixed #2778, bug in pad/backfill with 0-len frame\n- fixed very obscure bug in DataFrame.from_records with dictionary and columns passed and hash randomization is on!\n- integer upcasts will now happend on `where` when using inplace ops (#2793)\n\nTST:\n- tests added for merging changes, astype, convert\n- fixes for test_excel on 32-bit\n- fixed test_resample_median_bug_1688\n- separated out test_from_records_dictlike\n- added tests for (GH #797)\n- added lots of tests for`where`\n\nDOC:\n- added DataTypes section in Data Structres intro\n- whatsnew examples\n\n_It would be really helpful if some users could give this a test run before merging. I have put in test cases for numeric operations, combining with DataFrame and Series, but I am sure there are some corner cases that were missed_\n\n```\nIn [17]: df1 = DataFrame(randn(8, 1), columns = ['A'], dtype = 'float32')\n\nIn [18]: df1\nOut[18]: \n          A\n0 -0.007220\n1 -0.236432\n2  2.427172\n3 -0.998639\n4 -1.039410\n5  0.336029\n6  0.832988\n7 -0.413241\n\nIn [19]: df1.dtypes\nOut[19]: A    float32\n\nIn [20]: df2 = DataFrame(dict( A = Series(randn(8),dtype='float16'), \n                                                B = Series(randn(8)), \n                                                C = Series(randn(8),dtype='uint8') ))\n\nIn [22]: df2\nOut[22]: \n          A         B    C\n0  1.150391 -1.033296    0\n1  0.123047  1.915564    0\n2  0.151367 -0.489826    0\n3 -0.565430 -0.734238    0\n4 -0.352295 -0.451430    0\n5 -0.618164  0.673102  255\n6  1.554688  0.322035    0\n7  0.160767  0.420718    0\n\n\nIn [23]: df2.dtypes\nOut[23]: \nA    float16\nB    float64\nC      uint8\n\nIn [24]: # here you get some upcasting\n\nIn [25]: df3 = df1.reindex_like(df2).fillna(value=0.0) + df2\n\nIn [26]: df3\nOut[26]: \n          A         B    C\n0  1.143170 -1.033296    0\n1 -0.113385  1.915564    0\n2  2.578539 -0.489826    0\n3 -1.564069 -0.734238    0\n4 -1.391705 -0.451430    0\n5 -0.282135  0.673102  255\n6  2.387676  0.322035    0\n7 -0.252475  0.420718    0\n\nIn [27]: df3.dtypes\nOut[27]: \nA    float32\nB    float64\nC    float64\n```\n\nthe example from #622\n\n```\nIn [23]: a = np.array(np.random.randint(10, size=1e6),dtype='int32')\n\nIn [24]: b = np.array(np.random.randint(10, size=1e6),dtype='int64')\n\nIn [25]: df = pandas.DataFrame(dict(a = a, b = b))\n\nIn [26]: df.dtypes\nOut[26]: \na    int32\nb    int64\n```\n\nConversion examples\n\n```\n# conversion of dtypes\nIn [81]: df3.astype('float32').dtypes\nOut[81]: \nA    float32\nB    float32\nC    float32\n\n# mixed type conversions\nIn [82]: df3['D'] = '1.'\n\nIn [83]: df3['E'] = '1'\n\nIn [84]: df3.convert_objects(convert_numeric=True).dtypes\nOut[84]: \nA    float32\nB    float64\nC    float64\nD    float64\nE      int64\n\n# same, but specific dtype conversion\nIn [85]: df3['D'] = df3['D'].astype('float16')\n\nIn [86]: df3['E'] = df3['E'].astype('int32')\n\nIn [87]: df3.dtypes\nOut[87]: \nA    float32\nB    float64\nC    float64\nD    float16\nE      int32\n\n# forcing date coercion\nIn [18]: s = Series([datetime(2001,1,1,0,0), 'foo', 1.0, 1,\n   ....:             Timestamp('20010104'), '20010105'],dtype='O')\n   ....:\n\nIn "isnul", "nuniqu", "instead", "valu", "count"], "B_title": "BUG: isnull doesnt handle PeriodNaT properly", "B_clean_title": ["bug", "isnul", "doesnt", "handl", "periodnat", "period", "na", "properli"], "A_body": "closes #9129\n\nCurrently, `Series.nunique` [(source)](https://github.com/pydata/pandas/blob/master/pandas/core/base.py#L429) calls `Series.value_counts` [(source)](https://github.com/pydata/pandas/blob/master/pandas/core/base.py#L371), which by default, sorts the values. \n\nCounting unique values certainly doesn't require sorting, so we could fix this\nby passing `sort=False` to `value_counts`.\n\nBut `nunique` can also be calculated by calling `Series.unique` instead of\n`value_counts`, and using `com.isnull` to handle the `dropna` parameter.\n\nThis PR attempts to implement this. Here is a vbench perf test which seems to show an improvement for tests using `nunique`.\n\n```\n/usr/bin/time -v ./test_perf.sh -b master -t nunique-unique -r groupby\n```\n\nHere are the best and worst ratios:\n\n```\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nTest name                                    | head[ms] | base[ms] |  ratio 0.5748 |\ngroupby_ngroups_10000_max                    |   2.5337 |   4.1683 |   0.6078 |\ngroupby_frame_nth_none                       |   2.3570 |   3.2880 |   0.7168 |\ngroupby_ngroups_10000_var |\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nTest name                                    | head[ms] | base[ms] |  ratio "title_sim": [0.031208852996179946], "body_sim": [0.01712929918369115], "file_list_sim": 0.3333333333333333, "overlap_files_len": 2, "code_sim": [0.5745553359088886, 0.5811218235776487], "location_sim": [0.28313253012048195, 0.4392523364485981], "pattern": -1, "time": 181}, {"A_title": "CLN: series to now inherit from NDFrame", "A_clean_title": ["cln", "seri", "now", "inherit", "ndframe", "nd", "frame"], "B_title": "ENH: Series item access via attribute #1903", "B_clean_title": ["enh", "seri", "item", "access", "via", "attribut", "1903"], "A_body": "Major refactor primarily to make Series inherit from NDFrame\n\naffects #4080, #3862, #816, #3217, #3386, #4463, #4204, #4118 , #4555\n\nPreserves pickle compat\nvery few tests were changed (and only for compat on return objects)\na few performance enhancements, a couple of regressions (see bottom)\n\n_obviously this is a large change in terms of the codebase, but it brings more consistency between series/frame/panel (not all of this is there yet, but future changes are much easier)_\n\n_Series is now like Frame in that it has a BlockManager (called SingleBlockManager), which holds a block (of any type we support). This introduced some overhead in doing certain operations, which I spent a lot of time optimizing away, further optimizations will come from cythonizing the core/internals, which should be straightforward at this point_\n\nHighlites below:\n\nIn 0.13.0 there is a major refactor primarily to subclass `Series` from `NDFrame`,\nwhich is the base class currently for `DataFrame` and `Panel`, to unify methods\nand behaviors. Series formerly subclassed directly from `ndarray`.\n- Refactor of series.py/frame.py/panel.py to move common code to generic.py\n  - added `_setup_axes` to created generic NDFrame structures\n  - moved methods\n    - `from_axes,_wrap_array,axes,ix,shape,empty,swapaxes,transpose,pop`\n    - `__iter__,keys,__contains__,__len__,__neg__,__invert__`\n    - `convert_objects,as_blocks,as_matrix,values`\n    - `__getstate__,__setstate__` (though compat remains in frame/panel)\n    - `__getattr__,__setattr__`\n    - `_indexed_same,reindex_like,align,where,mask,replace`\n    - `filter` (also added axis argument to selectively filter on a different axis)\n    - `reindex,reindex_axis` (which was the biggest change to make generic)\n    - `truncate` (moved to become part of `NDFrame`)\n- These are API changes which make `Panel` more consistent with `DataFrame`\n  - swapaxes on a Panel with the same axes specified now return a copy\n  - support attribute access for setting\n  - filter supports same api as original `DataFrame` filter\n- Reindex called with no arguments will now return a copy of the input object\n- Series now inherits from `NDFrame` rather than directly from `ndarray`.\n  There are several minor changes that affect the API.\n  - numpy functions that do not support the array interface will now\n    return `ndarrays` rather than series, e.g. `np.diff` and `np.where`\n  - `Series(0.5)` would previously return the scalar `0.5`, this is no\n    longer supported\n  - several methods from frame/series have moved to `NDFrame`\n    (convert_objects,where,mask)\n  - `TimeSeries` is now an alias for `Series`. the property `is_time_series`\n    can be used to distinguish (if desired)\n- Refactor of Sparse objects to use BlockManager\n  - Created a new block type in internals, `SparseBlock`, which can hold multi-dtypes\n    and is non-consolidatable. `SparseSeries` and `SparseDataFrame` now inherit\n    more methods from there hierarchy (Series/DataFrame), and no longer inherit\n    from `SparseArray` (which instead is the object of the `SparseBlock`)\n  - Sparse suite now supports integration with non-sparse data. Non-float sparse\n    data is supportable (partially implemented)\n  - Operations on sparse structures within DataFrames should preserve sparseness,\n    merging type operations will convert to dense (and back to sparse), so might\n    be somewhat inefficient\n  - enable setitem on `SparseSeries` for boolean/integer/slices\n  - `SparsePanels` implementation is unchanged (e.g. not using BlockManager, needs work)\n- added `ftypes` method to Series/DataFame, similar to `dtypes`, but indicates\n  if the underlying is sparse/dense (as well as the dtype)\n- All `NDFrame` objects now have a `_prop_attributes`, which can be used to indcated various\n  values to propogate to a new object from an existing (e.g. name in `Series` will follow\n  more automatically now)\n\nPerf changed a bit primarily in groupby where a Series has to be reconstructed in order to be passed to the function (in some cases). I basically pass a Series-like class to the grouped function to see if it doesn't raise, if its ok, then it is used rather than a full Series in order to reduce overhead of the Series creation for each group.\n\n```\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nTest name                                    | head[ms] | base[ms] |  ratio   |\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------\ngroupby_multi_python                         | 109.3636 |  78.3370 |   1.3961 |\nframe_iteritems                              |   3.4664 |   2.0154 |   1.7200 |\nframe_fancy_lookup                           |   3.3991 |   1.6137 |   2.1064 |\nsparse_frame_constructor                     |  11.7100 |   5.3363 |   2.1944 |\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nTest name                                    | head[ms] | base[ms] |  ratio In addition it simplifies the internal processing of intraday periods.\n\n``` python\nIn []: pd.date_range('2013-01-01', periods=5, freq=pd.offsets.Nano(5))\nOut[]: \n<class 'pandas.tseries.index.DatetimeIndex'>\n[2013-01-01 00:00:00, ..., 2013-01-01 00:00:00.000000020]\nLength: 5, Freq: 5N, Timezone: None\n```\n\nIt requires Numpy 1.7 to work, using Numpy 1.6 yields the original behaviour before this PR.\n\nThis is the continuation of #2555 after it was merged without effect fixing issue #1812.\n\nThe biggest part is a refactoring of pandas/src/period.c to use a conversion factor matrix for intraday conversion. This minimizes the impact of adding three more intraday time units (ms, us and ns). Thus the amount of frequency conversion methods is reduced to one per intraday frequency source or target. The intraday conversion factor is looked up in the conversion factor matrix inside the method.\n\nNanosecond support is only available when using numpy >= 1.7. When using with numpy < 1.7 everything except nanosecond support should work as expected.\n", "A_clean_body": ["close", "1812", "thi", "pull", "request", "fix", "handl", "nanosecond", "time", "period", "offset", "addit", "it", "simplifi", "intern", "process", "intraday", "period", "python", "pd", "date", "rang", "'2013", "01", "01", "periods=5", "freq=pd", "offset", "nano", "out", "class", "'panda", "tseri", "index", "datetimeindex", "datetim", "index", "2013", "01", "01", "00:00:00", "2013", "01", "01", "00:00:00", "000000020", "length", "freq", "5n", "timezon", "none", "it", "requir", "numpi", "work", "numpi", "yield", "origin", "behaviour", "befor", "thi", "pr", "thi", "continu", "2555", "after", "it", "wa", "merg", "without", "effect", "fix", "issu", "1812", "biggest", "part", "refactor", "panda", "src", "period", "use", "convers", "factor", "matrix", "intraday", "convers", "thi", "minim", "impact", "ad", "three", "more", "intraday", "time", "unit", "ms", "us", "ns", "thu", "amount", "frequenc", "convers", "method", "reduc", "one", "per", "intraday", "frequenc", "sourc", "or", "target", "intraday", "convers", "factor", "look", "up", "convers", "factor", "matrix", "insid", "method", "nanosecond", "support", "onli", "avail", "when", "numpi", "when", "numpi", "everyth", "except", "nanosecond", "support", "work", "as", "expect"], "B_body": "(Continues #2145)\n\nAlrighty. "merg", "21881", "22048", "22151", "22161", "22162", "22164", "22167", "fail", "merg"], "B_body": "This is a resurrection and heavy revision/expansion of a PR that pcwalton did to resolve #8861.\n\nThe most relevant, user-visible semantic change is this:  if a type expression for some value has a destructor, then any lifetimes referenced within that type expression must _strictly outlive_ the scope of the value.\n\nSee discussion on https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/769, especially for the discussion of the meaning of \"strictly outlive.\"\n\n---\n\nA previous version of this pull request also removed the `#[unsafe_destructor]` attribute, as well as the analysis that would reject generic `Drop` impls that were not annotated with that attribute. An example `./configure`\ninvocation is:\n\n```\n./configure \\\n    --enable-rustbuild\n    --target=arm-unknown-linux-musleabi \\\n    --musl-root=\"$MUSL_ROOT\"\n```\n\nwhere `MUSL_ROOT` points to the `arm-linux-musleabi` prefix.\nUsually that path will be of the form\n`/foobar/arm-linux-musleabi/arm-linux-musleabi`.\n\nUsually the cross-compile toolchain will live under\n`/foobar/arm-linux-musleabi/bin`. That path should either by added\nto your `PATH` variable, or you should add a section to your\n`config.toml` as follows:\n\n```\n[target.arm-unknown-linux-musleabi]\ncc = \"/foobar/arm-linux-musleabi/bin/arm-linux-musleabi-gcc\"\ncxx = \"/foobar/arm-linux-musleabi/bin/arm-linux-musleabi-g++\"\n```\n\nAs a prerequisite you'll also have to put a cross-compiled static\n`libunwind.a` library in `$MUSL_ROOT/lib`. When enabled mathjax can be used by wrapping math in double-dollars like so: `$$ \\sqrt{x} + \\log^2n $$`. If the dollars are part of a larger block element, the content will be rendered inline. If they surround an _entire_ block, the math will be rendered in \"display mode\" as seen in my example pages. Note: the opening  `$$`'s must be lead by whitespace, and the closing `$$`'s must be followed by whitespace. Therefore `blah blah $$x^2$$.` will not render as math, because there is no whitespace between the last `$` and the `.`. \n\nCloses #16300\nTrivializes #15285\n", "B_clean_body": ["'m", "not", This type is excellent for building your own data structures like Vec and VecDeque.\nIn particular:\n- Produces heap::EMPTY on zero-sized types\n- Produces heap::EMPTY on zero-length allocations\n- Catches all overflows in capacity computations (promotes them to \"capacity overflow\" panics)\n- Guards against 32-bit systems allocating more than isize::MAX bytes\n- Guards against overflowing your length\n- Aborts on OOM\n- Avoids freeing heap::EMPTY\n- Contains a ptr::Unique and thus endows the user with all related benefits\n\nThis type does not in anyway inspect the memory that it manages. When dropped it _will_\nfree its memory, but it _won't_ try to Drop its contents. It is up to the user of RawVec\nto handle the actual things _stored_ inside of a RawVec.\n\nNote that a RawVec always forces its capacity to be usize::MAX for zero-sized types.\nThis enables you to use capacity growing logic catch the overflows in your length\nthat might occur with zero-sized types.\n\nHowever this means that you need to be careful when roundtripping this type\nwith a `Box<[T]>`: `cap()` won't yield the len. However `with_capacity`,\n`shrink_to_fit`, and `from_box` will actually set RawVec's private capacity\nfield. This allows zero-sized types to not be special-cased by consumers of\nthis type.\n\nEdit: \nfixes #18726 and fixes #23842\n", "B_clean_body": ["per", "top", "level", "comment", "low", "level", "util", Bootstrapping\nfrom a previously stable release is a long-desired feature of distros because\nthey're not fans of downloading binary stage0 blobs from us. Additionally, this\nmakes our own CI easier as we can decommission all of the snapshot builders and\nstart having a regular cadence to when we update the stage0 compiler.\n\nA new `src/etc/get-stage0.py` script was added which shares some code with\n`src/bootstrap/bootstrap.py` to read a new file, `src/stage0.txt`, which lists\nthe current stage0 compiler as well as cargo that we bootstrap from. This script\nwill download the relevant `rustc` package an unpack it into `$target/stage0` as\nwe do today.\n\nOne problem of bootstrapping from stable releases is that we're not able to\ncompile unstable code (e.g. all the `#![feature]` directives in libcore/libstd).\nTo overcome this we employ two strategies:\n- The bootstrap key of the previous compiler is hardcoded into `src/stage0.txt`\n  (enabled as a result of #32731) and exported by the build system. This enables\n  nightly features in the compiler we download.\n- The standard library and compiler are pinned to a specific stage0, which\n  doesn't change, so we're guaranteed that we'll continue compiling as we start\n  from a known fixed source.\n\nThe process for making a release will also need to be tweaked now to continue to\ncadence of bootstrapping from the previous release. This process looks like:\n1. Merge `beta` to `stable`\n2. Produce a new stable compiler.\n3. Change `master` to bootstrap from this new stable compiler.\n4. Merge `master` to `beta`\n5. Produce a new beta compiler\n6. Change `master` to bootstrap from this new beta compiler.\n\nStep 3 above should involve very few changes as `master` was previously\nbootstrapping from `beta` which is the same as `stable` at that point in time.\nStep 6, however, is where we benefit from removing lots of `#[cfg(stage0)]` and\nget to use new features. This also shouldn't slow the release too much as steps\n1-5 requires little work other than waiting and step 6 just needs to happen at\nsome point during a release cycle, it's not time sensitive.\n\nCloses #29555\nCloses #29557\n", "A_clean_body": ["thi", "commit", "remov", "all", "infrastructur", "repositori", "our", "so", "call", "snapshot", "instead", "bootstrap", "compil", #22563 as `impl`s are no longer treated as modules in resolve.\n\nUnfortunately, this is still a _[breaking-change]_:\n- If you used a global path to a primitive type, i.e. `::bool`, `::i32` etc. - that was a bug I had to fix.\n  Solution: remove the leading `::`.\n- If you passed explicit `impl`-side type parameters to an inherent method, e.g.:\n\n``` rust\nstruct Foo<T>(T);\nimpl<A, B> Foo<(A, B)> {\n    fn pair(a: A, b: B) -> Foo<(A, B)> { Foo((a, b)) }\n}\nFoo::<A, B>::pair(a, b)\n// Now that is sugar for:\n<Foo<A, B>>::pair(a, b)\n// Which isn't valid because `Foo` has only one type parameter.\n// Solution: replace with:\nFoo::<(A, B)>::pair(a, b)\n// And, if possible, remove the explicit type param entirely:\nFoo::pair(a, b)\n```\n- If you used the `QPath`-related `AstBuilder` Colour brewing is done manually so the only additional import required is `numpy`, and output is still pure dot format. \n\nEnhancements include:\n- Drawing leaf nodes at the base of the tree for clarity\n- Colours indicating how the node classification is 'leaning', including multi-class\n- Percentage samples shown in node instead of raw number of samples\n- Percentage per class shown for all nodes, not just leaves\n\nStandard output, omitting the new `pretty` and `simple` flags, should result in the exact same graphical output from Graphviz as the incumbent version, though the dot code has been altered slightly for simplicity given the new more complicated node representation for `pretty`.\n\nA few examples using the Titanic survivor dataset:\n\nno flags:\n\n![full_new](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5210848/4514716/0a8c122a-4b88-11e4-92dd-78f78bbfcee9.png)\n\n`pretty`:\n\n![full_pretty](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5210848/4514717/154df71e-4b88-11e4-9d09-b763ebe63763.png)\n\n`pretty` & `simple`:\n\n![full_pretty_simple](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5210848/4514718/20512c9e-4b88-11e4-88f7-6eb78fabec4d.png)\n\n`pretty` & `max_depth`:\n\n![cropped_pretty](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5210848/4514721/3957a330-4b88-11e4-9544-78f68cab3da5.png)\n\nIt has been moderately tested on pure `tree.DecisionTreeClassifier` objects, though I am well aware that regression needs work and will fail if attempted with the new flags (though the standard output still appears to be functional).\n\nTo be discussed:\n- How to represent colours for regression... I'm thinking a diverging colour scheme with white for the median or mean of the two most extreme values in the leaves should work well.\n- Should the text and graphical options be broken out further? Something like `show_major_class`, `use_colours`, `use_percentages`, etc., or some perhaps discarded. I based the options off the R package, that's not meant to imply that this is the state of the art, just the best I've stumbled across.\n- Should the base implementation even be maintained? The extra sub-tree recursion per node is a little expensive, but it's just a single tree... And seeing what each node is voting towards gives more intuitive information than the error coefficients alone. It even appears that this used to be standard output from the examples [here](http://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/tree.html#tree)\n\nOther options that might be useful:\n- Left to right orientation for use in reports?\n- Anything else you can think of? Explain your changes.\n\nWhen running a 'diag' GMM on a high-dimensional feature space, a Memory Error was thrown. This is suspicious because quadratic memory should not be used for diagonal GMM fitting. Indeed, there was a section of gmm.py that had a needless covariance matrix calculation for the 'diag' and 'spherical' cases.\n\nThe modified code fixes that; behavior should be the same for 'diag'.\n\nFor 'spherical', the previous code initialized the variance term to the average value of all terms in the covariance matrix. ["mrg", "fix", "kneighborsregressor", "neighbor", "regressor", "radiusneighborsregressor", "radiu", "neighbor", "regressor", "return", "nan", "na", "predi"], "B_title": "BUG: avoid infinite weights in kNN regression", "B_clean_title": ["bug", "avoid", "infinit", "weight", "knn", "nn", "regress"], "A_body": "A  `KNeighborsRegressor` with distance weighting will predict `NaN` if the data to predict on happens to match a data point from the training set.  (This actually happened to me with some data from a Kaggle competition)\n\nFor example,\n\n```\nfrom sklearn import neighbors\nimport numpy as np\n\nX = np.array([[1.0],[2.0],[3.0]])\ny = np.array([1.0, 2.0, 3.0])\n\nclf = neighbors.KNeighborsRegressor(n_neighbors=3, weights='distance')\n\nclf.fit(X,y)\nprint(clf.predict([[1.0]]))\n```\n\nThe output is `NaN`.  This seems like undesirable behavior.  I would have expected `pred` to be `1.0`.  In addition, `RadiusNeighborsRegressor` suffers from this problem.  \n\nNote that the infinities are already handled properly by `KNeighborsClassifier` and `RadiusNeighborsClassifiers`.  For example,\n\n```\nfrom sklearn import neighbors\nimport numpy as np\n\nX = np.array([[1.0],[2.0],[3.0]])\ny = np.array([1, 0, 1])\n\nclf = neighbors.KNeighborsClassifier(n_neighbors=3, weights='distance')\n\nclf.fit(X,y)\nprint(clf.predict([[1.0]]))\n```\n\nThis outputs `1` as expected.\n\nThis pull request is my proposed solution.  Note that if there are two points with distance=0, it chooses one of them, which is consistent with the warning given in the [KNeighborsRegressor docs](http://scikit-learn.org/dev/modules/generated/sklearn.neighbors.KNeighborsRegressor.html).\n\nThis is my first pull request for any project, so let me know if I'm doing something wrong!\n", "contribut"], "B_body": "I raised this issue a while back on the [mailing list](http://sourceforge.net/p/scikit-learn/mailman/message/34450663/).\nWhen using `GridSearchCV` on a `MetaEstimator` wrapping an `SVC` (_not_ `LinearSVC`) with a `precomputed=True` the Gram matrix does not get sliced correctly.\nFor me this was occurring because the default One-vs-One strategy for the SVC is not ["rfc", "gsoc2015", "so", "c2015", "improv", "gmm", "api"], "B_title": "FIX : pass random_state to kmeans in gmm.fit", "B_clean_title": ["fix", "pass", "random", "state", "kmean", "gmm", "fit"], "A_body": "GSoC 2015 project,  Improve GMM API\n1. [x] Completes [derivation report](https://www.dropbox.com/s/8hlbb7dlwllwcry/VBGMM.pdf?dl=0).\n2. [x] Adds new classes. One abstract class `_BasesMixture`. Three derived classes `GaussianMixture`, `BayesianGaussianMixture`, `DirichletProcessGaussianMixture`\n3. [x] Decouples large functions, especially in `DirichletProcessGaussianMixture` and `BayesianGaussianMixture`\n4. [x] Removes numerical stability fixes for HMM. It seems that whenever there is a numerical issue, the code always adds 10_EPS in the computation. I think in some cases there is a better way to address the problem, such as normalization the extremely small variables earlier, or we just simply remove ```10_EPS``` which is only for HMM.\n5. [x] Writes updating functions for `BayesianGaussianMixtureModel` and `DirichletProcessGaussianMixtureModel` according to the report.\n6. [x] Provides methods that allow users to initialize the model with user-provided data\n7. [x] Corrects kmeans initialization. It is weird when using kmeans initialization, only means is initialized. The weights and covariances are initialized by averaging.\n8. [x] Writes several checking functions for the initialization data\n9. [x] Adjusts the verbose messages. When `verbose>1`, it display log-likelihood and time used in the same line of the message `Iteration x`\n10. [x] Remove `fit_predict`\n11. [x] Adds warning for `params!='wmc'`\n12. [ ] Studies and contrasts the convergence of classical MLE / EM GMM with Bayesian GMM against the number of samples and the number of components\n13. [x] Friendly warning and error messages, or automatically addressing if possible (e.g. random re-init of singular components)\n14. [ ] Examples that shows how models can over-fit by comparing likelihood on training and validation sets (normalized by\n    the number of samples). In many instances of the variable `scale` setting was ignored.  Data was always centered, and always scaled.  The data is now scaled appropriately when `scale=True` is set, and not scaled when it's `False`\n2. The return from the `predict()` function was always de-centered, but never de-scaled, so that we got:\n   `Ypred = Ypred + self.y_mean_`  for all cases\n   instead of:\n   `Ypred = (Ypred * self.y_std_) + self.y_mean_` when `scale=True`\n3. In the nipals algorithm, either C and Q matrices are used for deflation modes (regression or canonical).  This is now implemented.  The #FIXME note is now not necessary, as `coef_` is calculated differently depending on those two cases.  The calculated `coef_` was also scaled unnecesarily by standard deviations of X and Y: this is now commented out.  Only matrices W and C are scaled by their norms in the inner loop.  The outer loop scales P, Q, and C (canonical and regression) matrices by `T.T*T` or `U.T*U`\n4. Some documentation was changed to reflect code modifications.  Also, instructions to use `sklearn.preprocessing.scale` are included, as that could be a useful step for most users.\n5. "[MRG+1] Add multiplicative-update solver in NMF, with all beta-divergence", "A_clean_title": ["mrg+1", "add", "multipl", "updat", "solver", "nmf", "all", "beta", "diverg"], "B_title": "NMF for Kullback-Leibler divergence", "B_clean_title": ["nmf", "kullback", "leibler", "diverg"], "A_body": "This PR is a second part of what have been discussed in #4811. (first part, #4852, merged)\nIt includes :\n- a Multiplicative-Update solver in NMF. This solver is generally slower than the Coordinate-Descent solver, but it handles all beta-divergences (including Frobenius, generalized Kullback_Leibler and Itakura-Saito). \n- a plot to visualize the beta-divergence for several values of beta.\n- benchmarks [below](https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/5295#issuecomment-174002806)\n\n[Link to the rendered "34", "align=", "absmiddl", "alt=", "review", "http", "learn", "scikit", "learn", "5295", "review", "io", "review", "scikit", "review", "end"], "B_body": "Adds the KLdivNMF class to decomposion.\nThe implemented method uses multiplicative updates. It is optimized to work with sparse matrices with lots of features.\n\n```\n\"\"\"Non negative factorization with Kullback Leibler divergence cost.\n\nParameters\n----------\nX: {array-like, sparse matrix}, shape = [n_samples, n_features]\n    Data the model will be fit to.\n\nn_components: int or None\n    Number of components, if n_components is not set all components\n    are kept\n\ninit:  'nndsvd' |  'nndsvda' | 'nndsvdar' | 'random'\n    Method used to initialize the procedure.\n    Default: 'nndsvdar' if n_components < n_features, otherwise random.\n    Valid options::\n\n        'nndsvd': Nonnegative Double Singular Value Decomposition (NNDSVD)\n            initialization (better for sparseness)\n        'nndsvda': NNDSVD with zeros filled with the average of X\n            (better when sparsity is not desired)\n        'nndsvdar': NNDSVD with zeros filled with small random values\n            (generally faster, less accurate alternative to NNDSVDa\n            for when sparsity is not desired)\n        'random': non-negative random matrices\n\ntol: double, default: 1e-4\n    Tolerance value used in stopping conditions.\n\nmax_iter: int, default: 200\n    Number of iterations to compute.\n\nsubit: int, default: 10\n    Number of sub-iterations to perform on W (resp. H) before switching\n    to H (resp. W) update.\n\nAttributes\n----------\n`components_` : array, [n_components, n_features]\n    Non-negative components of the data\n\nrandom_state : int or RandomState\n    Random number generator seed control.\n\nExamples\n--------\n\n>>> import numpy as np\n>>> X = np.array([[1,1], [2, 1], [3, 1.2], [4, 1], [5, 0.8], [6, 1]])\n>>> from sklearn.decomposition import KLdivNMF\n>>> model = KLdivNMF(n_components=2, init='random', random_state=0)\n>>> model.fit(X) #doctest: +ELLIPSIS +NORMALIZE_WHITESPACE\nKLdivNMF(eps=1e-08, init='random', max_iter=200, n_components=2,\n        random_state=0, subit=10, tol=1e-06)\n>>> model.components_\narray([[ 0.50303234,  0.49696766],\n       [ 0.93326505,  0.06673495]])\n\nNotes\n-----\nThis implements\n\nLee D. D., Seung H. S., Learning the parts of objects by non-negative\n  matrix factorization. Nature, 1999\n\"\"\"\n```\n", "B_clean_body": ["add", "kldivnmf", "ldiv", "nmf", "class", "decompos", "implement", "method", "use", "multipl", "updat", "it", "optim", "work", "spars", "matric", "lot", tree.export_graphviz()", "A_clean_title": ["mrg", "pretti", "decis", "tree", "tree", "export", "graphviz"], "B_title": "[bug]Fixed bugs when rendering dot file into graphics which is introduced by tree.export_graphviz", "B_clean_title": ["bug", "fix", "bug", "when", "render", "dot", "file", "into", "graphic", "which", "introduc", "by", "tree", "export", "graphviz"], "A_body": "As mentioned in #3643 this enhancement is intended to make the output of tree.export_graphviz more aesthetically pleasing as inspired by [fancyRpartPlot](http://blog.revolutionanalytics.com/2013/06/plotting-classification-and-regression-trees-with-plotrpart.html) in R. Colour brewing is done manually so the only additional import required is `numpy`, and output is still pure dot format. \n\nEnhancements include:\n- Drawing leaf nodes at the base of the tree for clarity\n- Colours indicating how the node classification is 'leaning', including multi-class\n- Percentage samples shown in node instead of raw number of samples\n- Percentage per class shown for all nodes, not just leaves\n\nStandard output, omitting the new `pretty` and `simple` flags, should result in the exact same graphical output from Graphviz as the incumbent version, though the dot code has been altered slightly for simplicity given the new more complicated node representation for `pretty`.\n\nA few examples using the Titanic survivor dataset:\n\nno flags:\n\n![full_new](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5210848/4514716/0a8c122a-4b88-11e4-92dd-78f78bbfcee9.png)\n\n`pretty`:\n\n![full_pretty](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5210848/4514717/154df71e-4b88-11e4-9d09-b763ebe63763.png)\n\n`pretty` & `simple`:\n\n![full_pretty_simple](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5210848/4514718/20512c9e-4b88-11e4-88f7-6eb78fabec4d.png)\n\n`pretty` & `max_depth`:\n\n![cropped_pretty](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5210848/4514721/3957a330-4b88-11e4-9544-78f68cab3da5.png)\n\nIt has been moderately tested on pure `tree.DecisionTreeClassifier` objects, though I am well aware that regression needs work and will fail if attempted with the new flags (though the standard output still appears to be functional).\n\nTo be discussed:\n- How to represent colours for regression... I'm thinking a diverging colour scheme with white for the median or mean of the two most extreme values in the leaves should work well.\n- Should the text and graphical options be broken out further? Something like `show_major_class`, `use_colours`, `use_percentages`, etc., or some perhaps discarded. I based the options off the R package, that's not meant to imply that this is the state of the art, just the best I've stumbled across.\n- Should the base implementation even be maintained? The extra sub-tree recursion per node is a little expensive, but it's just a single tree... And seeing what each node is voting towards gives more intuitive information than the error coefficients alone. It even appears that this used to be standard output from the examples [here](http://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/tree.html#tree)\n\nOther options that might be useful:\n- Left to right orientation for use in reports?\n- Anything else you can think of? "other", "option", "that", "might", "use", "left", "right", "orient", "use", "report", "anyth", "you", "think", "though", "graphviz", "littl", "limit", "what", "you", "pull", "off", "welcom", "ani", "other", "suggest", "gotcha"], "B_body": "When exporting a tree into a dot file using `tree.export_graphviz`,  the dot file is usually like this \n\n```\n    digraph Tree {\n        0 [label=\"A <= 1.5000\\nerror = 0.451898202175\\nsamples = 19396\\nvalue = [  6690.  12706.]\", shape=\"box\"] ;\n        1 [label=\"B <= 1.5000\\nerror = 0.484204229212\\nsamples = 6690\\nvalue = [ 2667.  4023.]\", shape=\"box\"] ;\n        0 -> 1 ;\n        2 [label=\"C <= 1.5000\\nerror = 0.429043311043\\nsamples = 12706\\nvalue = [ 4023.  8683.]\", shape=\"box\"] ;\n        0 -> 2 ;\n    }\n```\n\nHowever when sample number is large, `tree.export_graphviz` will create a dot file like this\n\n```\n    digraph Tree {\n        0 [label=\"A <= 1.5000\\nerror = 0.451898202175\\nsamples = 2.48325 e6\\nvalue = [  2.470544 e6   1.2706 e4 ]\",\n        1 [label=\"B <= 1.5000\\nerror = 0.484204229212\\nsamples = 2.470544 e6\\nvalue = [ 2.667e3  2.467877e6]\", shape=\"box\"] ;\n        0 -> 1 ;\n        2 [label=\"C <= 1.5000\\nerror = 0.429043311043\\nsamples = 1.2706 e4\\nvalue = [ 4.023 e3  8.683  e3]\", shape=\"box\"] ;\n        0 -> 2 ;\n    }\n```\n\nThe scientific notation(like `value = [  2.470544 e6   1.2706 e4 ]`)  will broke the dot file rendering process like follows[1][2]:\n\n```\n    dot -Tpdf file.dot -o file.pdf\n```\n\nThe patch will transform the scientific notation(like `value = [  2.470544e6   1.2706e4 ]`) into normal one(like  `value = [  2470544.   12706.]`).\n\n[1] http://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/tree.html#classification\n[2] "paramet", "cross", "val", "score", "function"], "B_title": "ENH extensible parameter search results", "B_clean_title": ["enh", "extens", "paramet", "search", "result"], "A_body": "This adds a new parameter `pre_dispatch` to `cross_val_score`. The same parameter is used in `GridSearchCV` https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/blob/master/sklearn/grid_search.py#L524\n\nTests are passing, docs arre build correctly and I checked for PEP8.\n\nFeel free to disregard this PR if not of any use.\n", "A_clean_body": ["thi", "add", "new", "paramet", "pre", "dispatch", "cross", "val", "score", "same", "paramet", "use", "gridsearchcv", "grid", "search", "cv", "http", "learn", "scikit", "py", "github", "com", "scikit", "search", "learn", "blob", "master", "sklearn", "grid", "l524", "test", "are", "pass", "doc", "arr", "build", "correctli", "check", "pep8", "feel", "free", "disregard", "thi", "pr", "not", "ani", "use"], "B_body": "`GridSearch` and friends need to be able to return more fields in their results (e.g. #1742, [composite score](http://sourceforge.net/mailarchive/forum.php?thread_name=513C6BDD.8020001%40ais.uni-bonn.de&forum_name=scikit-learn-general)).\n\nMore generally, the conceivable results from a parameter search can be classified into:\n1. per-parameter setting, per-fold (currently only the test score for each fold)\n2. per-parameter setting (currently the parameters and mean test score across folds)\n3. per-search (`best_params_`, `best_score_`, `best_estimator_`; however `best_params_` and `best_score_` are redundantly available in `grid_scores_` as long as the index of the best parameters is known.)\n\nHence this patch changes the output of a parameter search to be (attribute names are open for debate!):\n- `grid_results_` (1.) a structured array (a numpy array with named fields) with one record per set of parameters\n- `fold_results_` (2.) a structured array with one record per fold per set of parameters\n- `best_index_` (3.)\n- `best_estimator_` if `refit==True` (3.)\n\nThe structured arrays can be indexed by field name to produce an array of values; alternatively they can be indexed as an array to produce a single record, akin to the `namedtuple`s introduced in 0c94b55 (not in 0.13.1). In any case it allows numpy vectorised operations, as used here when calculating the mean score for each parameter setting (in `_aggregate_scores`).\n\nGiven this data, the legacy `grid_scores_` (already deprecated), `best_params_` and `best_scores_` are calculated as properties.\n\nThis approach is extensible to new fields, in particular new fields within `fold_results_` records, which are compiled from dicts returned from `fit_fold` (formerly `fit_grid_point`).\n\nThis PR is cut back from #1768; there you can see this extensibility exemplified to store training scores, training and test times, and precision and recall together with F-score.\n", "B_clean_body": ["gridsearch", "grid", "search", "friend", "need", "abl", "return", "more", "field", "their", "result", "1742", Score in Gridsearch", "B_clean_title": ["mrg", "train", "score", "gridsearch"], "A_body": "<!--\nThanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look at\nthe contribution guidelines: https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#Contributing-Pull-Requests\n-->\n#### Reference Issue\n\n<!-- Example: Fixes #1234 -->\n\nResolves #6894 Timing in *SearchCV.results_\n               #6895 Training Score in *SearchCV.results_\n#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.\n\nThe _fit method in BaseSearchCV calls the _fit_and_score function from module _validation.\n_fit_and_score has the ability to report train_score, but not by default.  On the other hand,\nthe __init__ of BaseSearchCV does not accept return_train_score as an optional keyword.  As a result, there was no way to have the results_ attribute receving train score.\n\nThe fix is to add the keyword return_train_score to the __init__ of BaseSearchCV (which is inherited by both GridSearchCV and RandomizedSearchCV).  Default is still set to False.  When return_train_score is set to True, a set of addition steps is taken to put train_score into results_\n\nThe timing information is always available but was not written into \"results_\".  This patch also writes timing info into results_ by default.\n#### Any other comments?\n\nTest is also re-written.  In the test I explicitly choose return_train_score=True for better coverage.\n\n<!--\nPlease be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is\nnecessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. `frame_mut(id)` from constellation, which panicked when the table lookup failed.\n\nThe panics were causing race conditions, e.g. visiting google.com and resizing the page would cause a panic, most Active documents are kept alive strongly, but inactive documents are only kept alive weakly. When a document is GCd, it is marked as discarded, and if it is every reactivated, a reload of the URL is triggered.\r\n\r\nNote that this PR is pretty aggressive about discarding, and can any inactive document (other than those being kept alive by other same-origin pipelines). We might want to damp it down a bit.\r\n\r\nAlso note that this interacts with browser.html in that the reloading triggered by reactivating a document triggers mozbrowser events.\r\n\r\nTo test this, I added a `-Zdiscard-inactive-documents` debug flag, which discards all inactive documents, even ones which are reachable through other same-origin pipelines.\r\n\r\n---\r\n<!-- Thank you for contributing to Servo! $anotherProperty;\r\n}\r\n````\r\n\r\nAlso it looks like a good use case for my Dynamic Validation Group as I think in many cases you do not want a sequential validation you want to see the validation Having the name in the template allows for a clean javascript to replace the prototype name in the prototype (see adjusted sample in the Doc PR). \n\n| Q | A |\n| --- | --- |\n| Bug fix? | yes |\n| New feature? | yes |\n| BC breaks? | no |\n| Deprecations? | no |\n| Tests pass? | yes |\n| Fixed tickets | n.a |\n| License | MIT |\n| Doc PR | https://github.com/symfony/symfony-docs/pull/2544 |\n", "A_clean_body": ["when", "sever", "collect", "type", "same", "page", "you", "might", "wa", "n't", "use", "differ", "prototyp", "name", "have", "name", "templat", "allow", "clean", "javascript", "replac", "prototyp", "name", "prototyp", "see", "adjust", "sampl", "doc", "pr", "bug", "fix", "ye", "new", "featur", "ye", "bc", "break", "no", "deprec", "no", "test", "pass", "ye", "fix", "ticket", "licens", "mit", "doc", "pr", "http", "doc", "pull", "2544", "github", "com", "symfoni", "symfoni"], "B_body": "| Q | A |\n| --- | --- |\n| Bug fix? | no |\n| New feature? | yes |\n| BC breaks? | no |\n| Deprecations? | no |\n| Tests pass? | yes |\n| Fixed tickets | na |\n| License | MIT |\n| Doc PR | WIP |\n- [x] fix the tests as they have not been updated yet\n- [ ] submit changes to the documentation\n\n---\n\nI've added 4 extra data-\\* attributes to collections in twig and php views for easier js manipulation.\n\nNew attributes:\n- `data-form-widget='collection'`: This is a collection and all children are form types\n- `data-collection-allow-add`: Allow adding of new elements\n- `data-collection-allow-delete`: Allow deletion of elements (new and existing)\n- `data-prototype-name`: The prototype name\n\nThis should make javascript integration much easier.\n\nExample js:\n\n``` js\n$('[data-form-widget=collection]').each(function(){\n\n    var $collection = $(this),\n        prototypeString = $collection.data('prototype'),\n        prototypeName = $collection.data('prototypeName') || '__name__',\n        prototypeNameRegx = new RegExp(prototypeName+\"(label__)?\",\"g\"),\n        count = $collection.children().length;\n\n    var $deleteLink = $(\"<span />\", {\n        'class': 'js-delete',\n        'text': 'Delete'\n    });\n\n    var $addLink = $(\"<span />\", {\n        'class': 'js-add',\n        'text': 'Add'\n    });\n\n    if($collection.data('collectionAllowDelete')) {\n\n        $collection\n            .children()\n            .append($deleteLink.clone(true));\n\n        $collection.on('click', '.js-delete', function(){\n            event.preventDefault();\n            $(this).parent().remove();\n        });\n    }\n\n    if($collection.data('collectionAllowAdd')) {\n\n        $addLink.click(function(event){\n            event.preventDefault();\n            var newPrototypeString = prototypeString.replace(prototypeNameRegx, count),\n                $newPrototype = $(newPrototypeString).append($deleteLink.clone(true));\n            $newPrototype.insertBefore($addLink);\n            count++;\n        });\n\n        $collection.append($addLink);\n    }\n});\n```\n\nReplaces #5145\n", "B_clean_body": ["bug", "fix", "no", "new", "featur", "ye", "bc", "break", "no", "deprec", "no", `data-form-widget='collection'`: This is a collection and all children are form types\n- `data-collection-allow-add`: Allow adding of new elements\n- `data-collection-allow-delete`: Allow deletion of elements (new and existing)\n- `data-prototype-name`: The prototype name\n\nThis should make javascript integration much easier.\n\nExample js:\n\n``` js\n$('[data-form-widget=collection]').each(function(){\n\n    var $collection = $(this),\n        prototypeString = $collection.data('prototype'),\n        prototypeName = 'js-add',\n        'text': 'Add'\n    });\n\n    if($collection.data('collectionAllowDelete')) {\n\n        $collection\n            .children()\n            .append($deleteLink.clone(true));\n\n $newPrototype = $(newPrototypeString).append($deleteLink.clone(true));\n            $newPrototype.insertBefore($addLink);\n            count++;\n        });\n\n        $collection.append($addLink);\n "no", "test", "pass", "ye", "fix", "ticket", "licens", "mit", "doc", "pr", "ad", "miss", "autoconfigur", "flag", "debug", "contain", "servic", "id"], "B_body": "| Q             | A\r\n| ------------- | ---\r\n| Branch?       | master\r\n| Bug fix?      | no\r\n| New feature?  | yes (mostly, a continuation of a new feature)\r\n| BC breaks?    | no\r\n| Deprecations? | no\r\n| Tests pass?   | yes\r\n| Fixed tickets | n/a\r\n| License       | MIT\r\n| Doc PR        | https://github.com/symfony/symfony-docs/issues/7538\r\n\r\nThis is a proposal to allow the user to opt into some automatic `_instanceof` config. Suppose I want to auto-tag all of my voters and event subscribers\r\n\r\n```yml\r\n# current\r\nservices:\r\n    _defaults:\r\n        autowire: true\r\n\r\n    _instanceof:\r\n        Symfony\\Component\\Security\\Core\\Authorization\\Voter\\VoterInterface:\r\n            tags: [security.voter]\r\n\r\n        Symfony\\Component\\EventDispatcher\\EventSubscriberInterface:\r\n            tags: [kernel.event_subscriber]\r\n\r\n    # services using the above tags\r\n    AppBundle\\Security\\PostVoter: ~\r\n    AppBundle\\EventListener\\CheckRequirementsSubscriber: ~\r\n```\r\n\r\nIf I'm registering a service with a class that implements `VoterInterface`, when would I ever *not* want that to be tagged with `security.voter`? Here's the proposed code:\r\n\r\n```yml\r\n# proposed\r\nservices:\r\n    _defaults:\r\n        autowire: true\r\n        autoconfigure: true\r\n\r\n    # services using the auto_configure_instanceof functionality\r\n    AppBundle\\Security\\PostVoter: ~\r\n    AppBundle\\EventListener\\CheckRequirementsSubscriber: ~\r\n```\r\n\r\nThe user must opt into this and it only applies locally to this configuration file. It works because each enabled bundle would have the opportunity to add one or more \"automatic instanceof\" definitions - e.g. SecurityBundle would add the `security.voter` instanceof config, FrameworkBundle would add the `kernel.event_subscriber` instanceof config, etc.\r\n\r\nFor another example, you can check out the proposed changes to `symfony-demo` - symfony/symfony-demo#483 - the `_instanceof` section is pretty heavy: https://github.com/hhamon/symfony-demo/blob/81694ac21e63bebe7ecfa22fa689766f2f38ccd5/app/config/services.yml#L20\r\n\r\nThanks!\r\n", "B_clean_body": ["branch", "A_clean_title": ["propertyaccess", "properti", "access", "bc", "break", "sinc"], "B_title": "[property access] Fix issue for broken reference chain", "B_clean_title": ["properti", "access", "fix", "issu", "broken", "refer", "chain"], "A_body": "setValue & isWratable loops must only stops on reference and object. References can also be arrays and if the loop stops the value is never set in the object. (Breaks since 2.6.5 commit e3e4695)\n\n| Q | A |\n| --- | --- |\n| Bug fix? | yes |\n| New feature? | no |\n| BC breaks? | no |\n| Deprecations? | no |\n| Tests pass? | yes |\n| Fixed tickets |  |\n| License | MIT |\n| Doc PR |  |\n\nThis merge request fixes the following cases taht was working with version previous to 2.6.5:\n\nA class with a property myArray which can be a multi dimensional array can now be accesed using myArray[foo][bar][baz]\nPreviously only myArray[foo] was working the break is since commit e3e4695\n", "A_clean_body": ["setvalu", "set", "valu", "iswrat", "wratabl", "loop", "must", "onli", "stop", "refer", "object", "refer", "also", "array", "loop", "stop", "valu", "never", "set", "object", "break", "sinc", "commit", "e3e4695", "bug", "fix", "ye", "new", "featur", "no", "bc", "break", "no", "deprec", "no", "test", "pass", "ye", "fix", "ticket", "licens", "mit", "doc", "pr", "thi", "merg", "request", "fix", "follow", "case", "taht", "wa", "work", "version", "previou", "class", "properti", "myarray", "my", "array", "which", "multi", "dimension", "array", "now", "acces", "myarray", "my", "array", "foo", "bar", "baz", "previous", "onli", "myarray", "my", "array", "foo", "wa", "work", "break", "sinc", "commit", "e3e4695"], "B_body": "For the 'property values' that corresponds to a property path in PropertyAccessor::readPropertiesUntil() method, if current element's 'IS_REF' flag is true, it means and only means that it is passed as a reference to its immediate parent in the property path.\n\nIt does not guarantee that current element's reference will be automatically escalated to the top, because if there is an element, which is passed by value, stands in its way of going back to the top, the reference chain will be broken.\n\nHowever, a broken reference chain does NOT necessarily break the reference itself.\n\nThere are actually two scenarios:\n1. Current element is an object: this won't break the object's reference, because object is always passed as reference, even if the array that holds it is copied, the object is still copied as reference.\n2. Current element is an array element: this will also break the reference, because when copying an array, the array elements are copied as values instead of references. This means, at this point, the top element is referring to a different \"current element\". In order to escalate current element back to the top, its values must be copied explicitly.\n\nThe original code of PropertyAccessor does not recognize the 2nd senario, so it will raise issues in method setValue() and isWritable().\n\nLet's explain this issue with some examples:\n\n``` php\n// example 1\n\nclass Foo\n{\n    protected $value;\n\n    public function getValue()\n    {\n        return $this->value;\n    }\n\n    public function setValue($value)\n    {\n        $this->value = $value;\n    }\n\n    public function __construct($value)\n    {\n       $this->value = $value;\n    }\n}\n\n$pa = new PropertyAccessor();\n\n$b = new Foo('old-value');\n$a = new Foo(\n    array(\n       'a' => array(\n           'b' => array(\n               'c' => $b\n           )\n       )\n    )\n)\n\n$pa->setValue($a, 'value[a][b][c].value', 'new-value');\n// The reference chain is broken at $a.value, because array is\n// passed as value. But since $a.value[a][b][c].value is an object,\n// which is always passed as reference, the refernce itself is not broken,\n// the original code base works and the value of $a.value[a][b][c].value\n// will be changed to 'new-value'\n```\n\n``` php\n// example 2.\n\nclass Foo\n{\n    protected $value;\n\n    public function getValue()\n    {\n        return $this->value;\n    }\n\n    public function setValue($value)\n    {\n        $this->value = $value;\n    }\n\n    public function __construct($value)\n    {\n       $this->value = $value;\n    }\n}\n\n$a = new Foo(\n    array(\n        'a' => array(\n            'b' => 'old-value'\n        )\n    )\n);\n\n$pa = new PropertyAccessor();\n\n$pa->setValue($a, 'value[a][b]', 'new-value');\n\n// The reference chain is broken at $a.value, because array is\n// passed as value and the reference of $a.value[a][b] is broken as\n// well, because when $a.value is copied, $a.value[a][b] is passed by\n// value as well.\n// But the original code base does not recognize this scenario and will\n// terminate the process earlier, which will fail to update the value of\n// $a.value[a][b]\n\n```\n\nThis issue is caused by the incorrect use of 'IS_REF' flag: the original\ncode base only use the 'IS_REF' flag to identify reference element, but\nit does not care if it's an object or array element. For object, it's\nsafe to terminate the process earlier, but for array element, we should\nnot terminate the process unless we can confirm that its reference chain\nis not broken - all of its ancient elements in the property path are\npassed by reference.\n\nThis issue affects both the setValue() and the isWritable() methods.\n\nSo we need introduce a new flag, 'IS_REF_CHAINED', to identify an\nelement that is passed as reference and all its ancient elements in\nthe property path are also passed as reference.\n\nAnd we can terminate the process as follows:\n1. If current element is an object, then it's safe to terminate the value setting process here because object is always passed as reference.\n2. If current element is not an object and its 'IS_REF_CHAINED' flag is true, then it's safe to terminate the value setting process, because all the acient elements in the property path are referring\n   to this object as reference, so there is no need to copy values.\n3. Otherwise, we should not terminate the value setting process here,\n   so that the element value can be copied explicitly later.\n   \n   | Q | A |\n   | --- | --- |\n   | Bug fix? | yes |\n   | New feature? | no |\n   | BC breaks? | no |\n   | Deprecations? | no |\n   | Tests pass? | yes |\n   | Fixed tickets | n/a |\n   | License | MIT |\n   | Doc PR | n/a |\n", "B_clean_body": ["'properti", "overrid", "default", "success", "failur", "handler"], "B_title": "Extend AbstractFactory for easy extending", "B_clean_title": ["extend", "abstractfactori", "abstract", "factori", "easi", "extend"], "A_body": "| Q | A |\n| --- | --- |\n| Bug fix? | no |\n| New feature? | yes |\n| BC breaks? | no |\n| Deprecations? | no |\n| Tests pass? | yes |\n| Fixed tickets | #5432, #9272, #10417, #11926 |\n| License | MIT |\n| Doc PR | symfony/symfony-docs#4258 |\n\nOverriding the default success/failure handler of the security firewalls is possible via the `success_handler` and `failure_handler` setting but this approach is not flexible as it does not allow you to get the options/provider key.\n\nTo sum up the problem:\n- Overriding the default success/failure handler is possible via a service;\n- When not overridden, the default success/failure handler gets options and the provider key;\n- Those options and the provider key are injected by the factory as they are dynamic (they depend on the firewall and the provider key), so getting those options/provider key is not possible for a custom service that is only configured via the container configuration;\n- Extending the default handler does not help as the injection mechanism is only triggered when no custom provider is set;\n- Wrapping the default handler is not possible as the service id is dynamic.\n\n... and of course we need to keep BC and make it work for people extending the default handler but also for people just using the interface.\n\nInstead of the current PR, I propose this slightly different approach. It's not perfect, but given the above constraint, I think this is an acceptable trade-of.\n\nSo, several use cases:\n- Using the default handler (no change);\n- Using a custom handler that implements `AuthenticationSuccessHandlerInterface` directly and does not need any options (no change);\n- Using a custom handler that needs the options/provider key (that's the new use case this PR supports).\n\nThis PR introduces 2 new classes that wrap custom handlers. If those classes define the `setOptions()` and/or `setProviderKey()` methods, they are automatically called with the correct arguments. Yours handler does not need to extend the default handler `DefaultAuthentication*Handler`, but doing so helps as the setters are already defined there.\n", "A_clean_body": ["bug", "fix", "no", "new", these regexps are proper (credit card validation is always a pain)\nLicense of the code: MIT\nDocumentation PR: \n\nRegarding Cases excluded from new Regular Expressions:\n- Credit card lengths should be respected, these regexp cover lengths in http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_card_number\n- Visa length can only be 16 and 13 (older ones)\n- Diners Cards starting by 5 come from a joint venture Because the string only behavior was enforced by the transformer tests this is a BC change. (Personally I think that this is not a BC break that would cause problems).\n\nAnother possible fix is to add a normalizer for the `empty_data` option and transform a int or float to a LocalizedString
