When stdout and stderr share the same formatter, this results in color codes being output while this is not desired behaviour.\n\nE.g.\n\n``` php\n# stdout.php\n<?php\nrequire_once 'vendor/autoload.php';\n$out = new Symfony\\Component\\Console\\Output\\ConsoleOutput();\n$out->writeln('<info>OK</info>');\n```\n\nwithout patch\n\n``` bash\n$ php stdout.php | more\nESC[32mOKESC[39m\n\n$ php stdout.php 2>/dev/null | more\nOK\n```\n\nwith patch\n\n``` bash\n$ php stdout.php | more\nOK\n```\n\nThe cleanest solution I could think of, was simply cloning the given formatter rather than sharing the same instance.\n\nPartial credit goes to @Seldaek as well for discovering and debugging this unexpected behaviour with me.\n\n| Q | A |\n| --- | --- |\n| Bug fix? Install it via Composer and have it available automatically if the intl extension is not available.\n\nAdditionally, the component ships data from the ICU library which can be accessed through the methods:\n\n``` php\nuse Symfony\\Component\\Intl\\Intl;\n\nIntl::getCurrencyBundle()->...\nIntl::getLanguageBundle()->...\nIntl::getLocaleBundle()->...\nIntl::getRegionBundle()->...\n```\n\nIf the intl extension is installed, Composer will install the ICU data for the ICU version in the intl extension. If the intl extension is not installed, Composer will use stub ICU data for the latest ICU version (see `Intl::getStubIcuVersion()`).\n\nSee the [README](/bschussek/symfony/blob/intl/src/Symfony/Component/Intl/README.md) for more information.\n\nTodo:\n- [x] finish the Intl README file\n- [x] update the Icu README file\n- [x] update the | yes |\n| New feature? | no |\n| BC breaks? | no |\n| Deprecations? | no |\n| Tests pass? | yes |\n| Fixed tickets | - |\n| License | MIT |\n", "A_clean_body": ["bug", "fix", "ye", "new", "featur", "no", "bc", "break", "no", "deprec", "no", "test", "pass", "ye", "fix", "ticket", "licens", "mit"], "B_body": "| Q | A |\n| --- | --- |\n| Bug fix? | yes |\n| New feature? | yes |\n| BC breaks? | no |\n| Deprecations? | no |\n| Tests pass? | yes |\n| Fixed tickets | #14349, #13626 |\n| License | MIT |\n| Doc PR | N/A |\n\nThis is an alternative approach for the version feedback feature of PR #13626. The original PR performed a server-side HTTP request to symfony.com, which might be problematic in certain environments, see #14349.\n\nThis PR makes the following assumptions:\n- Symfony's release roadmap is rarely changed\n- After the first release of a branch, the Symfony development team is committed to the announced support dates.\n- The support period of a stable  branch might be extended, but it's usually not reduced.\n\nGiven those assumptions, the EOM and EOL dates may be shipped with the Symfony release and may be updated with a later bugfix release. The information would be available offline without any need to query Symfony's servers.\n\nIf the user is running the latest bugfix release of a branch, the EOM/EOL dates should be accurate. If he's running an earlier version, he might get a false positive warning about reaching EOM or EOL if the support period has been extended in the meantime. But since he's running an outdated version anyway, would this really be a problem?\n", "B_clean_body": ["bug", "fix", "ye", "new", "featur", "ye", "bc", "break", "no", "deprec", "no", "test", "pass", ["optionsresolv", "option", "resolv", "merg", "option", "class", "into", "optionsresolv", "option", "resolv"], "B_title": "[OptionsResolver] Exception doesn't report the actual type used", "B_clean_title": ["optionsresolv", "option", "resolv", "except", "n't", "report", "actual", "type", "use"], "A_body": "| Q | A |\n| --- | --- |\n| Bug fix? | yes |\n| New feature? | no |\n| BC breaks? | yes |\n| Deprecations? | yes |\n| Tests pass? | yes |\n| Fixed tickets | #4500, #9174, #10585, #10202, #11020, makes #7979+#10616 obsolete |\n| License | MIT |\n| Doc PR | symfony/symfony-docs#4159 |\n#11716 was reverted as preparation of this PR (453882cd03dd30c4fb4b4465772f84583948e81b).\n\nThe Options class was merged into OptionsResolver. This made it possible to fix several tickets, as indicated above.\n\n**Usage**\n\nSee [the updated documentation](https://github.com/webmozart/symfony-docs/blob/issue11705/components/options_resolver.rst).\n\n**Bug Fixes**\n\nPreviously, the options weren't validated before the normalizers were called. As a result, the normalizers had to perform validation again:\n\n``` php\n$resolver->setAllowedTypes(array(\n    'choices' => 'array',\n));\n$resolver->setNormalizers(array(\n    'choices' => function (Options $options, $value) {\n         array_merge($options['choices'], ...);\n    },\n));\n\n// fatal error\n$resolver->resolve(array('choices' => 'foobar'));\n```\n\nThis is fixed now.\n\n**BC Breaks**\n\nThe `array` type hint was removed from `setRequired()`, `setAllowedValues()`, `addAllowedValues()`, `setAllowedTypes()` and `addAllowedTypes()`. If anybody implemented `OptionsResolverInterface`, they must adapt their code.\n\nThe Options class was turned into an interface extending ArrayAccess and Countable. Anybody instantiating Options directly should instantiate OptionsResolver instead. Anybody using any of the methods available in Options (`get()`, `has()`) should use the ArrayAccess interface instead.\n\nNormalizers are not called anymore for undefined options (#9174). People need to set a default value if they want a normalizer to be executed independent of the options passed to `resolve()`.\n\n**Deprecations**\n\nOptionsResolverInterface was deprecated and will be removed in 3.0. OptionsResolver instances are not supposed to be shared between classes, hence an interface does not make sense.\n\nSeveral other methods were deprecated. See the CHANGELOG and UPGRADE-2.6 files for information.\n\n**Todo**\n- [x] Fix PHPDoc\n- [x] Adapt CHANGELOG/UPGRADE\n- [x] Adapt documentation\n- [x] Deprecate OptionsResolver[Interface]\n", PR #13048 due to issue #13269", "B_clean_title": ["secur", "revert", "pr", "13048", "due", "issu", "13269"], "A_body": "| Q | A |\n| --- | --- |\n| Bug fix? | yes |\n| New feature? | no |\n| BC breaks? | no |\n| Deprecations? | no |\n| Tests pass? | yes |\n| Fixed tickets | #13269, #13283 |\n| License | MIT |\n| Doc PR | none |\n\nSee #13269 for the discussion. This workaround avoids destroying the old session after login on the migrate strategy when running under a php version that we know to be broken.\n\nCorresponding php bug: https://bugs.php.net/bug.php?id=63379\n", "A_clean_body": ["bug", "fix", "ye", "new", "featur", "no", "bc", "break", "no", "deprec", "no", "test", "pass", "ye", "fix", "ticket", "13269", "13283", "licens", "mit", "doc", "pr", "none", "see", "13269", "discuss", "thi", "workaround", "avoid", "destroy", "old", "session", "after", "login", "migrat", "strategi", "when", "run", "under", "php", "version", "that", "we", "know", "broken", "correspond", "php", "bug", "http", "php", "php", "bug", "net", "bug", "id=63379"], "B_body": "| Q | A |\n| --- | --- |\n| Bug fix? | yes |\n| New feature? | no |\n| BC breaks? | no |\n| Deprecations? | no |\n| Tests pass? | yes |\n| Fixed tickets | #13269 |\n| License | MIT |\n| Doc PR |  |\n", "B_clean_body": ["bug", "fix", "ye", "new", "featur", "no", "bc", "break", "no", "deprec", "no", "test", "pass", "ye", "fix", "ticket", "13269", "licens", "mit", "doc", "pr"], "title_sim": [0.23037920385339156], "body_sim": [0.5764214540946337], "file_list_sim": 1.0, "overlap_files_len": 2, "code_sim": [0.0, 0.0], "location_sim": [1.0, 1.0], "pattern": 1, "time": 0}, {"A_title": "[2.7][Form] Refactored choice lists to support dynamic labels, values and attributes", "A_clean_title": ["form", "refactor", "choic", "list", "support", "dynam", "label", "valu", "attribut"], "B_title": "[Form] Implemented attributes for choices", "B_clean_title": ["form", "implement", "attribut", "choic"], "A_body": "| Q | A |\n| --- | --- |\n| Bug fix? | no |\n| New feature? | yes |\n| BC breaks? | yes |\n| Deprecations? | yes |\n| Tests pass? | yes |\n| Fixed tickets | #4067, #5494, #3836, #12148 |\n| License | MIT |\n| Doc PR | TODO |\n\nThis PR didn't make it in time anymore for the 2.6 feature freeze. It will be merged as soon as development for 2.7 officially starts.\n\nI implemented the additional options \"choice_label\", \"choice_name\", \"choice_value\", \"choice_attr\", \"group_by\" and \"flip_choices\" for ChoiceType. Additionally the \"preferred_choices\" option was updated to accept callables and property paths.\n\nThe \"flip_choices\" option will be removed in Symfony 3.0, where the \"choices\" will be flipped by default. The reason for that is that, right now, choices are limited to strings and integers (i.e. valid array keys). When we flip the array, we remove that limitation. Since choice labels are always strings, we can also always use them as array keys:\n\n``` php\n// Not possible currently, but possible with \"flip_choices\"\n$builder->add('attending', 'choice', array(\n    'choices' => array(\n        'Yes' => true,\n        'No' => false,\n        'Maybe' => null,\n    ),\n    'flip_choices' => true,\n));\n```\n\nAll the features described here obviously also apply to subtypes of \"choice\", such as \"entity\".\n\n**choice_label**\n\nReturns the label for each choice. Can be a callable (which receives the choice as first and the key of the \"choices\" array as second argument) or a property path.\n\nIf `null`, the keys of the \"choices\" array are used as labels.\n\n``` php\n// callable\n$builder->add('attending', 'choice', array(\n    'choices' => array(\n        'yes' => true,\n        'no' => false,\n        'maybe' => null,\n    ),\n    'flip_choices' => true,\n    'choice_label' => function ($choice, $key) {\n        return 'form.choice.'.$key;\n    },\n));\n\n// property path\n$builder->add('attending', 'choice', array(\n    'choices' => array(\n        Status::getInstance(Status::YES),\n        Status::getInstance(Status::NO),\n        Status::getInstance(Status::MAYBE),\n    ),\n    'flip_choices' => true,\n    'choice_label' => 'displayName',\n));\n```\n\n**choice_name**\n\nReturns the form name for each choice. That name is used as name of the checkbox/radio form for this choice. It is also used as index of the choice views in the template. Can be a callable (like for \"choice_label\") or a property path.\n\nThe generated names must be valid form names, i.e. contain alpha-numeric symbols, underscores, hyphens and colons only. They must start with an alpha-numeric symbol or an underscore.\n\nIf `null`, an incrementing integer is used as name.\n\n``` php\n// callable\n$builder->add('attending', 'choice', array(\n    'choices' => array(\n        'Yes' => true,\n        'No' => false,\n        'Maybe' => null,\n    ),\n    'flip_choices' => true,\n    'choice_name' => function ($choice, $key) {\n        // use the labels as names\n        return strtolower($key);\n    },\n));\n\n// property path\n$builder->add('attending', 'choice', array(\n    'choices' => array(\n        'Yes' => Status::getInstance(Status::YES),\n        'No' => Status::getInstance(Status::NO),\n        'Maybe' => Status::getInstance(Status::MAYBE),\n    ),\n    'flip_choices' => true,\n    'choice_name' => 'value',\n));\n```\n\n**choice_value**\n\nReturns the string value for each choice. This value is displayed in the \"value\" attributes and submitted in the POST/PUT requests. Can be a callable (like for \"choice_label\") or a property path.\n\nIf `null`, an incrementing integer is used as value.\n\n``` php\n// callable\n$builder->add('attending', 'choice', array(\n    'choices' => array(\n        'Yes' => true,\n        'No' => false,\n        'Maybe' => null,\n    ),\n    'flip_choices' => true,\n    'choice_value' => function ($choice, $key) {\n        if (null === $choice) {\n            return 'null';\n        }\n\n        if (true === $choice) {\n            return 'true';\n        }\n\n        return 'false';\n    },\n));\n\n// property path\n$builder->add('attending', 'choice', array(\n    'choices' => array(\n        'Yes' => Status::getInstance(Status::YES),\n        'No' => Status::getInstance(Status::NO),\n        'Maybe' => Status::getInstance(Status::MAYBE),\n    ),\n    'flip_choices' => true,\n    'choice_value' => 'value',\n));\n```\n\n**choice_attr**\n\nReturns the additional HTML attributes for choices. Can be an array, a callable (like for \"choice_label\") or a property path.\nIf an array, the key of the \"choices\" array must be used as keys.\n\n``` php\n// array\n$builder->add('attending', 'choice', array(\n    'choices' => array(\n        'Yes' => true,\n        'No' => false,\n        'Maybe' => null,\n    ),\n    'flip_choices' => true,\n    'choice_attr' => array(\n        'Maybe' => array('class' => 'greyed-out'),\n    ),\n));\n\n// callable\n$builder->add('attending', 'choice', array(\n    'choices' => array(\n        'Yes' => true,\n        'No' => false,\n        'Maybe' => null,\n    ),\n    'flip_choices' => true,\n    'choice_attr' => function ($choice, $key) {\n        if (null === $choice) {\n            return array('class' => 'greyed-out');\n        }\n    },\n));\n\n// property path\n$builder->add('attending', 'choice', array(\n    'choices' => array(\n        'Yes' => Status::getInstance(Status::YES),\n        'No' => Status::getInstance(Status::NO),\n        'Maybe' => Status::getInstance(Status::MAYBE),\n    ),\n    'flip_choices' => true,\n    'choice_value' => 'htmlAttributes',\n));\n```\n\n**group_by**\n\nReturns the grouping used for the choices. Can be an array/Traversable, a callable (like for \"choice_label\") or a property path.\n\nThe return values of the callable/property path are used as group labels. If `null` is returned, a choice is not grouped.\n\nIf `null`, the structure of the \"choices\" array is used to construct the groups.\n\n``` php\n// default\n$builder->add('attending', 'choice', array(\n    'choices' => array(\n        'Decided' => array(\n            'Yes' => true,\n            'No' => false,\n        ),\n        'Undecided' => array(\n            'Maybe' => null,\n        ),\n    ),\n    'flip_choices' => true,\n));\n\n// callable\n$builder->add('attending', 'choice', array(\n    'choices' => array(\n        'Yes' => true,\n        'No' => false,\n        'Maybe' => null,\n    ),\n    'flip_choices' => true,\n    'group_by' => function ($choice, $key) {\n        if (null === $choice) {\n            return 'Undecided';\n        }\n\n        return 'Decided';\n    },\n));\n\n// property path\n$builder->add('attending', 'choice', array(\n    'choices' => array(\n        'Yes' => Status::getInstance(Status::YES),\n        'No' => Status::getInstance(Status::NO),\n        'Maybe' => Status::getInstance(Status::MAYBE),\n    ),\n    'flip_choices' => true,\n    'group_by' => 'type',\n));\n```\n\n**preferred_choices**\n\nReturns the preferred choices. Can be an array/Traversable, a callable (like for \"choice_label\") or a property path.\n\n``` php\n// array\n$builder->add('attending', 'choice', array(\n    'choices' => array(\n        'Yes' => true,\n        'No' => false,\n        'Maybe' => null,\n    ),\n    'flip_choices' => true,\n    'preferred_choices' => array(true),\n));\n\n// callable\n$builder->add('attending', 'choice', array(\n    'choices' => array(\n        'Yes' => true,\n        'No' => false,\n        'Maybe' => null,\n    ),\n    'flip_choices' => true,\n    'preferred_choices' => function ($choice, $key) {\n        return true === $choice;\n    },\n));\n\n// property path\n$builder->add('attending', 'choice', array(\n    'choices' => array(\n        'Yes' => Status::getInstance(Status::YES),\n        'No' => Status::getInstance(Status::NO),\n        'Maybe' => Status::getInstance(Status::MAYBE),\n    ),\n    'flip_choices' => true,\n    'preferred_choices' => 'preferred',\n));\n```\n\n**Technical Changes**\n\nTo properly implement all this, the old `ChoiceListInterface` class was deprecated and replaced by a new, slimmer one. The creation of choice views is now separated from choice lists. Hence a lot of logic is not executed anymore when processing (but not displaying) a form.\n\nInternally, a `ChoiceListFactoryInterface` implementation is used to construct choice lists and choice views. Two decorators exist for this class:\n- `CachingFactoryDecorator`: caches choice lists/views so that multiple fields displaying the same choices (e.g. in collection fields) use the same choice list/view\n- `PropertyAccessDecorator`: adds support for property paths to a factory\n\n**BC Breaks**\n\nThe option \"choice_list\" of ChoiceType now contains a `Symfony\\Component\\Form\\ChoiceList\\ChoiceListInterface` instance, which is a super-type of the deprecated `ChoiceListInterface`.\n\n**Todos**\n\nTo be completed after the release of 2.6:\n- [ ] Adapt CHANGELOGs\n- [ ] Adapt UPGRADE files\n- [ ] symfony/symfony-docs issue/PR\n", "A_clean_body": ["bug", "fix", "no", "new", "featur", "ye", "bc", "break", "ye", "deprec", "ye", "test", "pass", Bug fix? | no |\n| New feature? | yes |\n| BC breaks? | no |\n| Deprecations? | no |\n| Tests pass? | yes |\n| Fixed tickets |  |\n| License | MIT |\n| Doc PR |  |\n## Use cases\n\nAdd attributes to choices like it's possible with any other element for example to add microdata attributes to use in select2 templates or disable choices.\n## Usage\n\nThere are a few ways to apply attributes to choices:\n### By specifying the choices_attr option\n\nNote: It works only when using `choices`. See below for when using `choice_list`.\n#### As an array\n\n``` php\n$builder->add('choice', 'choice', null, array(\n    'choices' => array('a' => 'A', 'b' => 'B', 'c' => 'C'),\n    'choices_attr' => array(\n        'a' => array('disabled' => true, 'data-foo' => 'bar'),\n        'c' => array('disabled' => true, 'data-foo' => 'bar'),\n    ),\n));\n```\n#### As a callable\n\n``` php\n$builder->add('choice', 'choice', null, array(\n    'choices' => array('a' => 'A', 'b' => 'B', 'c' => 'C'),\n    'choices_attr' => function ($choice) {\n        $attributes = array();\n\n        if ('A' === $choice || 'C' === $choice) {\n            $attributes['disabled'] = true;\n            $attributes['data-foo'] = 'bar';\n        }\n\n        return $attributes;    \n    }\n));\n```\n### By passing the attributes to the choice lists\n\n``` php\n$builder->add('choice', 'choice', null, array(\n    'choice_list' => new SimpleChoiceList(\n        array('a' => 'A', 'b' => 'B', 'c' => 'C'), array(), array(\n            'a' => array('disabled' => true, 'data-foo' => 'bar'),\n            'c' => array('disabled' => true, 'data-bar' => 'baz'),\n        )\n    )\n);\n```\n\nEdit : It is related to the following issues\n\nhttps://github.com/symfony/symfony/pull/7510\nhttps://github.com/symfony/symfony/pull/9694\nhttps://github.com/symfony/symfony/issues/3836\n", "B_clean_body": {"A_title": "[Validator] Fix for #1406", "A_clean_title": ["valid", "fix", "1406"], "B_title": "[Form] Fix choice field validation", "B_clean_title": ["form", "fix", "choic", "field", "valid"], "A_body": "Proposal fix for #1406 + additional tests.\n", "A_clean_body": ["propos", "fix", "1406", "addit", "test"], "B_body": "To validate a choice field, we use an array of allowed values. It can be guessed from Choice constraint or specified when calling add() on the FormBuilder.\n\nThe validation is currently done using values of the given array. With this pull request, we validate with the keys of the array which makes much more sense as this is what is transfered in the POST request.\n\nWithout this patch, guessing is useless (validation always fails), and we're forced to give the list of allowed values (array_keys on what's given to Choice constraint) when calling add() on the FormBuilder.\n\nThis commit fixes issues #1405 and #1406.\n", "B_clean_body": ["valid", "choic", "field", "we", "use", "array", "allow", "valu", "it", "guess", "choic", "constraint", "or", "specifi", "when", "call", "add", "formbuild", "form", "builder", "valid", "current", "done", "valu", "given", "array", "thi", "pull", "request", "we", "valid", "key", "array", "which", "make", "much", "more", "sens", "as", "thi", "what", "transfer", "post", "request", "without", "thi", "patch", "guess", "useless", "valid", "alway", "fail", "we", "'re", "forc", "give", "list", "allow", "valu", "array", "key", "what", "'s", "given", "choic", "constraint", "when", "call", "add", "formbuild", "form", "builder", "thi", "commit", "fix", "issu", "1405", "1406"], "title_sim": [0.5731378398612568], "body_sim": [0.23350689956605192], "file_list_sim": 0.5, "overlap_files_len": 1, "code_sim": [0.06372165341977364, 0.3429139571330493], "location_sim": [0.35353535353535354, 0.7954545454545454], "pattern": 1, "time": 0}, {"A_title": "[2.8] Deprecate the correct APC cache service", "A_clean_title": ["deprec", "correct", "apc", "cach", "servic"], "B_title": "[FrameworkBundle][Validator] Fix apc cache service deprecation", "B_clean_title": ["frameworkbundl", "framework", "bundl", "valid", "fix", "apc", "cach", "servic", "deprec"], "A_body": "| Q | A |\n| --- | --- |\n| Bug fix? The main difference is that host pattern cannot be parsed same as path pattern.\nIn path optional placeholders are located in the end like \n\n```\n/example/{mandatory}/{optional1}/{optional2}\n```\n\nAnd hosts can have optional placeholders in the beginning like\n\n```\n{optional1}.{optional2}.{mandatory}.example.com\n```\n\nSo I have split compilePattern() method in compilePathPattern() and compileHostPattern() that have different compiling flow.\nThe goal was to be able configure host like\n\n``` yaml\nexample:\n    path:     /example\n    host:     {subdomain}.example.com\n    defaults: { subdomain: \"\" }\n```\n\nand match _http://example.com_ and _http://something.example.com_\n", "A_clean_body": ["bug", "fix", "no", "new", "featur", "ye", "bc", "break", "no", "deprec", "no", "test", "pass", "ye", "fix", "ticket", "7306", "licens", "mit", "new", "featur", "support", "option", "placehold", "host", "pattern", "main", "differ", "that", "host", "pattern", "not", "pars", "same", "as", "path", "pattern", "path", "option", "placehold", "are", "locat", "end", "like", "exampl", "mandatori", "optional1", "optional2", "host", "have", "option", "placehold", "begin", "like", "optional1", "optional2", "mandatori", "exampl", "com", "so", "have", "split", "compilepattern", "compil", "pattern", "method", "compilepathpattern", "compil", "path", "pattern", "compilehostpattern", "compil", "host", "pattern", "that", "have", "differ", "compil", "flow", "goal", "wa", "abl", "configur", "host", "like", "yaml", "exampl", "path", "exampl", "host", "subdomain", "exampl", "com", "default", "subdomain", "match", "http", "exampl", "com", "http", "exampl", "someth", "com"], "B_body": "WIP: An early stage that only implements the algorithm to get a parse tree of the pattern that can contain optionals parts (which itself can be nested at any depth). | master |\n| Bug fix? | no |\n| New feature? | no |\n| BC breaks? | no |\n| Deprecations? | no |\n| Tests pass? | yes |\n| Fixed tickets | - |\n| License | MIT |\n| Doc PR | - |\n", "A_clean_body": ["branch", "master", "bug", "fix", "no", "new", "featur", "no", "bc", "break", "no", "deprec", "no", "test", "pass", "ye", "fix", "ticket", "licens", "mit", "doc", "pr"], "B_body": "| Q | A |\n| --- | --- |\n| Branch | master |\n| Bug fix? | no |\n| New feature? | yes |\n| BC breaks? | no |\n| Deprecations? | no |\n| Tests pass? | yes |\n| Fixed tickets | #4833, #15524 |\n| License | MIT |\n| Doc PR | todo |\n- [ ] Gather feedback\n- [ ] Address a doc PR\n- [ ] Update CHANGELOG\n- [ ] Add a lot of tests :)\n# Summary\n- c2944ac fixes #4833. Handle nested options resolving\n  - add `OptionsResolver::nested` a private array of nested `OptionsResolver` instances by root names,\n  - add `OptionsResolver::setNested($option, array $defaults)` defines an option as a new self and returns the nested `OptionsResolver` instance,\n  - add `OptionsResolver::isNested($option)` returns whether an option name is a root name for a nested `OptionsResolver` instance,\n  - add `OptionsResolver::getNested()` an array of root names representing nested `OptionsResolver` instances.\n  \n  ``` php\n  $connexionResolver = $resolver->setNested('connexion', array(\n      'host' => 'localhost',\n      'port' => 80,\n  );\n  \n  $connexionResolver->setRequired('user');\n  $connexionResolver->setDefault('password', function (Options $connexion) {\n      return isset($nested['user']) ? '' : null;\n  });\n  $connexionResolver->setDefault('secure', false);\n  $connexionResolver->setNormalizer('secure', function (Options $connexion, $secure) {\n      return 443 === $nested['port'] ?: $secure;\n  });\n  $connexionResolver->setAllowedTypes('port', 'int');\n  $connexionResolver->setAllowedTypes('user', 'string');\n  \n  $resolver->setRequired('connexion');\n  $resolver->setNormalizer('connexion', function (Options $options, $resolvedConnexion) {\n      if ('localhost' === $resolvedConnexion['host']) {\n          $resolvedConnexion['host'] = $option['param'];\n      }\n  \n      return $resolvedConnexion;\n  });\n  \n  // In a sub class\n  parent::configureOptions($resolver);\n  \n  $resolver->setDefault('user', $user);\n  $connexionResolver = $resolver->setDefault(\n      'connexion', function (Options $options, $previousDefaultConnexion) {\n          if ($options['user'] instanceof UserInterface and 'localhost' !== $previousDefaultConnexion['host'])\n              $connexion['user'] = $options['user']->getUsername();\n          }\n  );\n  \n  $options = $resolver->resolve($array);\n  ```\n  \n  `*Allowed*` methods are not supported with root name of nested options since they always have to be an array, so:\n- f2ad947 trigger warning ? throw `BadMethodCallException` ? what do you think ?\n- 9e4e02a fixes #15524. Handle extra options resolving and `addAllowed*ForAll` rules with constant flags\n  - add `Options::NONE` constant,\n  - add `Options::ALL` constant, matches defined and extra options,\n  - add `Options::DEFINED` constant,\n  - add `Options::NESTED` constant,\n  - add `Options::EXTRA` constant, matches any undefined options, helps dealing with \"anonymous\" options (using a numerical index)\n  - add `OptionsResolver::allowedValuesForAll` a private array to validate all options even undefined but not root of nested options as they must always be an array,\n  - add `OptionsResolver::allowedTypesForAll` a private array to validate all options (as previous),\n  - add `OptionsResolver::resolveUndefined` a private `bool` to allow extra options resolving,\n  - add `OptionsResolver::addAllowedValuesForAll($options, $allowedValues, $replace = false, $nested = Options::ALL)`, first argument may be an array of options names or any flag constant except `Options::NONE`, if a root name of nested options is passed as/among first argument the method will be recursive because the fourth argument default is `Options::ALL`, prevent it by passing `Options::NONE` instead,\n  - add `OptionsResolver::addAllowedTypesForAll($options, $allowedTypes, $replace, $nested)`, same as previous, note that passing `Options::ALL` as first argument will not apply to root of nested options as they must always be arrays and on contrary will apply on extra options, pass `true` as third argument to override previous allowed types,\n  - add `OptionsResolver::setPrototypes((string|string[]) $types, (mixed) $values, $options = Options::EXTRA)`, sets `resolveUndefined` to `true` and validate any extra options with the any given type with its corresponding allowed values,\n  - add `OptionsResolver::allowExtraOptions($allow = true)`\n  \n  ``` php\n  $resolver->setNested('attachments', array($attachments))\n      ->allowExtraOptions()\n      ->addAllowedTypesForAll(Options::ALL, '\\Swift_Attachment');\n  \n  // Another way by implicitly allowing extra options:\n  $resolver->setNested('emails')\n      ->setPrototypes('string', function ($email) use ($regex) {\n          return preg_match($regex, $email);\n      });\n  ```\n  \n  The difference is that in the second case implicitly the flag `Options::EXTRA` is passed so previous defaults will not be validate by prototypes rules, if that's not what you want pass `Options::ALL` as third argument.\n  Note that `setNested()` returns the nested `OptionsResolver` instance in this examples, you could call these methods on the `$resolver` as well but this not the same:\n  \n  ``` php\n  // Any undefined global options can only be strings\n  $resolver\n      ->allowExtraOptions()\n      ->addAllowTypesForAll(Options::EXTRA, 'string', true, Options::NONE);\n  ```\n- ccd5ce1 Harden dependency of nested options with an internal class\n  - add `NestedOptions` class which extends `OptionsResolver`,\n  - add `NestedOptions::root` the parent `OptionsResolver` instance,\n  - add `NestedOptions::rootName` the root option name,\n  - add `NestedOptions::resolve()` overrides to throw an exception is parent `OptionsResolver` instance is not locked,\n  - add `OptionsResolver::isLocked()` internal public method to check from `NestedOptions` if it can be resolved.\n# Work in Progress (RFC)\n- add `OptionsResolver::setExtraNormalizer(function (Options $options, $extraName, $extraValue) { ... })` to normalize any undefined options, basically a shortcut for the currently supported `setNormalizer(Options::Extra, callable)` but with handling of `$extraName`\n- add a `OptionsResolver::prototypes` private array holding allowed values by allowed types to validate extra options.\n- be more strict on NestedOptions array type and indexing when setting defaults. Currently the implementation does not distinguish  nested defaults using a numerical index instead of names, which may cause problem when overriding them or to properly map validation/normalization.\n", "B_clean_body": ["branch", "master", "bug", "fix", "no", "new", "featur", "ye", "bc", "break", "no", "deprec", "no", "test", "pass", "ye", "fix", "ticket", "4833", So either we can add the typehint on the Response, or we can also typehint the parameter :\n\n``` php\n<?php\n\nclass Response\n{\n    // ...\n    public function __construct($content = '', $status = 200, $headers = array())\n    {\n        $this->headers = new ResponseHeaderBag((array) $headers);\n    }\n\n    // ...\n}\n```\n\nThough I think it is not as neat as the typehint directly on the parameter, but  I heard that it was a no-go to add a typehint on object's constructor, as this could be a potential BC Break. Is it still the case ? Actually, the URI generated had an IP address in place of the host. Because the host starts with a number, preg_replace tries to replace a backreference that selects nothing in the regexp pattern.\n\nThe previous bug is repeatable with the following code: \n\n```\n<?php\n$uri = 'http://127.0.0.1/login';\n$server_http_host = '227.0.0.7';\necho preg_replace('{^(https?\\://)'.parse_url($uri, PHP_URL_HOST).'}', '\\\\1'.$server_http_host, $uri);\n// outputs \"27.0.0.7/login\" instead of \"http://127.0.0.1/login\"\n```\n\nHere is the php.net documentation related to this issue:\n\nWhen working with a replacement pattern where a backreference is immediately followed by another number (i.e.: placing a literal number immediately after a matched pattern), you cannot use the familiar \\1 notation for your backreference. \\11, for example, would confuse preg_replace() since it does not know whether you want the \\1 backreference followed by a literal 1, or the \\11 backreference followed by nothing. In this case the solution is to use \\${1}1. This creates an isolated $1 backreference, leaving the 1 as a literal.\n", "A_clean_body": ["bug", "fix", "ye", "featur", "addit", "no", "backward", "compat", "break", "no", "symfony2", "test", "pass", "ye", "licens", "code", "mit", "had", "issu", "browserkit", "browser", "kit", "while", "do", "function", "test", "behat", "actual", "uri", "gener", "had", "ip", "address", "place", "host", "becaus", "host", "start", "number", "preg", "replac", "tri", "replac", "backrefer", "that", "select", "noth", "regexp", "pattern", "previou", "bug", "repeat", "follow", "code", "php", "uri", "'http", "127", "login", "server", "http", "host", "'227", "echo", "preg", "replac", "http", "pars", "url", "uri", "php", "url", "host", "1'", "server", "http", "host", "uri", "output", "27", "login", "instead", "http", "127", "login", "here", "php", "net", "document", "relat", "thi", "issu", "when", "work", "replac", "pattern", "where", "backrefer", "immedi", "follow", "by", "anoth", "number", "place", "liter", "number", "immedi", "after", "match", "pattern", "you", "not", "use", "familiar", "notat", "your", "backrefer", "11", "exampl", "would", "confus", "preg", "replac", "sinc", "it", "not", "know", "whether", "you", "want", "backrefer", "follow", "by", "liter", "or", "11", "backrefer", "follow", "by", "noth", "thi", "case", "solut", "use", "thi", "creat", "isol", "backrefer", "leav", "as", "liter"], "B_body": "| Q | A |\n| --- | --- |\n| Bug fix? | yes |\n| New feature? | no |\n| BC breaks? | no |\n| Deprecations? | no |\n| Tests pass? | yes |\n| Fixed tickets | #11139 |\n| License | MIT |\n| Doc PR | - |\n\nIn the 2.4 API it was possible to do both:\n\n``` php\n$validator->validatePropertyValue($object, 'propertyName', $myValue);\n$validator->validatePropertyValue('\\Vendor\\Namespace\\ClassName', 'propertyName', $myValue);\n```\n\nIn the 2.5 API, the second case was not supported anymore. This is fixed now.\n\nTogether with the fix comes also a small change (also in the 2.4 API) which I'll demonstrate with a code snippet:\n\n``` php\n$metadata->addPropertyConstraint('ClassName', 'propertyName', new Callback(\n    function ($value, $context) {\n        var_dump($context->getRoot());\n        var_dump($context->getPropertyPath());\n    }\n));\n\n$validator->validatePropertyValue('ClassName', 'propertyName', 'foobar');\n```\n\nBefore this PR, the output would be:\n\n```\nstring(9) \"ClassName\"\nstring(12) \"propertyName\"\n```\n\nThis doesn't make a lot of sense, because usually the following condition holds during validation:\n\n``` php\n'' === $context->getPropertyPath() || $value === $propertyAccessor->getValue($context->getRoot(), $context->getPropertyPath())\n```\n\nwhich obviously cannot work if root is a class name. Thus I changed the root and property path to become:\n\n```\nstring(6) \"foobar\"\nstring(0) \"\"\n```\n\nWith this change, the condition holds also in this case.\n", "A_clean_body": ["bug", "fix", needed to be changed, so the old behavior was probably not even intended as no test for it existed)\nFixes #5180\n\nThis can be achieved by explicitly passing the parameter. Previously it just ignored the parameter that equals the default value. You can still omit optional variables by not passing it at all or passing null as param value.\n\nExample:\nGiven the route `new Route('/index.{_format}', array('_format' => 'html'));`\nPreviously generating this route with params `array('_format' => 'html')` resulted in `/index` which means one could not generate `/index.html` at all. This has been changed. You can of course still generate just `/index` by passing array('_format' => null) or not passing the param at all.\n\nI'm certain this is the best solution to the problem even if it slightly breaks bc. "test", "case", "test", "form", "type", "extens"], "B_body": "| Q | A |\n| --- | --- |\n| Bug fix? | no |\n| New feature? | yes |\n| BC breaks? | no |\n| Deprecations? | no |\n| Tests pass? | yes |\n| Fixed tickets | ~ |\n| License | MIT |\n| Doc PR | ~ |\n\nThis PR is a improvement suggestion about `FormIntegrationTestCase`.\n\nBased on the [documentation](http://symfony.com/doc/current/cookbook/form/unit_testing.html#adding-custom-extensions), we currently have to setUp again all the form builder process just to add a type extension to get, for example, `constraints` option working.\n\nWith this modification, we can simply do something like this.\n\n``` php\nclass ChangePasswordFormTypeTest extends TypeTestCase\n{\n    protected function getTypeExtensions()\n    {\n        $validator = $this->getMock('Symfony\\Component\\Validator\\Validator\\ValidatorInterface');\n        $validator->method('validate')->will($this->returnValue(new ConstraintViolationList()));\n\n        return array(\n            new FormTypeValidatorExtension($validator),\n        );\n    }\n\n    // [...] Do your tests here.\n}\n```\n\nMuch simpler, isn't it?\n\nI think this could be done also for type guessers. Will work on it.\n\nI'm excited to see yours review comments! :+1: \n\n**Note:** This should be cherry-pick on 3.0. Could be very useful to have it on 2.7 also because of new LTS. It's up to you.\n", "B_clean_body": ["bug", "fix", "no", "new", "featur", "ye", "bc", "break", "no", "deprec", "no", "test", "pass", "ye", "fix", "ticket", "licens", "mit", "doc", "pr", "thi", "pr", It works like the pattern property (hostname_pattern can have variables, requirements, etc). The hostname_pattern property can be set on both routes and route collections.\n\nYaml example:\n\n``` yaml\n# Setting the hostname_pattern for a whole collection of routes\n\nAcmeBundle:\n    resource: \"@AcmeBundle/Controller/\"\n    type: annotation\n    prefix: /\n    hostname_pattern: {locale}.example.com\n    requirements:\n        locale: en|fr\n\n# Setting the hostname_pattern for single route\n\nsome_route:\n    pattern: /hello/{name}\n    hostname_pattern: {locale}.example.com\n    requirements:\n        locale: en|fr\n        name: \\w+\n    defaults:\n        _controller: Foo:bar:baz\n```\n\nAnnotations example:\n\n``` php\n<?php\n\n/**\n * Inherits requirements and hostname pattern from the collection\n * @Route(\"/foo\")\n */\npublic function fooAction();\n\n/**\n * Set a specific hostnamePattern for this route only\n * @Route(\"/foo\", hostnamePattern=\"{_locale}.example.com\", requirements={\"_locale=\"fr|en\"})\n */\npublic function fooAction();\n\n```\n\nPerformance:\n\nConsecutive routes with the same hostname pattern are grouped, and a single test is made against the hostname for this group, so the overhead is very low:\n\n```\n@Route(\"/foo\", hostnamePattern=\"a.example.com\")\n@Route(\"/bar\", hostnamePattern=\"a.example.com\")\n@Route(\"/baz\", hostnamePattern=\"b.example.com\")\n```\n\nis compiled like this:\n\n```\nif (hostname matches a.example.com) {\n    // test route \"/foo\"\n    // test route \"/bar\"\n}\nif (hostname matches b.example.com) {\n    // test route \"/baz\"\n}\n```\n\nThe PR also tries harder to optimize routes sharing the same prefix:\n\n```\n@Route(\"/cafe\")\n@Route(\"/cacao\")\n@Route(\"/coca\")\n```\n\nis compiled like this:\n\n```\nif (url starts with /c) {\n    if (url starts with /ca) {\n        // test route \"/cafe\"\n        // test route \"/cacao\"\n    }\n    // test route \"/coca\"\n}\n```\n", "A_clean_body": ["bug", "fix", "no", "featur", "addit", "ye", no\nSymfony2 tests pass: yes\n\nToday I wanted to add different routes for different hosts in a project. Therefore I added a new _host requirement to the routing system. This makes it possible to work with several host names in one symfony installation. It can be easily added to any route like\n\n```\n _welcome:\n   pattern: /\n   requirements: { _host: 'example.org' }\n```\n\nIt is quite useful when you define routes as annotations, because you can set a host for a whole controller:\n\n```\n/**\n* @Route(requirements={\"_host\"=\"example.org\"})\n*/\nclass MyController { ... }\n```\n\nI also added an UrlGenerator so it is possible to generate urls just like before. This should ease the comparison of role strings and instances of `Role` itself. For example, in the `FOSUserBundle` the `User` model contains roles which are represented as strings. It works like the pattern property (hostname_pattern can have variables, requirements, etc). The hostname_pattern property can be set on both routes and route collections.\n\nYaml example:\n\n``` yaml\n# Setting the hostname_pattern for a whole collection of routes\n\nAcmeBundle:\n    resource: \"@AcmeBundle/Controller/\"\n    type: annotation\n    prefix: /\n    hostname_pattern: {locale}.example.com\n    requirements:\n        locale: en|fr\n\n# Setting the hostname_pattern for single route\n\nsome_route:\n    pattern: /hello/{name}\n    hostname_pattern: {locale}.example.com\n    requirements:\n        locale: en|fr\n        name: \\w+\n    defaults:\n        _controller: Foo:bar:baz\n```\n\nAnnotations example:\n\n``` php\n<?php\n\n/**\n * Inherits requirements and hostname pattern from the collection\n * @Route(\"/foo\")\n */\npublic function fooAction();\n\n/**\n * Set a specific hostnamePattern for this route only\n * @Route(\"/foo\", hostnamePattern=\"{_locale}.example.com\", requirements={\"_locale=\"fr|en\"})\n */\npublic function fooAction();\n\n```\n\nPerformance:\n\nConsecutive routes with the same hostname pattern are grouped, and a single test is made against the hostname for this group, so the overhead is very low:\n\n```\n@Route(\"/foo\", hostnamePattern=\"a.example.com\")\n@Route(\"/bar\", hostnamePattern=\"a.example.com\")\n@Route(\"/baz\", hostnamePattern=\"b.example.com\")\n```\n\nis compiled like this:\n\n```\nif (hostname matches a.example.com) {\n    // test route \"/foo\"\n    // test route \"/bar\"\n}\nif (hostname matches b.example.com) {\n    // test route \"/baz\"\n}\n```\n\nThe PR also tries harder to optimize routes sharing the same prefix:\n\n```\n@Route(\"/cafe\")\n@Route(\"/cacao\")\n@Route(\"/coca\")\n```\n\nis compiled like this:\n\n```\nif (url starts with /c) {\n    if (url starts with /ca) {\n        // test route \"/cafe\"\n        // test route \"/cacao\"\n    }\n    // test route \"/coca\"\n}\n```\n", "A_clean_body": ["bug", "fix", "no", "featur", "addit", "ye", Next, all Deny directives are evaluated. If any matches, the request is rejected. Last, any requests which do not match an Allow or a Deny directive are denied by default.\n\nDeny,Allow\nFirst, all Deny directives are evaluated; if any match, the request is denied unless it also matches an Allow directive. Symfony 2.7 still needs an alias for the service declared for a custom constraint. Otherwise, it's not loaded as a service from the container, so the dependencies are not injected.\r\n\r\n### A. Failing example, without alias\r\n\r\n**Service declaration:**\r\n\r\n    validator.custom_less_than:\r\n        class: AppBundle\\Validator\\Constraints\\CustomLessThanValidator\r\n        arguments: ['@service_container']\r\n        tags:\r\n            - { name: validator.constraint_validator}\r\n\r\n**Constraint:**\r\n\r\n\tclass CustomLessThan extends Constraint\r\n\t{\r\n\t\tpublic $message = 'The value should be lett than \"%lessThan%\".';\r\n\t}\r\n\r\n**Validator:**\r\n\r\n\tclass CustomLessThanValidator extends ConstraintValidator \r\n\t{\r\n\t\tuse ContainerAwareTrait;\r\n\r\n\t\tpublic function __construct(ContainerInterface $service_container)\r\n\t\t{\r\n\t\t\t$this->setContainer($service_container);\r\n\t\t}\r\n\r\n\t\tpublic function validate($value, Constraint $constraint)\r\n\t\t{\r\n\t\t\t$lessThanValue = $this->container->getParameter('less_than_value');\r\n\t\t\t\t   \r\n\t\t\tif ($value > $lessThanValue)\r\n\t\t\t{\r\n\t\t\t\t$this->context->buildViolation($constraint->message)\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t->setParameter('%lessThan%', $lessThanValue)\r\n\t\t\t\t\t\t->addViolation();\r\n\t\t\t}\r\n\t\t}\r\n\t}\r\n\r\n**Result:**\r\n> Catchable Fatal Error: Argument 1 passed to AppBundle\\Validator\\Constraints\\CustomLessThanValidator::__construct() must be an instance of Symfony\\Component\\DependencyInjection\\Container, none given, called in vendor\\symfony\\symfony\\src\\Symfony\\Bundle\\FrameworkBundle\\Validator\\ConstraintValidatorFactory.php on line 71 and defined\r\n> 500 Internal Server Error - ContextErrorException\r\n\r\n### B. |\n\nHello. \n\nThe request is a data object, and so the request should not be\ninside the container. That's why the request will be removed\nfrom the container in Symfony 3.0\n\nSo it is better to let the HttpKernel injects the request when\nthe user want to use the request.\n\nMore over, it is faster. Copy and Paste error", "A_clean_title": ["minor", "document", "copi", "past", "error"], "B_title": "Update equal-width example numbering", "B_clean_title": ["updat", "equal", "width", "exampl", [-0.028781076818659764], "body_sim": [0.01284996329328894], "file_list_sim": 1.0, "overlap_files_len": 1, "code_sim": [0.0, 0.0], "location_sim": [1.0, 1.0], "pattern": 0, "time": 0}, {"A_title": "Example code for Pagination incorrect", "A_clean_title": ["exampl", "code", "pagin", "incorrect"], "B_title": "WIP: Bootstrap 3", "B_clean_title": ["wip", "bootstrap"], "A_body": "Hi,\n\nJust noticed that the example code for pagination was incorrect; it had \"Prev\" and \"Next\" in the links rather than the &laquo; and &raquo; shown in the example HTML.\n", "A_clean_body": ["hi", "just", "notic", "that", "exampl", "code", "pagin", "wa", "incorrect", "it", "had", "prev", "next", "link", "rather", "than", "laquo", "raquo", "shown", "exampl", "html"], "B_body": "While our last major version bump (2.0) was a complete rewrite of the docs, CSS, and JavaScript, the move to 3.0 is equally ambitious, but for a different reason: **Bootstrap 3 will be mobile-first.** This is an ongoing document to identify the changes we'll be making along the way.\n## Docs and repo\n\nWe'll be working to simplify the content of the docs once again. Key changes are around the organization of the pages and the tools powering them.\n#### Repository\n- [x] **Add new `dist` folder.**\n  - Includes two subfolders, `css` and `js`, each containing a regular and minified version of Bootstrap's CSS and JavaScript.\n- [x] **Separate dependencies from compiled Bootstrap files** with new `assets` folder.\n  - All files within `assets` are documentation assets or third party dependencies.\n- [x] **Switch from Makefile to Grunt.**\n  - Grunt is JavaScript-based\n  - Helps folks who want to run and compile Bootstrap locally on Windows\n  - Replaces all existing `make` commands with `grunt` commands (all the same functionality, just a different tool)\n#### General docs changes\n- [x] **Convert docs to Jekyll.** \n  - Instead of Mustache, docs templates are built with [Jekyll](http://jekyllrb.com).\n  - This greatly simplifies deploying docs changes, isolates our docs from CSS and JavaScript changes, and drastically decreases the amount of code being tracked in the repo.\n  - It also provides better URLs, page title variables, partials, and code highlighting.\n  - New repo structure\n- [x] **Host previous versions of documentation.**\n  - Instead of having folks download release tags, we'll go back and add the docs for the most recent version (2.3.2) to the site. They'll be available at http://getbootstrap.com/2.3.2/ once v3 goes live.\n- [x] **Move examples to separate repo.**\n  - Fitting with our theme of focus and simplicity in the repo, we're moving all the example templates out into their own repository at [twbs/bootstrap-examples](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-examples).\n  - This keeps the examples as static files without a Jekyll server in the way, so more folks have easy access to them.\n  - It also removes a ton of static files (the example screenshots) from the repo and that's a huge win.\n- [x] **Add \"Customizing Bootstrap\" section** to detail best practices for customizing CSS.\n- [x] **Remove all i18n tags from Mustache templates.** No more `{{_i}}` and `{{/i}}` in the docs templates, just raw HTML in our Mustache files.\n- [x] **Remove Extend page** because it's content was not directly applicable to Bootstrap and out of date with info in the readme and Getting Started page.\n#### Homepage\n- [x] Point link to the new [Bootstrap Expo](http://expo.getbootstrap.com).\n- [x] Remove examples and basically all marketing content from homepage.\n#### Getting started\n- [x] Add Bower installation instructions to guide.\n- [x] Add new Customization best practices section.\n## Global JavaScript\n- [x] Overhaul CSS transitions and reinforce with JavaScript transitions as necessary.\n- [x] Improve noConflict throughout plugins.\n- [x] Namespace events to reduce conflict issues.\n- [x] **Drop bootstrap-typeahead.js.**\n  - For context, see #7805 & https://github.com/twitter/bootstrap/commit/88dd9de9bad56b30a12466477a810c78648200c9.\n  - Instead, use [Twitter's typeahead.js plugin](https://github.com/twitter/typeahead.js/).\n## Global CSS\n\nAt a high level, we're dropping IE7 and FF3.6 support, combining standard and responsive CSS into a single file, and consolidating additional code as appropriate.\n### Browser support\n- [x] **Drop support for IE7.** Removed all `*` hacks, such as `*zoom: 1;`, and other IE7-specific lines of CSS.\n- [x] **Drop support for Firefox 3.6.** Removed `-moz-box-shadow` instances and related hacks.\n### LESS changes\n- [x] **Refactor most components to be more mixin-friendly.**\n  - Instead of all component classes being a hodgepodge of un-nested CSS, we'll re-order the code to make it super easy to take any Bootstrap class and use it as a mixin.\n  - Not all components have been rewritten this way, but those that make sense to rename have.\n- [x] **Rename variables to use dashes** instead of camelCase. For example, it's now `@body-bg` instead of `@bodyBackground`.\n- [x] **More consistent variable naming scheme.**\n  - The format of variables was all over the place and has now been standardized.\n  - The general approach is element, state, pseudo state. For example, `@navbar-link-color-hover`.\n- [x] **Replace existing color variables with more semantic ones.**\n  - No more `@blue`, `@orange`, and the like, which we weren't using them much anyway.\n  - They've been replaced with `@brand-primary`, `@brand-success`, and others. These are then assigned on a per-component basis (e.g., `@state-warning-text`, `@btn-background-primary`, etc).\n  - Also removed `@black` and `@white` because `#000` and `#fff` are 20% shorter and not something that should be controlled via variable.\n- [x] **Remove `.border-radius()` and `.border-*-*-radius` mixins.** \n  - As only Android 2.1, iOS 3.2, and older desktop browsers [require a prefixed version](http://caniuse.com/#feat=border-radius), we've removed the base mixin. Since we no longer require prefixes for independent corners, we've dropped those mixins as well. Mixins for a single side, like `.border-left-radius`, are still available.\n- [x] **Use decimal values in `.opacity()` mixin instead of whole numbers** to match default CSS patterns. \n  - For example, write `.opacity(.5)` instead of `.opacity(50)`.\n- [x] **Add retina image mixin.** Declare a standard and 2x image path and set the size for easy retina images anywhere with `.img-retina()`.\n- [x] **Add new global `@component-active-bg` variable.**\n  - Instead of assigning `@link-color` to multiple variables for backgrounds, we have dedicated a new variable to that.\n  - Change `@component-active-bg` and customize the active states of nav pills, dropdowns, and more.\n- [x] **Update gradient mixins for better color stop support.**\n  - Vertical and horizontal gradients now accept four values, in the following order: `@start-color`, `@start-percent`, `@end-color`, and `@end-percent`.\n  - Upgrading means specifying all four values in the above order, or specifying variables directly when calling your mixins.\n  - To call a gradient but only set two properties, directly assign values to the variables like so: `#gradient > .vertical(@start-color: red; @end-color: blue);`. Doing so will include the default values for any unmentioned variables.\n- [x] **Drop unused prefixes from several mixins.**\n  - See https://github.com/twitter/bootstrap/pull/8380 for more information.\n### Miscellaneous\n- [x] **Go mobile first.** Responsive CSS is no longer separate and all responsive features are now compiled into the core `bootstrap.css` file near. Separate files are no longer required, and have thus been removed.\n- [x] **Upgrade to latest Normalize, and removed reset.less.** \n  - This includes removing reset.less in favor of a dedicated normalize.less file. \n  - Print styles and responsive image CSS (the only meaningful modifications from the previous reset file) have been moved to print.less and scaffolding.less, respectfully.\n- [x] **Moved print styles to separate print.less file.**\n  - Previously print styles were bundled with the scaffolding.less page.\n  - Now within a separate file for easy removal via the Customizer.\n- [x] **Remove layouts.less.** \n  - Since it only held a couple layout styles and the fluid container has been removed (see next section), this file is superfluous. \n  - We've moved the default `.container` styles to `grid.less`.\n- [x] **Add `!important` to `.hide` and `.show`.** \n  - For these classes to work on every element, the specificity either needed to be higher or we needed the `!important` flag. We opted for the latter for fewer lines of code.\n- [x] **Drop `*-important` for `.*-danger`.** \n  - Some elements had red variations that came from different class naming schemes, so we standardized that by switching all red variations to `*-danger`. \n  - Includes buttons, labels, badges, text, alerts. and progress bars.\n- [x] Refactor responsive utility classes to match new media queries.\n## Grid system\n\nThe grid is drastically simpler, yet more powerful, in BS3. We're transitions back to a single grid system, but with all the awesomeness that was present in the old grids. On top of that, we've also added some new features.\n- [x] **Overhaul grid systems to make it fluid and mobile-first.**\n  - Removed the separate fluid grid system, container, and layout as we're down to one grid.\n  - New single grid system (still uses `.row`) utilizes percentages over pixels, `padding` instead of `margin`, and `box-sizing: border-box` for easy math.\n  - The grid is mobile first, meaning it starts out stacked and scales up as necessary to become horizontal via media queries. Previously the grid was built for 940px layouts and scaled up and down.\n  - Nesting is still 100% supported, but columns will be proportionately sized to their parent, just as the old fluid grid behaved.\n  - Offsets are still 100% supported.\n- [x] **Increase specificity of grid classes.**\n  - Instead of `.span*` and `.offset*`, we're now using `.col-*` and `.col-offset-*`, respectively.\n- [x] **Add tiny and small grid systems for phones and tablets.**\n  - Similar to the default grid system, we've added two more sets of grid classes to create more complex layouts for phones and tablets. That means you can optionally utilize 12 columns at two additional important breakpoints.\n  - Use `.col-*` classes for tiny devices (smartphones).\n  - Use `.col-sm-*` classes for small devices (tablets).\n  - The small grid classes also include support for offsets and source ordering, but the tiny grid classes do not.\n- [x] **Simplify required grid variables.**\n  - The `@grid-row-width` and `@grid-column-width` variables have been removed. We didn't use the row width (`@gridRowWidth` as of v2.3.1) variable anywhere in the source and column widths are now derived via simple calculations in our LESS.\n  - We've added a new `@grid-float-breakpoint` variable to customize the point at which the floats and widths kick in for our new mobile-first grid.\n- [x] **New and improved grid mixins.**\n  - Changed `.makeRow()` to `.make-row()`.\n  - Changed `.makeColumn()` to `.make-column()`. In addition, it includes a media query to apply the `float` and `width` when above the `@grid-float-breakpoint` value.\n  - Added `.make-column-offset()` to generate column gaps, similar to the predefined grid classes.\n- [x] **Add `.col-push-*` and `.col-pull-*` modifier classes** for easy column source ordering.\n- [x] **Remove dedicated table grid classes.**\n  - They are no longer necessary given the new grid.\n  - However, we are still removing the float on `.col-*` classes when used within `.table` elements.\n- [x] **Remove dedicated input grid classes.**\n  - Remove input grid mixin and input span classes.\n  - Given new grid system, inputs are always `width: 100%;` to start.\n  - Best practices now are to place 100% wide inputs _within_ grid columns as opposed to using classes directly on input elements.\n- [x] Use `max-width` instead of `width` on all `.container` instances to help prevent some issues with containers in components like navbars.\n## Type\n\nTypography in Bootstrap 3 isn't seeing much change, just a decent amount of cleanup and some small improvements.\n#### Headings\n- [x] Add support for headings classes (e.g., `h1, .h1 { \u2026 }`).\n- [x] Remove `text-rendering: optimizeLegibility` from headings to prevent (inconsistent) broken rendering on some Android and Windows devices.\n#### Lists\n- [x] Change `ul.unstyled` to `.list-unstyled`.\n  - No longer dependent on HTML element in the selector.\n  - Can now be used as mixin.\n- [x] Change `ul.inline` to `.list-inline`.\n  - Uses `.list-unstyled` as a mixin to reset default list styles.\n  - Can now be used as a mixin.\n#### Text classes\n- [x] **Changed `.muted` to `.text-muted`** to match the other contextual text colors.\n- [x] Fixed bug with text alignment utility classes and tables.\n#### LESS\n- [x] Remove all `#font` mixins.\n  - We only used these in one place and they honestly just complicated things.\n  - Instead of using mixins, just make use of the `@font-family-` variables.\n- [x] Drop the `@altFontFamily` variable.\n\nWe explored the use of rem units over pixels, but found little benefit to offset the implications of their use. IE8 would still need a pixel fallback, and that's a lot of duplicate lines of code. Moreover, using rems everywhere instead of pixels would exacerbate that problem. Mixing rems and pixels doesn't seem to make sense either right now. However, we can and will continue to evaluate this in future releases.\n## Tables\n- [x] **Add support for responsive utility classes on table elements.**\n- [x] Remove `table.info` from table state classes.\n- [x] Added global `text-align: left;` for `<th>` elements (to undo the default center alignment) and removed `font-weight: bold;` from them (bold is a browser default).\n- [x] Improve nesting by scoping all styles to immediate children.\n  - Using the `>` selector, we scope all styles.\n  - Doesn't change much, but does mean you'll need to apply the table classes to all nested tables.\n## Images\n- [x] **Consolidate image thumbnail styles.** No more `.img-polaroid` as it duplicated the same styles as `.thumbnail`. Now you can use `.img-thumbnail` for regular inline(-block) images, or `.thumbnail` for composite components.\n## Buttons\n\nFewer, but better buttons. They're redesigned and we're removing some from the mix because they have no clear and universal semantic purpose.\n- [x] **Default button now requires `.btn-default` class.**\n  - The default gray button requires two classes\u2014`class=\"btn btn-default\"`.\n  - This better matches all our other buttons as well.\n  - We tried to remove the `.btn` class as well, but given the CSS for creating button groups and dropdowns, it's much simpler to keep it around.\n  - While it does add an extra class, it's specificity great simplifies customization methods in plain CSS, and even more so when extending those classes with LESS mixins.\n- [x] **Drop `.btn-inverse`.**\n  - There _really_ is no semantic reasoning for having it, so it's gone.\n- [x] Revamp some of the aesthetics of the buttons (no more outer box-shadow) by default.\n- [x] **Simplify button mixins and pseudo states.**\n  - Removed the `.buttonBackground()` mixin since it was no longer in use.\n  - Added the `.btn-pseudo-states()` mixin for setting button `background-color` and `border-color` for the default and `:hover`, `:focus`, `:active`, and various `disabled` states.\n- [x] **Add justified button group option for link buttons.**\n  - This feature is only available for buttons with link tags, e.g. `<a href=\"#\" class=\"btn\">Button</a>`, and is not compatible with the `<button>` element due to some browser lame-itude that keeps buttons from accepting auto widths on `table-cell` buttons.\n## Tables\n- [x] **Add `.active` contextual class.**\n  - Applies the table hover `background-color` to any row or cell that gets the `.active` class.\n- [x] Allow contextual classes to be applied to `<thead>` and `<tfoot>` cells.\n## Forms\n\nForm controls are now 100% width by default, input groups have been overhauled, and form states simplified.\n- [x] **Update box model for inputs.** \n  - Switched to `box-sizing: border-box;` and `width: 100%;` by default for all textual inputs.\n  - This means you'll need to specify a size for inputs, whereas before 3.0 inputs had a set pixel width (around 220px) to start.\n- [x] **Remove `input-prepend` and `input-append` for singular `.input-group`.** The classes have changed for the elements within, and require a bit more markup to use buttons.\n  - Use `.input-group` as the parent class around the input and addon.\n  - For text based prepends/appends, use `.input-group-addon`  instead of `.addon`.\n  - For button prepends/appends, use `.input-group-btn` and place your `.btn` **within** that element.\n- [x] **Drop `.form-search`.**\n- [x] **Add support for `fieldset[disabled]`.** All form controls within a `<fieldset>` with the `disabled` attribute will be styled appropriately.\n- [x] **Drop `cursor: pointer;` from labels** and instead only set them on checkbox and radio label options.\n- [x] **Drop `.controls-row` for grid inputs.** \n  - Given input elements in 3.0 are set to `width: 100%` by default, and since we don't want to implement a separate input grid, we've opted to drop the `.controls-row` functionality.\n  - Instead, folks should wrap inputs in standard grid markup: with a wrapping `.row` and individual `.span*` columns around each input.\n- [x] **Drop `.input-block-level` mixin and class.** \n  - Since inputs are already `width: 100%;`, this is redundant. \n  - **Note:** inputs are still `display: inline-block`, so if you absolutely need them to be block level, you'll need to independently set that yourself.\n- [x] **Drop the `.uneditable-input` control.** Instead, use a read-only input if you must.\n- [x] **Drop `.inline-help` option.**\n- [x] **Horizontal forms are now mobile-first**, meaning at <768px, elements are stacked. Above that, elements are floated and appear side-by-side.\n- [x] **Checkboxes and radios now require an extra `<div>`.** \n  - Instead of `label.checkbox`, you'll need `div.checkbox` with a `<label>` within. \n  - This was done to tighten up the clickable area around labels and avoid potential misclicks.\n- [x] **New classes for inline radios and checkboxes.** \n  - Instead of `.radio.inline`, you now need a single class, `.radio-inline`, for direct use on a `<label>` element. \n  - To be clear, inline radios and checkboxes do not need a wrapping `<div>`, but the default stacked ones do.\n- [x] Added new placeholder syntax to the `.placeholder()` mixin for Firefox 19+.\n- [x] **Drop `.help-inline`.**\n  - Given the 100% wide inputs and focus on mobile, inline help text makes much less sense.\n  - Block help text via `.help-block` remains.\n## Icons\n- [x] **Convert to Glyphicons font and move to separate repository.**\n  - Convert to Glyphicons v1.7 @font-face and drop the old PNGs.\n- [x] **Change required base class and prefix.** \n  - Instead of using an attribute selector, like `[class^=\"glyphicon-\"]`, we now require a base class, `.glyphicon`.\n  - This improves general performance for larger pages while also increasing the durability of our code (as it doesn't enforce a specific order of classes). \n  - This is in addition to the prefix class (which has also been udpated).\n  - All classes start with `.glyphicon-` instead of `.icon-` for a more unique class and consistency with the newly required base class.\n## Responsive utilities\n- [x] Refactor responsive-utilities.less to use new mobile-first approach.\n- [x] Update the docs to reflect the changes in media queries used.\n## Button groups\n- [x] **Add support for dropdowns in button groups (or, nested button groups).**\n- [x] **Update checkbox and radio variations to use form controls.**\n  - Checkbox and radio button groups now use `<input>`s in their markup.\n## Labels and badges\n\nWe have differentiated the labels and badges with v3. The gist is that badges no longer have modifier classes and are purely meant as unread counters.\n- [x] Dropped all modifier variations on badges, making it as neutral as possible, much like those of Mail.app on OS X.\n- [x] Dropped the `.label-inverse` variation (in conjunction with the inverse button being removed).\n- [x] Refactor labels to scale with their parent's `font-size`.\n## Jumbotron (formly hero unit)\n- [x] **Class changed** from `.hero-unit` to `.jumbotron`. Associated variables have also been updated to match.\n- [x] **Lighter `font-weight` for headings**. Uses semibold instead of bold for headings.\n- [x] **Scale `font-size`** in responsive views.\n- [x] Now full-width without rounded corners to in mobile viewports.\n- [x] Improved type styles\u2014now it starts with normal heading sizes and scales to larger sizes given a larger viewport.\n## Breadcrumbs\n- [x] Remove the trailing `/` from the last item.\n## Navigation\n#### Navs\n- [x] **Remove `.nav-list` option**. Replaced by the new `.list-group` component.\n- [x] **Remove tabs on left, right, and bottom.** \n  - Tabs on the left and right, while occasionally useful, have been removed from our CSS.\n  - You can still use the JavaScript plugin and custom CSS to make left/right tabs, but we will no longer include those in the core.\n- [x] **Removed parent `<div>` in the pagination component** and **dropped center and right alignment options**. See #6562 for context.\n#### Navbars\n- [x] **Drop support for `.navbar-search`.** We dropped the `.navbar-search` form layout, so it doesn't make sense to have this anymore. Also, this is just a _slightly_ fancier `.navbar-form`, which we plan on keeping.\n- [x] **Overhaul styles of default navbar** and its sub-components:\n  - Dropdown menu carets (those attached to the actual menu, not the indicators) have been removed so that dropdown menus sit flat against the edge of the navbar.\n  - Navbar vertical dividers have been brought in a smidge, meaning they do not extend the full height of the navbar.\n  - No more box-shadow or gradients on the navbars.\n  - Height of navbar has increased from 44px to 62px for mobile devices, and 50px for desktops.\n- [x] **Removed `.navbar-inner`** and moved relevant styles to `.navbar`. The inner div is no longer required, greatly simplifying our shit.\n- [x] **Changed `.navbar > .nav` to `.navbar-nav`.**\n- [x] **Change `.btn-navbar` to `.navbar-toggle`.**\n  - More consistent naming schema\n  - Redesigned it a bit, lightening the styles and widening it, while also positioning it absolutely to the top right.\n- [x] **Updated navbar brand component:**\n  - Changed `.brand` to `.navbar-brand` for a more consistent naming schema.\n  - Center aligned `.navbar-brand` in mobile views, with a `max-width: 200px;` to limit hit area given a likely navbar toggle will be very near by.\n- [x] **Dropped navbar dividers.**\n- [x] **Added support for disabled nav links.**\n  - Includes new variables like `@navbar-link-color-disabled` and `@navbar-link-bg-disabled`, along with the inverse options.\n#### Dropdowns\n- [x] **Remove submenus** suport in dropdown menus.\n- [x] Removed `.nav-header` and replaced with `.dropdown-header` on account of no more `.nav-list` and that dropdowns still benefit from section headings.\n## Progress bars\n- [x] **Add variables for background colors.** Instead of hard-coded (and different) green, red, yellow, and blue colors, we use the new (more semantic) global colors.\n- [x] **Refactor progress bar classes** for simpler CSS.\n  - New structure is now `.progress` on the outer `<div>` and `.progress-bar` on the inner `<div>`.\n  - Instead of placing modifier classes on the parent, they are placed directly on the bars (e.g., `.progress-bar-info`) in addition to the required `.progress-bar` class.\n## Modals\n- [x] **No longer require use of `.hide`.** We updated the utility classes to use `!important` and to avoid clashing, removed the `.hide` class from modals. Now `display: none;` is set directly in the modals.less file. **When upgrading, be sure to remove the `.hide` class from existing modals.**\n- [x] **Redesign the modals to be mobile-first.**\n  - As BS3 is mobile-first, this new modal also starts at the mobile level and scales up via media queries.\n  - Reintroduces `.modal-open` on the body (so we can nuke the scroll there)\n  - Adds a couple extra levels of markup (namely `.modal-dialog` and `.modal-content`) so we can scroll the entire modal rather than overflow a section within the modal.\n  - Related, `.modal` is now the wrapper, and `.modal-content` is the modal itself. This is so we can still use `position: fixed;`, but make the modal relatively positioned so that scrolling moves the entire modal, not something with it.\n  - Added a `.modal-title` for more consistent and useful targeting of the heading content (previously this was just an `<h3>` and selector performance wise that sucked).\n- [ ] **Test on iOS5.** Not sure if we need to go older, but I want to check here to see how well fixed is supported.\n- [ ] **Test on Android devices** (including native browser and Chrome). I only have a year-old Nexus lying around, so might need help tracking down bugs on older devices.\n- [ ] **Add option to programmatically set width** of the modal.\n- [ ] Prevent `<body>` scrollbar and shifting content with `overflow: hidden;`.\n## Thumbnails\n- [x] **Drop the `.thumbnails` meta component.** Instead of special HTML and CSS for grid sizing, just use the grid system itself. Individual `.thumbnail` styles are still available, but for sizing, require a parent with a set `width` (e.g., grid columns).\n## Alerts\n- [x] `<hr>` elements within any `.alert` component will now be styled to match the border color of the alert.\n- [x] Immediate children links within default alerts, and within paragraph text, are now styled for improved readability. Links are automatically bolded and appear as a slightly darker color than the alert text.\n## New: List groups\n\nAdded a new component, the list group, for creating simple and complex series of components. Perfect for more complex implementations like email inboxes, or simple ones like a list of options.\n- Requires `.list-group` as a parent base class (on a `<ul>`, `<ol>`, or `<div>`)\n- Requires  `.list-group-item` for individual list items\n- List items can also be easily linked\u2014just change from `<ul class=\"list-group\">` and `<li class=\"list-group-item\">` to `<div class=\"list-group\">` and `<a class=\"list-group-item\">`.\n- Option: include a badge, chevron, or both to any list item for automatic placement.\n- Option: use `.list-group-item-heading` and `.list-group-item-text` for custom content implementations.\n\n**Linked list groups replace the nav list component.**\n\nList groups can also be used within panels with the `.list-group-flush` class to take them the full width of the parent panel.\n## New: Panels\n\nAdded a new component, the panel, for easily containing content within a box with an optional heading. Also included are contextual state classes for success, warning, danger, and info.\n## Tooltips\n- [x] Bump font-size from 11px to 12px.\n## Carousel\n- [x] **Redesign!** Lighter styles for the previous and next controls, as well as the carousel captions.\n- [x] **Update required markup for carousel controls.** The `.carousel-control` class now requires another element within it for the previous/next characters. Those characters are now Glyhpicons icons for improved styling and positioning across browsers and devices.\n- [x] **Indicators are now bottom-middle aligned.**\n- [x] **Captions are reinforced as optional** and, by default, are hidden on mobile views, then shown for >768px viewports.\n## Customizer\n- [x] Redesign the entire thing.\n- [ ] Highlight dependencies between components and assets.\n- [ ] Figure out how to load and download the same customizations.\n", "B_clean_body": ["while", "our", "last", "major", "version", "bump", "wa", "complet", "rewrit", "doc", "css", "A_body": "", "A_clean_body": [], "B_body": "Don't reference `Tether` via attachment to `window`, with the update one can import bootstrap providing the dependencies in webpack with:\n\n``` js\nnew webpack.ProvidePlugin({\n  $: 'jquery',\n  jQuery: 'jquery',\n  Tether: 'tether',\n});\n```\n\nThen inside one's own bootstrap/globals, `import 'bootstrap';` will simply work, and $/jQuery can be used from there.\n\nI had wanted to do this, but also expose jQuery, Tether, etc when in development build in my code, but if I provide `window.Tether`, I can't then expose it to the outside...\n", "B_clean_body": ["n't", "refer", "tether", "via", "attach", "window", "updat", "one", "import", "bootstrap", "provid", "depend", "webpack", "js", "new", "webpack", "provideplugin", "provid", "plugin", "'jqueri", "jqueri", "queri", "'jqueri", "tether", "'tether", "then", "insid", "one", "'s", "own", "bootstrap", "global", "import", "'bootstrap", "will", "simpli", "work", "jqueri", "queri", "use",
